title: Zurich American Insurance Company v. Tolbert
description: Tony Fitzgerald Tolbert (Tolbert) and Tonesha Tolbert (collectively Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Zurich American Insurance Company in this declaratory judgment action to determine Appellantsâ€™ entitlement to Underinsured Motorist (UIM) Coverage.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.

<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Zurich American
      Insurance Company, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Tony Fitzgerald
      Tolbert and Tonesha Tolbert Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4382
Heard March 5, 2008 â€“ Filed May 2, 2008
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED


	
		
			
				Matthew Christian, of Greenville, for Appellants.
				J.R. Murphy and Jeffrey C. Kull, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.: Â Tony
  Fitzgerald Tolbert (Tolbert) and Tonesha Tolbert (collectively Appellants)
  appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Zurich American
  Insurance Company in this declaratory judgment action to determine Appellantsâ€™
  entitlement to Underinsured Motorist (UIM) Coverage.  We affirm in part,
reverse in part, and remand.

FACTS
Tolbert is an employee of BMW
  Manufacturing in Greer, South Carolina.Â  As a part of a lease program for BMW
  employees, Tolbert leased a 2003 BMW 325.Â  BMW contracted with Zurich to provide business automobile insurance to its employees through its insurance policy
  (Policy), which, in addition to liability insurance, contained two endorsements
  providing UIM coverage to the leasing employees in certain circumstances.Â  
On a
  Saturday in 2003, Tolbert picked up his son from a friendâ€™s house in Greenwood, South Carolina.Â  At the time, Tolbert was driving a 1989 Honda Accord registered
  and titled in his name, instead of the BMW he was leasing from his employer.Â  The
  Honda was insured under a policy with Southern United Fire Insurance Company
  purchased by Tolbert; however, Tolbert had chosen to reject UIM coverage under
  the Honda policy.Â  On the return trip from Greenwood to Greenville, South Carolina, Tolbert was involved in an accident caused by William Humbert.Â  Tolbert was
  severely injured, and missed nearly eleven months of work, while accumulating
  over $136,000 in medical expenses.Â  In a separate proceeding, Tolbert settled
  with Humbert for the minimum liability limits of $15,000 Humbert carried on his
  automobile.Â  
Thereafter,
  Zurich filed this declaratory judgment action against Appellants, seeking a
  determination that Tolbert did not qualify as an insured for the purposes of UIM coverage under the Policy.Â  Both parties filed motions for summary
  judgment, and a hearing was scheduled shortly thereafter.Â  At the hearing,
  Appellants argued that, in addition to being a Class I insured under the
  Policy, they were entitled to UIM coverage because two separate, included
  endorsements extended coverage beyond the Policy.Â  Appellants maintained one of
  the endorsements purportedly made the Honda a temporary substitute of the
  leased BMW, and thus qualified Appellants for coverage.Â  In support of this
  assertion, Appellants submitted an affidavit stating the leased BMW was
  inoperable at the time of the accident because it was in need of servicing.Â  
The
  circuit court granted Zurichâ€™s motion for summary judgment, holding the plain
  language of the Policy explicitly excluded the portability of UIM coverage in
  the circumstances of the accident.Â  Appellants filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion
  for reconsideration, which was denied.Â  This appeal followed.
 STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion,
  this court applies the same standard of review as the trial court under Rule
  56, SCRCP.Â  Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 30, 619 S.E2d 437, 443
  (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Summary judgment is proper when no issue exists as to any
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of
  law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  To determine whether any triable issues of fact
  exist, the reviewing court must consider the evidence and all reasonable
  inferences in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Tolbert as a Class I
  Insured
Appellants first contend
  Tolbert was a named or Class I insured[1] under the Policy.Â  We believe the circuit court correctly determined he was not.
The â€œCommon Policy
  Declarationâ€ page supplies the named insured to be used throughout the entire
  Policy, and provides only BMW of North America, LLC, in the given space.Â  Below
  this provision, when given the opportunity to describe the named insured, the
  â€œCorporationâ€ box is checked.Â  Furthermore, on the â€œBusiness Auto Coverage
  Formâ€ page, the Policy provides:Â  â€œThroughout this policy the words â€˜youâ€™ and
  â€˜yourâ€™ refer to the Named Insured shown in the Declarations.Â  The words â€˜weâ€™,
  â€˜usâ€™ and â€˜ourâ€™ refer to the Company providing this insurance.â€Â  We therefore find
  Tolbert was neither a named insured nor a Class I insured of BMWâ€™s basic Policy.Â  See Concrete Servs., Inc. v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 331 S.C.
  506, 511, 498 S.E.2d 865, 867 (1998) (adopting the majority view that a
  corporation cannot have a spouse or family members that qualify as Class I
  insureds). 
II. Policy in Conflict
  With Insurance Laws of South Carolina
Appellants next
  contend Zurichâ€™s exclusion of UIM coverage is in
  conflict with the insurance laws of South Carolina.Â  We disagree.
Appellants maintain UIM coverage cannot be retracted once offered and accepted, and that UIM is
  personal and portable at all times.Â  To this end, Appellants rely principally
  on our courtâ€™s opinion in Burgess v. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company,
  which was subsequently reversed.Â  361 S.C. 196, 201 S.E.2d 861 (Ct. App. 2004), revâ€™d 373 S.C. 37, 644 S.E.2d 40 (2007).Â  Burgess is a case
  similar to the one before us, where an insured was injured in a motorcycle
  accident while operating a motorcycle which he owned, but on which he carried
  no UIM coverage.Â  The policy at issue in Burgess restricted UIM
  coverage, allowing it to be excess coverage if the vehicle involved in the
  accident was one owned by the insured, but limited it to the amount of UIM
  coverage the insured carried on the vehicle involved.Â  The supreme court
  distinguished voluntary UIM coverage, from Uninsured Motorist (UM) coverage,
  which is a mandatory part of all automobile insurance policies.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-150 (2002).Â  While the Burgess court agreed with
  our courtâ€™s determination that UIM coverage is personal and portable, the
  supreme court expressly held â€œpublic policy is not offended by an automobile
  insurance policy provision which limits the portability of basic â€˜at-homeâ€™ UIM
  coverage when the insured has a vehicle involved in the accident.â€Â  Burgess,
  373 S.C. at 42, 644 S.E.2d at 43.Â  
The Policy in the
  case before us differs from the policy at issue in Burgess, because here,
  the basic Policy completely eliminates UIM coverage from Zurich if the vehicle
  involved in the accident is owned by the insured.Â  Rather, it is the two
  separate endorsements discussed below which would under certain circumstances
  provide UIM coverage to BMW employees leasing under the program.Â  Nevertheless,
  the analysis under Burgess remains the same.Â  Tolbert was driving his
  own vehicle on which he had the ability to decide whether to purchase voluntary
  UIM coverage.Â  Tolbert made the decision not to obtain UIM coverage when he
  insured the Honda.Â  As a result, we hold the Policyâ€™s limitation on UIM
  coverage portability neither offends public policy, nor is in conflict with the insurance laws of South Carolina.
III. Coverage Under the
  Endorsements
Finally, Appellants
  contend the circuit court erred in failing to find two separate endorsements
  contained within the Policy extended UIM coverage to Tolbert.Â  
A. Drive Other
  Car Coverage Endorsement
Appellants first
  maintain the endorsement entitled â€œDrive Other Car Coverage â€“ Broadened
  Coverage for Named Individualsâ€ (DOCC) extended UIM coverage under the Policy
  to Tolbert.Â  As its name indicates, the DOCC endorsement provides for certain
  extensions of coverage from the basic Policy; specifically, the schedule
  provides that â€œ[a]ny employee furnished with a company carâ€ is entitled to a
  limit of one million dollars of UIM coverage.Â  However, the Policy specifically
  excludes the type of coverage Appellants seek in a qualification contained in
  the following DOCC endorsement, Section C:

	Changes
  in Auto Medical Payments and Uninsured and Underinsured Motorists Coverages
	The
  following is added to Who is An Insured:
	Any
  individual named in the Schedule and his or her â€œfamily membersâ€ are â€œinsuredâ€
  while â€œoccupyingâ€ or while a pedestrian when being struck by any â€œautoâ€ you
  donâ€™t own except:
	Any
  â€œautoâ€ owned by that individual or by any â€œfamily member.â€

Appellants maintain this
  qualification cannot restrict the endorsement extension of UIM coverage to
  Tolbert without adding several operable words that are not included in a
  responsible reading of Section C.Â  We disagree, and hold that Section C is
  neither vague nor open to multiple interpretations, and expressly excludes
  Tolbert from recovering UIM in the very situation that occurred.Â  
Given the express
  instructions listed above from the Business Auto Coverage Form, the only tenable
  reading of this provision is that: Â any individual named in any schedule
  (Tolbert) and his or her family members are insured while occupying . . . any
  auto you (BMW) donâ€™t own except:Â  any auto owned by that individual (Tolbert)
  or by any family member (of Tolbert). Â Essentially Section C allows for the
  portability of UM and UIM coverages to Tolbert in any accident in which he is a
  passenger or a pedestrian, except accidents involving an auto owned by Tolbert
  or one of his family members.Â  Because Tolbert was driving a vehicle that he
  owned at the time of the accident, Section C prohibits him from recovering UIM
  coverage under this endorsement.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in
  granting Zurichâ€™s motion for summary judgment as to this issue. 
B. South Carolina Underinsured Motorists Coverage Endorsement
Appellants next
  maintain a second endorsement, entitled â€œSouth Carolina Underinsured Motorists
  Coverage,â€ (SC UIM) also extends UIM coverage under the Policy to Tolbert.Â  This
  endorsement provides for the payment of UIM coverage to â€œinsured[s]â€ when
  involved in an accident andÂ  Â continues to define who is an insured according
  to whether the named insured is designated in the Declarations as:Â  (1) an
  individual; or (2) a partnership, limited liability company, corporation, or
  any other form or organization.Â  As discussed above, the named insured
  designated in the â€œCommon Policy Declarationâ€ page is BMW of North America,
  LLC. Â Accordingly, section (B)(2) of this endorsement applies. Â This
  subsection provides:

	B. Who
  Is An Insured
	
		If the Named Insured is designated in the Declarations as:
		2.
  A partnership, limited liability company, corporation or any other form of
  organization, then the following are â€œinsuredsâ€:
		
			a.
  Anyone â€œoccupyingâ€ a covered â€œautoâ€ or a temporary substitute for a covered
  â€œautoâ€.Â  The covered â€œautoâ€ must be out of service because of its breakdown,
  repair, servicing, â€˜lossâ€™ or destruction.
		
	

Appellants contend the Honda
  qualified as a temporary substitute for the covered BMW because the BMW needed
  of servicing at the time of the accident.Â  In support of this claim, Appellants
  tendered an affidavit to the court stating â€œ[t]he reason that [Tolbert was
  driving] the [Honda] . . . was due to the fact that the BMW was in need of
  service and an oil change and could not be driven.â€[2] Â 
Zurich contends
  Appellantsâ€™ Honda could not serve as a temporary substitute to the BMW because as
  an owned vehicle of Appellants, there was nothing temporary in the nature of Tolbertâ€™s
  use of it.Â  See Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Douglas, 273 S.C.
  243, 255 S.E.2d 828 (1979) (finding the use of an alleged substitute automobile
  must be temporary in order for coverage under a substitution provision to be
  extended).Â  However, unlike the DOCC endorsement, nothing in the SC UIM
  endorsement excludes an owned vehicle from being a temporary substitute under
  proper circumstances.Â  Moreover, we do not find Douglas controlling.Â 
  There, a husband purchased his wife a Pontiac he knew was stolen, replacing an
  Oldsmobile which had UIM coverage.Â  She thereupon began driving the â€œhotâ€
  automobile as her primary vehicle.Â  Subsequently, wife was killed in an
  accident while driving the stolen Pontiac.Â  In an action to determine whether
  the deceased was entitled to the benefit of UIM coverage from the Oldsmobile,
  the supreme court held the Pontiac could not qualify as a temporary
  substitute.Â  In Douglas, there was no allegation, as here, that the
  Oldsmobile was out of service.Â  Instead, we find the facts of this case more
  similar to those of Foremost Insurance Company v. Motorists Mutual Insurance
    Company, where the Ohio court found that under a similar employerâ€™s
  insurance provision, an employeeâ€™s owned motorcycle could serve as a temporary
  substitute to employerâ€™s out of service automobile.Â  854 N.E.2d 552 (2006). Â 
While Appellants will
  bear the ultimate burden at trial of proving the BMW was out of service due to
  its breakdown, repair, servicing, loss, or destruction, at this stage of the
  litigation, we find Appellantsâ€™ affidavit creates a genuine issue of material
  fact in that regard, sufficient to survive Zurichâ€™s motion for summary
  judgment.Â  See Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper
    Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 301, 305 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating â€œ[s]ummary
  judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is
  desirable to clarify the application of the lawâ€); Hall v. Fedor, 349
  S.C. 169, 173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002) (finding â€œ[e]ven when
  there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or
  inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be deniedâ€).
CONCLUSION

  We hold the grant of summary judgment was proper as to Tolbertâ€™s
  status as an insured, the Policyâ€™s adherence to the insurance laws of this
  state, and the DOCC endorsement.Â  However, Appellantsâ€™ affidavit in support of
  the Hondaâ€™s use as a temporary substitute for the BMW at the time of the
  accident created a genuine issue of fact, sufficient to survive Zurichâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the SC UIM endorsement.Â  The decision of the
  circuit court is accordingly
AFFIRMED IN
  PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
PIEPER, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.



[1] The two classes of insureds
  are: (1) the named insured, his spouse, and relatives residing in his
  household; and (2) any person using, with the consent of the named insured, the
  motor vehicle to which the policy applies and a guest in the motor vehicle. Â Garris
v. Cincinnati, 280 S.C. 149, 156, 311 S.E.2d 723, 727 (1984).
[2] The circuit courtâ€™s order granting Zurichâ€™s motion
  for summary judgment failed to address Appellantsâ€™ affidavit.Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C.
    v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2009) (stating if a
  party has raised an issue in the lower court, but the court fails to rule upon
  it, the party must file a motion to alter or amend the judgment in order to
  preserve the issue for appellate review).Â  Despite Appellants raising this
  issue in a Rule 59(e) motion, the circuit court did not rule on it.Â  Therefore,
  the issue is preserved for our review. Â Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C.
  555, 566, 633 S.E.2d 505, 510 (2006) (finding once an issue has been properly
  raised by a Rule
  59(e) motion, it is preserved, and a second motion is not required if the court
  does not
  specifically rule on the issue raised).

title: Camp v. Camp
description: In this domestic action, James Scott Camp appeals the family courtâ€™s order requiring him to pay a portion of his son's college expenses.  We find the appellant's Rule 59(e) motion was insufficient and failed to stay the time for appeal.  Consequently, this appeal is untimely, and we dismiss.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Theresa H. Camp
      and William James Camp, Respondents,
				v.
				James Scott
      Camp, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4383
Heard March 6, 2008 â€“ Filed May 2, 3008
APPEAL DISMISSED


	
		
			
				G. Waring Parker, of Summerville, for Appellant.
				William E. Hopkins, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

CURETON, A.J.:Â 
  In this domestic action, James Scott Camp (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s
  order requiring him to pay a pro rata share of the college expenses for William
  James Camp (William), a pro rata share of Theresa H. Campâ€™s (Motherâ€™s) Federal Parent
  Loan (PLUS), and $4,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We find this appeal is untimely
  and, therefore, dismiss. Â Â 
FACTS
Father and Mother are the parents of William, who was born
  September 22, 1987.Â  Father and Mother divorced in 2003.Â  Father earns $98,000
  per year as a pharmacist, and Mother earns $40,000 per year as a paralegal.Â  William
  earns approximately $13,000 per year.[1]Â Â Â  
In 2005, William began attending the University of South Carolina.Â  William received a Life scholarship in the amount of $5,000 per year, which is
  renewable annually if he maintains a grade-point average of 3.0 or better.Â  To
  pay the remaining college tuition and expenses, William received an
  unsubsidized Stafford Loan in the amount of $2,625, which is renewable annually
  in the amounts of $3,500 the second year and $5,500 the third and fourth years.Â 
  Mother and William obtained a Palmetto Assistance Loan in the amount of $5,000,
  which is not renewable.Â  In addition, Mother obtained a PLUS loan in the amount
  of $3,175, which is not renewable.Â  William completed his freshman year of
  college with a grade point average above 3.0.Â Â Â  
Williamâ€™s yearly college expenses total $18,254, including
  â€œtuition, fees, books, meal plan, meals outside of plan, housing, supplies,
  incidental expenses, and other associated or related expenses such as
  transportation, auto insurance, health insurance, gas and parking.â€Â  Father stated
  he would have calculated Williamâ€™s expenses differently, but he accepted the
  family courtâ€™s calculation of Williamâ€™s expenses.Â  In addition to these
  expenses, in 2005, William used $4,000 of his earnings to purchase a
  replacement used car to drive to school and work.Â Â  
The divorce decree did not address the issue of the partiesâ€™
  financial responsibilities for Williamâ€™s college education.Â  William is over
  the age of eighteen and therefore no longer a â€œchildâ€ under South Carolina law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-30(1) (1985). Â Although Mother and William contacted Father seeking assistance
  with funding for Williamâ€™s education, Father paid only $230 and declined to
  help further.Â  Mother and William filed suit seeking financial contributions
  from Father toward Williamâ€™s college education, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  On July
  26, 2006, the family court ordered Father to pay seventy percent of â€œthe
  difference between the total of [Williamâ€™s] education, including incidental
  expenses, and the loans, grants and scholarshipsâ€; seventy percent of the
  amount of Motherâ€™s PLUS loan; and $4,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Â Â 
On August 11, 2006, Father filed a motion for reconsideration that
  read, in its entirety:Â  

	PLEASE be advised that the Defendant through his undersigned
  attorney, will move before the Honorable David Sawyer, Jr., to reconsider the
  ruling in his Order dated July 26, 2006, in awarding [Williamâ€™s] college
  expenses and costs.Â  
	This motion hearing is set to be heard on the 18th day
  of October, 2006, at 3:45 oâ€™clock, p.m.Â  
	Please be present to defend if so minded.

Mother and William
  filed a response memorandum to this motion on October 16, 2006.Â  Father, in
  turn, faxed a memorandum in support of his motion to Mother and Williamâ€™s
  counsel on October 17, 2006.Â  Father filed his memorandum on October 18, 2006,
  approximately two hours before the hearing.Â  The family court heard and denied
  Fatherâ€™s motion for reconsideration on October 18, 2006.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
This
  appeal raises the novel question of whether a motion for reconsideration that
  is insufficient under Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP, stays the time for appeal.Â  We
  believe it does not.Â  Consequently, Fatherâ€™s appeal is untimely.
A motion
  presented in writing â€œshall state with particularity the grounds therefor, and
  shall set forth the relief or order sought. The requirement of writing is
  fulfilled if the motion is stated in a written notice of the hearing of the
  motion.â€Â  Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  â€œA motion to alter or amend the judgment shall
  be served not later than [ten] days after receipt of written notice of the
  entry of the order.â€Â  Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  Within ten days of filing a motion
  under Rule 59, the movant shall provide a copy of the motion to the judge.Â 
  Rule 59(g), SCRCP.
A
  party wishing to appeal an order of the family court must serve a notice of
  appeal on all respondents â€œwithin thirty (30) days after receipt of written
  notice of entry of the order or judgment.â€Â  Rule 203(b)(1) and (3), SCACR.Â  A
  timely Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend judgment stays the time for appeal
  until the appellant receives â€œwritten notice of entry of the order granting or
  denying such motion.â€Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR; Rule 59(f), SCRCP.Â  An untimely
  notice of appeal shall be dismissed.Â  Rule 203(d)(3), SCACR.Â  The clerk shall
  dismiss the appeal of a party who fails to comply with the Rules, and the case
  â€œshall not be reinstated except by leave of the court, upon good cause shown,
  after notice to all parties.â€Â  Rule 231, SCACR.Â  Timeliness of an appeal is a
  jurisdictional matter.Â  Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C.
  9, 17, 602 S.E.2d 772, 776 (2004).Â  An appellantâ€™s failure to comply with the
  procedural rules for appeal deprives the court of appellate jurisdiction but
  not of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  State v. Brown, 358 S.C. 382, 387,
  596 S.E.2d 39, 41 (2004).Â  
The
  question whether a motion to reconsider, alter, or amend judgment under Rule
  59(e) that is insufficient under Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP, stays the time for appeal
  is novel in South Carolina.Â  However, the federal courts may guide us on this
  issue.[2]Â 
  Rule 7(b)(1) is substantially similar to its federal counterpart, Rule 7(b)(1),
  FRCP.Â  Rule 59(e), SCRCP, is identical to its federal counterpart, Rule 59(e),
  FRCP.Â  
The
  United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit addressed this precise
  question as it relates to appeals under the Federal Rules in Martinez v.
    Trainor, 556 F.2d 818 (7th Cir. 1977).Â  There, the defendant filed a timely
  motion under Rule 59(e), FRCP.Â  Id. at 819.Â  The motion requested the
  district court to â€œâ€˜alter, amend, or vacateâ€™â€ its prior judgment.Â  One week
  later, the defendant moved for leave to file a memorandum supporting the
  motion.Â  Plaintiff objected.Â  The district court accepted defendantâ€™s
  memorandum nonetheless and subsequently denied defendantâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion.Â  When
  defendant later appealed the ruling, the plaintiff moved to dismiss the appeal
  as untimely.Â  Id.Â  The appellate court found the abbreviated motion
  complied with Rule 7(b)(1), FRCP, by adequately identifying the â€œrelief or
  order sought.â€Â  However, it failed to satisfy the additional requirement of
  stating â€œwith particularity the grounds therefor.â€Â  Id. at 820; Rule
  7(b)(1), FRCP.Â  According to the appellate court, the language at issue â€œfailed
  to state even one ground for granting the motion.â€Â  556 F.2d at 819.Â  The
  defendant argued in the alternative the memorandum he filed a week after the
  motion amended the motion itself.Â  The appellate court declined to permit what
  would, in effect, be an extension of time under Rule 6(b), FRCP,[3] stating â€œif a party could file a skeleton motion and later fill it in, the
  purpose of the time limitation would be defeated.â€Â  Id.Â  
The
  instant case, in its essentials, is analogous to Martinez.Â  Following
  the family courtâ€™s adverse ruling, Father filed a motion under Rule 59(e),
  SCRCP. Â Though timely, Fatherâ€™s motion failed to comply with Rule 7(b)(1),
  SCRCP.Â  Whereas the motion in Martinez failed only the particularity
  requirement of the federal rule, Fatherâ€™s motion satisfied neither the
  particularity nor the relief-sought requirement of the South Carolina rule.Â  Father
  neither identified an error of law by the family court nor stated a single
  ground on which the family court might grant him relief, thus failing the
  particularity requirement.Â  Furthermore, in requesting only that the family
  court â€œreconsider [its] ruling,â€ Father failed to identify the relief he sought
  through his motion.Â  Mother and William objected to the insufficiency of
  Fatherâ€™s motion in their response memorandum, and, as in Martinez, Father
  later filed a memorandum purporting to elaborate on his motion.[4] Â Like the Martinez trial court, the family court accepted the
  late memorandum and eventually denied the motion, and the movant appealed.Â Â Â  
Our
  ruling that an insufficient motion under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, does not stay the
  time for appeal comports with federal law on point as well as with prior South Carolina decisions on a closely related issue.Â  In Elam, our supreme court
  traced the history of judicial treatment of successive Rule 59(e) motions.Â  361
  S.C. at 15, 602 S.E.2d at 775.Â  Elam confirmed successive post-trial
  motions that raise no new issues do not stay the time for appeal and noted this
  ruling reflected the â€œprevailing view among federal courts.â€Â  Id. at 18,
  602 S.E.2d at 777.Â  The purposes of insufficient and successive post-trial
  motions appear to be the same:Â  both attempt to buy time without asserting a
  meritorious claim.Â  These tactics further neither justice nor efficiency, and
  we cannot facilitate their use.Â  
Our
  rules clearly state the requirements for motions and for appeals.Â  Permitting a
  post-trial motion that identifies neither the grounds on which it relies nor
  the relief sought to stay the time for appeal under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, would
  undermine our procedural rules.Â  Moreover, it would encourage parties to file
  baseless post-trial motions with the expectation of â€œfilling in the blanksâ€ at
  a later date.Â  Consequently, we find Fatherâ€™s appeal is untimely, and we
  dismiss.Â Â  
CONCLUSION

We
  find Fatherâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion for reconsideration was insufficient and failed
  to stay the time for appeal.Â  Consequently, Fatherâ€™s appeal was untimely, and
  we do not have jurisdiction to hear this appeal.Â  Accordingly, Fatherâ€™s appeal
  is 
DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  PIEPER, J., concur.


[1] Williamâ€™s 2005 W-2 statement indicates his gross
  earnings were $5,746 for that year.Â  However, William testified he works forty
  hours per week during the summer and approximately thirty hours per week during
  the school year at a rate of $8.50 per hour.Â  Assuming twelve weeks of
  full-time summer work and thirty-six weeks of part-time school-year work, Williamâ€™s
  gross income is approximately $13,260 per year.Â  
[2] Both federal courts and other state courts have
  contemplated this issue and other related issues.Â  See Allender v.
    Raytheon Aircraft Co., 439 F.3d 1236, 1238 (10th Cir. 2006) (insufficient
  post-trial motion under Rule 59(e), FRCP, did not toll time to appeal in spite
  of circuit courtâ€™s improper extension of time to file supporting memorandum); People
    v. Collins, 127 Ill.App.3d 236, 240, 468 N.E.2d 1343, 1346 (1984)
  (insufficiently specific post-trial motion did not preserve issues for review); N.C. Alliance for Transp. Reform v. N.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 645 S.E.2d
  105, 108-09 (N.C. App. 2007) (appeal of final order was untimely where
  insufficient post-trial motion under Rule 59(e), N.C.G.S. Â§ 1A-1, did not
  toll time to appeal, and only issues ruled upon in the post-trial motion were
  preserved).
[3] Rule 6(b), FRCP, is also substantially the same as
  Rule 6(b), SCRCP.Â  
[4] One notable difference between Martinez and
  this case is the timing of the objections to the Rule 59(e) motions and
  memoranda.Â  In Martinez, the defendant moved for leave to file his
  memorandum at the hearing on his motion, which occurred before his initial
  appeal period expired.Â  Id. at 819.Â  Plaintiff also objected during that
  period, thereby placing defendant on notice that his motion was insufficient.Â  Id.Â  Here, Fatherâ€™s hearing date was set well beyond the initial appeal period.Â  As
  a result, Mother and Williamâ€™s objection, and Fatherâ€™s subsequent memorandum
  supporting his motion, were all filed after the initial appeal period had
  expired.Â  However, we do not believe this difference renders Martinez distinguishable.Â

title: Murrells Inlet Corporation v. Ward
description: Does a plat recorded when property is subdivided confer an easement to the subsequent grantees of the property to the extent the easement is delineated in the plat?
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of
  Appeals

	
		
			
				Murrells Inlet Corporation, Respondent,
				v.
				Iva Mae Ward, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Horry County
J. Stanton
  Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity
Opinion No. 4384
Submitted May 1,
  2008 â€“ Filed May 2, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William Isaac Diggs, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
				Natasha M. Hanna, of Myrtle Beach, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Â Â Iva Mae Ward
  (Ward) appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order finding Ward created a fifty foot
  easement by recording a plat depicting the easement and requiring Ward to: (1)
  refrain from interference with the easement and (2) remove all encroachments
  from the easement.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Appellant Ward and other heirs inherited
  a 6.86 acre tract near Stevens Cross Road in Little River, South Carolina.Â  In
  1987, Ward became the sole owner of the entire tract.Â  In 1990, Ward divided the
  land into five lots for the purpose of transferring portions of the property to
  her children.Â  
When Ward subdivided the property, she
  granted a fifty foot right-of-way to the lots to allow access from Highway 57, as
  evidenced in a plat prepared for Ward by C.B. Berry R.L.S. and recorded in the
  Horry County Register of Deeds.Â  In the pleadings, Ward admitted she provided
  the fifty foot easement pursuant to the Horry County Zoning and Planning
  Regulations.Â  However, Ward now claims the surveyor included the road on the
  plat under the erroneous belief that the regulations required the easement for
  the creation of a subdivision.Â  Additionally, Ward avers she was unaware the
  plat included a fifty foot roadway and only intended for the existing driveway
  to remain as a shared private drive.Â  
Ward owns a house located on Lot A. Â She has resided and continues to reside at this address since the subdivision of
  the property.Â  Lot A is the closest lot to the access point for the subdivision
  off of Highway 57.Â  
After subdividing the property, Ward conveyed
  Lot 4 to her son Michael, who constructed a house on the property.Â  Lot 4 is located behind the other lots and is the farthest from Highway 57.Â  Access to Lot 4 is provided by a right-of-way running across one side of Wardâ€™s property.Â  Michael
  used this right-of-way for access to his portion of the tract.Â Â Â  
In 2003, Michael defaulted on a mortgage
  on the property and went into foreclosure.Â  In 2005, Respondent Murrells Inlet
  Corporation (MIC) purchased Lot 4, including the house and any improvements
  thereon and the accompanying right-of-way.Â  MIC then began using Lot 4 as rental property and presently has tenants residing in the home.Â  
MIC purchased the property with the
  understanding that there was a fifty foot right-of-way providing access to the
  lot.Â  The right-of-way is an unpaved dirt road that runs from Highway 57
  through the edge of Wardâ€™s property, passing alongside each of the lots in the
  tract, and ending at Lot 4.Â  It consists of two dirt ruts which allow only a
  single vehicle at a time to access the lots.Â  Â Â 
The right-of-way is currently in poor
  condition. Â Several encroachments in the right-of-way add to the difficulties
  inherent in traveling the road in its current state and prevent any
  improvements to the road from being completed.Â  Because of the roadâ€™s present condition
  and the encroachments, the tenants residing at Lot 4 have a hard time getting
  to and from their home and have expressed concerns that it may be impossible
  for an emergency vehicle to reach Lot 4.Â  MIC has repeatedly objected to Ward
  about the obstruction of the right-of-way to no avail.Â  
MIC filed a Petition for an Order to
  Remove Encroachments and a Rule to Show Cause against Ward and a hearing was
  held.Â  In issuing the order, the master concluded that Ward granted and
  dedicated an easement to Lot 4 when the tract was subdivided and Ward was not
  allowed to interfere with the use of the granted easement.Â  
In the Order to Remove Encroachments,
  the master noted that Ward and her family placed the following encroachments in
  the right-of-way:Â  an old truck filled with trash and debris, a rusty water
  heater, wooden poles, a wooden storage shed, a garden, various scrap metal,
  mattress springs, lawnmowers, and some other miscellaneous trash and debris.Â  The
  master found that Wardâ€™s misuse of the easement deprives MIC of the concurrent
  use of the easement for the purposes of ingress and egress to Lot 4.Â  

	The master ordered:Â  
	[Ward] shall not block the easement or
  use the easement for any purpose other than as a private driveway.Â  [Ward]
  shall, within fourteen days, remove those items that are within the fifty-foot
  right of way which encroaches upon the easement.Â  If [Ward] does not remove
  those items within the time allowed, [MIC] may remove said items and [Ward]
  shall pay the cost of the removal.Â  [Ward] shall also pay [MIC] the costs of
  this action and must pay the pro-rata share of any further improvements to the
  road.Â  

Following the decision of the master,
  Ward filed a Motion for Reconsideration.Â  The motion was denied.Â  
ISSUE
Does
  a plat recorded when property is subdivided confer an easement to the subsequent
  grantees of the property to the extent the easement is delineated in the plat?
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
The
  determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a law
  action and is subject to the any evidence standard of review when tried by a
  judge without a jury.Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633,
  635 (1998); Goodwin v. Johnson, 357 S.C. 49, 52, 591 S.E.2d 34, 35-36
  (Ct. App. 2003); Pittman v. Lowther, 355 S.C. 536, 540, 586 S.E.2d 149,
  151 (Ct. App. 2003); Revis v. Barrett, 321 S.C. 206, 208, 467 S.E.2d 460,
  462 (Ct. App. 1996); Smith v. Commissioners of Pub. Works, 312 S.C. 460,
  465, 441 S.E.2d 331, 334 (Ct. App. 1994); see also Jowers v. Hornsby,
  292 S.C. 549, 551, 357 S.E.2d 710, 711 (1987) (â€œThe decision of the trier of
  fact as to whether or not an easement exists will be reviewed by this Court as
  an action at law.â€).Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, the judgeâ€™s
  findings of fact will not be disturbed on appeal unless there is no evidentiary
  support for the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  
While
  the determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a
  law action, the question of the extent of an easement is an action in equity.Â  Tupper
    v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 323, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997); Plott
      v. Justin Enters., 374 S.C. 504, 510, 649 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2007); Lighthouse Tennis Club Village Horizontal Prop. Regime LXVI v. South Island Pub. Serv. Dist., 355 S.C. 529, 532, 586 S.E.2d 146, 147 (Ct. App. 2003); Eldridge
        v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 416, 503 S.E.2d 191, 200 (Ct. App.
  1998); Smith, 312 S.C. at 465, 441 S.E.2d at 334.Â  â€œ[In] an action in
  equity referred to a master for final judgment, we may find facts in accordance
  with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Van Blarcum v. North Myrtle Beach, 337 S.C. 446, 450, 523 S.E.2d 486, 488 (Ct. App. 1999); accord Stackhouse v. Cook, 271 S.C. 518, 521, 248 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1978); Settlemeyer
    v. McCluney, 359 S.C. 317, 320, 596 S.E.2d 514, 516 (Ct. App. 2004); Thomas
      v. Mitchell, 287 S.C. 35, 37-38, 336 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 1985); see
        also Tupper, 326 S.C. at 323, 441 S.E.2d at 190 (finding since it is
  an action in equity, the Court may take its own view of the evidence); Binkley
    v. Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation Dist., 348 S.C. 58, 67, 558 S.E.2d
  902, 907 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe scope of an easement is an equitable matter in
  which a reviewing court may take its own view of a preponderance of the
  evidence.â€). Â â€œOur broad scope of review, however, does not require this Court
  to disregard the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses
  and was in a better position to judge their credibility.â€Â  Plott, 374
  S.C. at 510-511, 649 S.E.2d at 95; accord Thomas, 287 S.C. at 38,
  336 S.E.2d at 155.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ward
  contends the master-in-equity erred by recognizing a fifty foot easement across
  Wardâ€™s property and requiring her to refrain from interference or encroachment
  on the easement.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œ
  â€˜An easement is a right which one person has to use the land of another for a
  specific purpose.â€™ â€Â  Frierson v. Watson, 371 S.C. 60, 67, 636 S.E.2d
  872, 875 (Ct. App. 2006) (quoting Steele v. Williams, 204 S.C. 124, 132,
  28 S.E.2d 644, 647 (1944)); accord Forest Land Co. v. Black, 216
  S.C. 255, 261, 57 S.E.2d 420, 423 (1950); Smith, 312 S.C. at 465, 441
  S.E.2d at 335.Â  â€œ â€˜A reservation of an easement in a deed by which lands are
  conveyed is equivalent, for the purpose of the creation of the easement, to an
  express grant of the easement by the grantee of the lands.â€™ â€Â  Frierson,
  371 S.C. at 67, 636 S.E.2d at 875 (quoting Sandy Island Corp. v. Ragsdale,
  246 S.C. 414, 419, 143 S.E.2d 803, 806 (1965)); accord Douglas v.
    Medical Investors, Inc., 256 S.C. 440, 445, 182 S.E.2d 720, 722 (1971).Â  â€œ[W]here
  a deed describes land as is shown as a certain plat, such becomes a part of the
  deed.â€Â  Carolina Land Co., Inc. v. Bland, 265 S.C. 98, 105, 217 S.E.2d
  16, 19 (1975); accord Lynch v. Lynch, 236 S.C. 612, 623, 115
  S.E.2d 301, 307 (1960); Frierson, 371 S.C. at 67, 636 S.E.2d at 876.Â  â€œBoth
  deeds and easements are valid to subsequent purchasers without notice when they
  are recorded.â€  Frierson, 371 S.C. at 67, 636 S.E.2d at 876 (citing
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-7-10 (Supp. 2005)).  â€œThe purpose of the recording
  statute is to protect a subsequent buyer without notice.â€  Frierson,
  371 S.C. at 67, 636 S.E.2d at 876 (emphasis omitted) (citing Burnett v.
    Holliday Bros., 279 S.C. 222, 225, 305 S.E.2d 238, 240 (1983)).
â€œWhere land is subdivided, platted into
  lots, and sold by reference to the plats, the buyers acquire a special property
  right in the roads shown on the plat. Â If the deed references the plat, the
  grantee acquires a private easement for the use of all streets on the map.â€Â  Davis v. Epting, 317 S.C. 315, 318, 454 S.E.2d 325, 327 (Ct. App. 1994); accord Carolina Land, 265 S.C. at 105, 217 S.E.2d at 19; Blue Ridge Realty
    Co. v. Williamson, 247 S.C. 112, 118, 145 S.E.2d 922, 925 (1965); Corbin
      v. Cherokee Realty Co., 229 S.C. 16, 25, 91 S.E.2d 542, 546 (1956); Newton
        v. Batson, 223 S.C. 545, 549-550, 77 S.E.2d 212, 213 (1953); Outlaw v.
          Moise, 222 S.C. 24, 30, 71 S.E.2d 509, 511 (1952); Cason v. Gibson,
  217 S.C. 500, 508-509, 61 S.E.2d 58, 61 (1950); Billings v. McDaniel,
  217 S.C. 261, 265, 60 S.E.2d 592, 593-594 (1950); Van Blarcum, 337 S.C.
  at 451, 523 S.E.2d at 488; Giles v. Parker, 304 S.C. 69, 73, 403 S.E.2d
  130, 132 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  The easement referenced in the plat is dedicated to
  the use of the owners of the lots, their successors in title, and to the public
  in general.Â  Carolina Land, 265 S.C. at 105, 217 S.E.2d at 19; Blue Ridge, 247 S.C. at 118, 145 S.E.2d at 925. Â As to the grantor, who
  conveyed the property with reference to the plat, and the grantee and his
  successors, the dedication of the easement is complete at the time the
  conveyance is made.Â  Newington Plantation Ests. Assns. v. Newington
    Plantation Ests., 318 S.C. 362, 365, 458 S.E.2d 36, 38 (1995); Immanuel
      Baptist Church of North Augusta v. Barnes, 274 S.C. 125, 130-131, 264
  S.E.2d 142, 145 (1980); Carolina Land, 265 S.C. at 105, 217 S.E.2d at 19; Outlaw, 222 S.C. at 30, 71 S.E.2d at 511; Pittman, 355 S.C. at
  542, 586 S.E.2d at 152. 
The grantee receives a private easement at
  the time of conveyance in any streets referenced in the plat.Â  Carolina Land,
  265 S.C. at 105-106, 217 S.E.2d at 19; Blue Ridge, 247 S.C. at 119, 145
  S.E.2d at 925; Giles, 304 S.C. at 73, 403 S.E.2d at 132.; see Newington
    Plantation, 318 S.C. at 365, 458 S.E.2d at 38 (â€œWhile dedication for public
  use is significant to the creation of a public easement, it is irrelevant to
  the determination whether a private easement exists.â€).Â  â€œ â€˜[W]here lands are
  platted and sales are made with reference to the plat, the acts of the owner in
  themselves merely create private rights in the grantees entitling the grantees
  to the use of the streets and ways laid down on the plat or referred to in the
  conveyance.â€™ â€Â  Vick v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 347 S.C. 470, 478, 556
  S.E.2d 693, 697 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Outlaw, 222 S.C. at 31, 71
  S.E.2d at 512).Â  â€œAbsent evidence of the sellerâ€™s intent to the contrary, a
  conveyance of land that references a map depicting streets conveys to the
  purchaser, as a matter of law, a private easement by implication with respect
  to those streets, whether or not there is a dedication to public use.â€Â  Newington Plantation, 318 S.C. at 365, 458 S.E.2d at 38.Â  Recordation of a
  plat containing an easement may be sufficient to show that the owner intended
  to dedicate that easement.Â  Van Blarcum, 337 S.C. at 450, 523 S.E.2d at
  488 (citing McAllister v. Smiley, 301 S.C. 10, 15, 389 S.E.2d 857, 861
  (1990) (Toal, J., dissenting)).Â  
Recently,
  in an excellent academic writing, our Supreme Court explicated the law of
  implied easements in Inlet Harbour v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Parks,
    Recreation and Tourism, Op. No. 26459 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 17, 2008)
  (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 11 at 15, 20-21):

	The creation of an implied
  easement generally requires that the facts and circumstances surrounding the
  conveyance, the property, the parties, or some other characteristic demonstrate
  that the objective intention of the parties was to create an easement. Â 25 Am. Jur. 2d
	Easements and Licenses Â§ 19 (2004); 28A C.J.S. Â§ 62.Â  Courts
  have, over time, developed various presumptions regarding the creation of
  implied easements in certain circumstances.Â  One such presumption arises when
  an owner subdivides his land and has the land platted into lots and streets.Â 
  This Court has recognized the general rule that when an owner conveys
  subdivided lots and references the plat in the deed, the owner grants the lot
  owners an easement over the streets appearing in the plat.Â  See, eg.,
	Blue
    Ridge Realty Co., 247 S.C. at 118, 145 S.E.2d at 924-925.Â  
	. . . 
	As a starting point, we note
  that the intentions of the parties to the transaction are the overriding focus
  when examining implied easements.Â  McAllister v. Smiley, 301 S.C. 10,
  16, 389 S.E.2d 857, 862 (1990) (Toal, J. dissenting); 28A C.J.S. Â§Â§ 82, 149;
  17A Am. Jur. Â§Â§ 40, 116; 25 Am. Jur. 2d. Â§ 19.Â  Thus, the Department over-reads
	Blue Ridge considerably in suggesting that the case stands for the
  proposition that an easement created by reference to a plat is presumptively an
  easement of a particular scope.Â  The rule applied in Blue Ridge is
  nothing more than a presumption that when a grantor conveys property with
  reference to a plat showing streets or other ways of passage, the grantor
  intends to allow the grantee the use of the delineated streets and ways of
  passage.Â  McAllister, 301 S.C. at 11-12, 389 S.E.2d at 858.Â  The case 
	Cason
    v. Gibson, 217 S.C. 500, 61 S.E.2d 58 (1950), explained the policy underlying
  this presumption in terms of estoppel.Â  In that case, this Court explained that
  when a grantor conveys land abutting a street, he is estopped from denying the
  streetâ€™s existence and the right of the grantee to its use.Â  Id. at 507,
  61 S.E.2d at 61.Â  This approach is reasonable, and it is also reasonable that
  when an owner conveys property that has been subdivided for residential
  purposes, the grantor presumably intends for grantees to have access to the
  abutting subdivision streets for normal residential purposes.Â  But the property
  at issue here is not subdivided residential property and abuts no road.Â  This
  demonstrates the problems that might occur if we were to apply a rigid
  presumption based solely upon particular geography or land division.Â  Our guidepost
  must be what the parties intended, and the best evidence of the partiesâ€™
  intentions are the facts and circumstances surrounding the conveyance.Â  Â 

The existence of an easement is NOT an issue in this case.Â  Only, the extent and scope of the easement is
  contested.Â  Because we are proceeding in equity, we may find facts in
  accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
The evidentiary record is imbued with
  intransigence and arrogance on the part of Ward.Â  Her belated activity in emasculating
  the easement by placing encroachments in the right-of-way is both unappealing
  and unavailing.Â  The factual finding by the master in regards to Wardâ€™s misuse
  of the easement is supported by the testimony.Â Â  To allow Wardâ€™s intent to
  override the original grant of a fifty foot easement would result in a travesty
  of justice.Â  Her demonstrated intent to eliminate a reasonable easement belies
  common sense.Â  
In the instant case, when Ward
  subdivided the property and recorded a plat referencing a fifty foot
  right-of-way, it may be inferred that she intended the right-of-way to be a
  private easement dedicated to the use of the lot owners, their successors in
  title, and the public.Â  The deed and the recorded plat in this case are
  controlling notwithstanding an â€œintentâ€ analysis.Â  By recording the easement on
  the plat, Ward evidenced an intention to grant that easement to any future lot
  owners in the subdivision.Â  When Ward originally conveyed Lot 4 with reference
  to the recorded plat, her grantees and any subsequent purchasers acquired the
  right to use this easement to the full extent that it is indicated in the plat.Â 
  MIC relied upon the recorded plat when it purchased Lot 4.Â  The dedication of
  the private easement was complete when Ward originally conveyed the lot.Â  It
  would now be unfair to deny MIC the right to the full use and enjoyment of the
  easement as indicated in the plat, regardless of what Ward now argues were her
  intentions at the time the plat was recorded.Â  Subsequent purchasers are
  entitled to rely on recorded deeds and plats to determine their rights in
  respect to property.Â  
CONCLUSION
Juxtaposing the Blue Ridge rule,
  the holding in Inlet Harbour, and the partiesâ€™ intentions, we come to
  the ineluctable conclusion that MIC is entitled to use of the fifty foot
  easement in order to access Lot 4 and this right-of-way should not be
  encroached upon or obstructed.Â  Accordingly,
  the order of the master is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Collins v. Frasier
description: The jury entered a defense verdict for Mark Frasier in this motor vehicle accident case and specifically found Frasier experienced a sudden, unforeseeable incapacity to operate his vehicle.  The record, which included medical testimony, supported this finding.  Therefore, we affirm.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Case No.:
          2004-CP-21-488
        Calvin Ben
          Collins, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Mark Conrad
          Frasier, Respondent.
        
          Case No.:
            2004-CP-21-489
        Faye B.
          Collins, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Mark Conrad
          Frasier, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Thomas A. Russo, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â Â  4385
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 6, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stephen J. Wukela, of Florence, for Appellants.
        Michael Mills Nunn, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.: This
  case arises out of a motor vehicle accident where the vehicle driven by Mark
  Frasier crossed the centerline and struck Calvin Collinsâ€™s vehicle.Â  Calvin and
  his wife, Faye, sued Frasier for the resulting injuries and loss of
  consortium.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Frasier after finding he suffered
  a sudden, unforeseeable incapacity to operate his vehicle.Â  The Collinses
  appeal the trial courtâ€™s denial of motions for a directed verdict, judgment
  notwithstanding the verdict, new trial, or to alter or amend the verdict.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
 In Boyleston v.
  Baxley, 243 S.C. 281, 284-85, 133 S.E.2d 796, 797 (1963), the South
  Carolina Supreme Court held a vehicle operator is not ordinarily chargeable with
  negligence when he suddenly losses consciousness due to an unforeseen cause.[2]Â 
  The court in Boyleston assigned the burden of proving such incapacity to
  the defendant.Â  243 S.C. at 285, 133 S.E.2d 797. Â The appeal before us today
  turns on whether Frasier presented sufficient evidence to create a jury
  question as to whether he suffered a sudden, unforeseeable incapacity to
  operate a vehicle.Â  We hold Frasier presented evidence which removed his
  sudden, unforeseeable incapacity defense from the realm of conjecture into the
  field of permissible inference.Â  As a result, the trial court properly
  presented the defense to the jury and committed no error in refusing to set the
  verdict aside.
We find the
  Collinsesâ€™ reliance on Howle v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 288 S.C. 586, 344
  S.E.2d 157 (Ct. App. 1986) unavailing.Â  In Howle, the jury rejected the
  defendant driverâ€™s defense of sudden, unforeseeable incapacity and found for
  the plaintiff.Â  Id. at 588, 344 S.E.2d at 158. Â The trial court denied a
  motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict by the defendant driver.Â  Id. at 589, 344 S.E.2d at 158. Â This Court affirmed the trial court after reviewing the evidence and all inferences reasonably
  deducible in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party, which is the applicable
  standard of review.Â  Id.Â  The driver in Howle suffered
  from diabetes for over thirty years, missed a meal, and appeared to be ill when
  dealing with a customer prior to the accident.Â  Id. at 589-90, 344
  S.E.2d at 158-59.Â  Because a question of fact was presented, the trial court
  correctly presented the defense of sudden, unforeseeable incapacity to the
  jury.Â  The point is that in Howle, as in the case before us, a jury
  question was presented.Â  There will always be examples where claims and
  defenses prevail in one factual setting but not in another.Â  Juries resolve
  questions of fact, just as the jury did in Howle and the jury did in the
  case before us.
In this case, the
  jury specifically found Frasier experienced â€œa sudden unforeseeable incapacity
  to operate his vehicle.â€Â  The only question we must answer is whether there is
  any evidence to support this finding.Â  We find the record contains ample
  support for this finding.Â  Frasier testified he felt fine while driving until
  suddenly he felt all of his energy drain and saw fuzz.Â  Frasierâ€™s family
  doctor, Dr. Robert Richey, was qualified as an expert in internal medicine.Â 
  Dr. Richey testified to his knowledge Frasier had not exhibited signs of
  fainting prior to the accident.Â  Following the accident, Dr. Richey
  administered a glucose tolerance test.Â  The test indicated Frasier suffered
  from hypoglycemia.Â  Dr. Richey explained a hypoglycemic event can result in
  loss of consciousness and the medicine Frasier was taking at the time of the
  accident could mask hypoglycemia.
 We agree with the
  Collinses that a defendantâ€™s own, self-serving testimony is insufficient by
  itself to create a question of fact as to
  the defense.Â  However, this is simply not the case here.Â  Frasier did not
  merely testify he blacked out.Â  In
  addition to Frasierâ€™s testimony regarding the event, the record includes Dr.
  Richeyâ€™s testimony about a likely cause of the incapacity, Frasierâ€™s lack of
  history with this illness, and the potential masking of the symptoms by
  Frasierâ€™s other medications.Â  Further, the Collinses find fault with the juryâ€™s
  assessment of the weight and credibility of the evidence in light of the
  conflicting testimony.Â  The issue of credibility is for the jury alone.Â  Parsons
    v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 67, 456
  S.E.2d 366, 368 (1995) (stating the credibility and weight of testimony
  is for the trier of fact).
In sum, Frasier
  provided sufficient proof of sudden, unforeseeable incapacity to create an
  issue of fact for the jury.Â  Therefore, no error occurred when the trial court
  denied the Collinsesâ€™ motions for directed verdict, judgment notwithstanding
  the verdict, new trial, and motion to alter or amend.Â  The judgment of the
  trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and HUFF, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The supreme court specifically recognized â€œthe
  principle that â€˜the operator of an automobile is not ordinarily chargeable with
  negligence because he is suddenly stricken by a fainting spell, or loses
  consciousness from some other unforeseen cause, and is unable to control the
  vehicle.â€™â€ Â Boyleston, 243 S.C. at 284-85, 133 S.E.2d at 797 (quoting 5A
  Am. Jur. Automobiles and Highway Traffic Â§ 223 (Supp. 1963)).

title: State v. Anderson
description: Anderson appeals his criminal conviction for first-degree burglary, asserting the trial court erroneously admitted evidence of an unauthenticated fingerprint card.  We find the fingerprint card was properly authenticated and affirm.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Richard Philyaw
          Anderson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4386
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 6, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Lanelle C. Durant, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and
          Assistant Attorney General Julie M. Thames, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John
          Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  In
  this criminal action, Richard P. Anderson appeals his conviction for
  first-degree burglary and sentence of twenty years in prison.Â  Anderson argues the trial court erred in admitting an unauthenticated rolled ten-print card as maintained in the automated fingerprint
  identification system (AFIS) into evidence.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On August 15, 2003, Pricilla Ward
  discovered someone had broken into the home she shared with her husband.Â  The
  intruder had gained access to the home by breaking a bedroom window.Â  The Wards
  discovered several items missing from the home, including jewelry and firearms.Â 
  Officer Hardee of the Horry County Police Department responded to the break-in
  and lifted two fingerprints from the broken window.Â  Hardee identified Stateâ€™s
  Exhibit One and Two as the lift cards of fingerprints taken off the window in
  the bedroom.Â  
The State called Sergeant Gause as an expert in the field of
  fingerprint analysis.Â  Gause testified he analyzed Stateâ€™s Exhibit One and Two,
  checking them through AFIS.Â  He explained how the AFIS machine takes a picture
  from a latent print which is then downloaded into the computer and sent through
  AFIS, which searches the database.Â  Gause testified AFIS produces twenty to
  thirty possible matches, and the operator then has to physically review each
  potential matching print and compare it with the latent print from the crime
  scene.Â  Gause identified Stateâ€™s Exhibit Three as the enlarged photograph of
  Stateâ€™s Exhibit One, one of the prints taken from the scene.Â  Stateâ€™s Exhibit
  Four was identified by Gause as â€œthe known printâ€ from the database that was found
  to be a match to the latent print.Â  Stateâ€™s Exhibit Four included an
  identification number of â€œSC00454508â€ in the bottom left-hand corner, which
  identified the individual to whom it belonged.Â  When they obtain the
  identification number of a matching print from AFIS, they then identify the
  person to whom that individual number is assigned.Â  Gause identified Stateâ€™s
  Exhibit Seven as a â€œknown rolled ten-print.â€Â  He explained that once a person
  is arrested, law enforcement rolls the prints on cards and the cards are
  retained on file in a database through SLED and the FBI.Â  Gause then identified
  Stateâ€™s Exhibit Seven as Andersonâ€™s ten-print card.Â  
At this point, Anderson objected to testimony regarding Stateâ€™s
  Exhibit Seven, the rolled ten-print card, arguing the rolled prints from the
  database had not been properly authenticated pursuant to State v. Rich,
  293 S.C. 172, 359 S.E.2d 281 (1987).Â  The court ruled the ten-print card
  required authentication.Â  The State indicated it would present evidence of a
  witness from SLED regarding AFIS.Â  Noting the ten-print card in question
  originated from Kirkland Correctional Facility, the State proposed, and counsel
  for Anderson agreed, the witness would identify it as coming from a South
  Carolina Law Enforcement Agency, apparently to avoid injecting information that
  it was taken at a correctional facility.Â  However, Anderson maintained the
  State was required to present testimony regarding the individual who actually
  took the print, and that information that it was taken by law enforcement would
  be insufficient for authentication.Â  The court disagreed, ruling the State was
  not required â€œto have the officer who actually took [the print].â€Â  
The State then presented the testimony of Lieutenant Joseph Means
  from SLED, who is in charge of the crime
  information center at SLED and oversees the AFIS system there.Â  Lieutenant Means described SLEDâ€™s
  procedures regarding ten-print cards and AFIS.Â  He testified AFIS stores all the digital fingerprint images of every
  ten-print card in South Carolina.Â  Means explained Stateâ€™s Exhibit Seven was a
  normal ten-print card, printed from the AFIS system work station.Â  Printed on
  the card is a state identification number, which Means explained is a unique
  number assigned to each individual when first arrested that stays unique to the
  individual no matter how many times that person is arrested.Â  A record is kept
  of which identification number belongs to which individual.Â  Means testified Stateâ€™s Exhibit Seven bore
  identification number â€œSouth Carolina 00454508,â€ which belonged to Anderson.Â  He then stated this ten-print fingerprint
  card of Anderson was taken on April 7, 2004 by a law enforcement agency.Â  He
  further testified these prints were sent to him and entered into the AFIS by
  his staff.Â  Means testified he was the custodian of the cards, and that once a
  fingerprint card is sent into SLED, his office maintains the card in the exact
  manner in which it arrives.Â  The
  trial court admitted the rolled ten-print card into evidence over Andersonâ€™s objection.Â  Thereafter, Anderson was convicted of first-degree burglary and
  sentenced to twenty years in prison.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission or
  exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial court, and
  the courtâ€™s decision will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion. Â State
    v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 208, 631 S.E.2d 262, 265 (2006).Â  An abuse of
  discretion occurs when the decision of the trial court is based upon an error
  of law or upon factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â  Id. Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Anderson contends the trial court erred in admitting the
  rolled ten-print card as maintained in AFIS into evidence because the card was
  not properly authenticated.Â  We disagree.Â  
Properly
  authenticated fingerprints are admissible against a criminal defendant. Â State
    v. Rich, 293 S.C. 172, 173, 359 S.E.2d 281, 281 (1987). Â Further, under the
  business records exception or the public records exception, admission of police
  fingerprint records is generally considered not to violate the prohibition
  against hearsay.Â  Id. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-5-510 (1985)
  (Providing in regard to business records as evidence, â€œ[a] record of an act,
  condition or event shall, insofar as relevant, be competent evidence if the
  custodian or other qualified witness testifies to its identity and the mode of
  its preparation, and if it was made in the regular course of business, at or
  near the time of the act, condition or event and if, in the opinion of the
  court, the sources of information, method and time of preparation were such as
  to justify its admission.â€); Rule 803(8),
  SCRE (Providing in regard to public
  records and reports, â€œ[r]ecords, reports,
  statements, or data compilations, in any form, of public offices or agencies,
  setting forth (A) the activities of the office or agency, or (B) matters
  observed pursuant to duty imposed by law as to which matters there was a duty
  to report. . .â€ are not excluded by the hearsay rule.). Â Â However, the party offering fingerprints into
  evidence must comply with the usual requirements of authentication. Â Rich,
  293 S.C. at 173, 359 S.E.2d at 281.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In Rich, our
  supreme court cited with approval a North Carolina case, State v. Foster,
  284 N.C. 259, 200 S.E.2d 782 (1973), in determining whether a fingerprint
  comparison had been properly authenticated.Â  293 S.C. at 173, 359 S.E.2d at 282.Â 
  The court noted in Foster, a police officer testified he identified a
  latent fingerprint with one alleged to be the defendantâ€™s which was on a
  fingerprint card in the master file of the police department. Â Id.Â  There, the prosecution neither attempted to lay a foundation that the
  fingerprints on the master file card were in fact those of the defendant, nor
  sought to introduce the master file card. Â Id.Â  In conclusion, the North
  Carolina Supreme Court held: Â â€œ[W]ithout evidence as to when and by whom the card was made and that the prints on the card were in fact those of this
  defendant,â€ testimony concerning the fingerprint card from the master file â€œviolated
  the hearsay rule and should have been excluded.â€ Â Id. Â at 174, 359
  S.E.2d 282 (emphasis added); Foster, 284 N.C. at 273, 200 S.E.2d at 793
  (emphasis added).Â  
Guided
  by the Foster holding, the South Carolina Supreme Court reversed Richâ€™s
  conviction and held a witness should not have been allowed to testify regarding
  fingerprint data contained in an unauthenticated document.Â  Rich, 293
  S.C. at 174, 359 S.E.2d at 282.Â  The court found the latent prints which the
  law enforcement agent had taken himself were properly admitted.Â  Id. at 173, 359 S.E.2d at 281.Â  However, testimony regarding the inked impressions
  used to compare to the latent prints was improper since the inked impressions
  were not properly authenticated.Â  Id. Â at 174, 359 S.E.2d at 282.Â  As in Foster, the State in Rich â€œneither attempted to lay a foundation
  that the fingerprints on the master file card were in fact those of the
  defendant, nor sought to introduce the master file card.â€Â  Id. Â at 173,
  359 S.E.2d at 282.
In
  the present case, Anderson contends a proper interpretation of Rich requires the State to present the actual person who took the fingerprint to
  testify in order to authenticate the fingerprints from the master card as
  evidence.Â  We do not believe Rich stands for such a strict authentication
  requirement.Â  Instead, we find the evidence presented by the State, showing
  when and where the fingerprints were taken and how they were submitted to SLED,
  and describing the process implemented by law enforcement for taking the
  fingerprints and maintaining an accurate record of them in AFIS, was sufficient
  to authenticate the fingerprints as Andersonâ€™s known prints.Â  See Rule
  901(a) and (b)(9), SCRE (â€œThe requirement of authentication or identification
  as a condition precedent to admissibility is satisfied by evidence sufficient
  to support a finding that the matter in question is what its proponent claims.â€
  Â â€œ[T]he following [is an example] of authentication or identification
  conforming with the requirements of this rule:Â  Evidence describing a process
  or system used to produce a result and showing that the process or system
  produces an accurate result.â€)Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly
  admitted testimony concerning the ten-print card.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Blanding v. Long Beach Mortgage Company
description: This case involves the issue of insurance proceeds.  Sandra Blanding (mortgagor) appeals the Master-in-Equity's determination that an insurance policy obtained by mortgagee provided excess coverage only and was not available to reduce Blanding's debt, and that the mortgagee is entitled to $49,495.14 due on Blanding's debt, prejudgment interest in the amount of $6,736.48, and $6,768.38 in attorneys' fees, for a total judgment of $63,000, the amount of insurance proceeds available from a policy obtained by Blanding.

<!--
