THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Sandra
          Blanding, Appellant,
        v.
        Long Beach
          Mortgage Company, Washington Mutual, Inc., Deutsche Bank National Trust
          Company, as Trustee for Long Beach Mortgage Loan Trust, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Robert E. Watson, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. Â 4387
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 6, 2008
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled July
21, 2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jay J. Hulst, of Moncks Corner, for Appellant. 
        Tina Cundari and Elizabeth Van Doren Gray, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  In
  this declaratory judgment action involving insurance proceeds, Sandra Blanding
  appeals the masterâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Long Beach Mortgage Company, Washington Mutual, Inc., and
  Deutsche Bank National Trust Company, as Trustee for Long Beach Mortgage Loan
  Trust.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The present case arises out of a dispute regarding the partiesâ€™
  rights with respect to casualty insurance proceeds paid for foreclosed property
  owned by Sandra Blanding.Â  In February 2003, Blanding executed and delivered a
  mortgage for $40,000 to Money First Financial Services, Inc., for the purchase
  of a manufactured home.Â  The mortgage was secured by real property located in Berkley County, South Carolina, to which the manufactured home was permanently attached.Â 
  Shortly thereafter, the mortgage was assigned to Long Beach Mortgage Company, a
  wholly owned subsidiary of Washington Mutual, Inc.Â  Approximately one year
  later, in January 2004, the mortgage was assigned to Deutsche Bank National
  Trust Company, as trustee for Long Beach Mortgage Loan Trust 2003-4.[2]Â  
As the borrower, Blanding was required to maintain insurance on
  her property which named Lender as mortgagee and/or as an additional loss
  payee.Â  Specifically, the mortgage requires as follows:

  Property Insurance.Â  Borrower shall keep the improvements now existing or hereafter
    erected on the Property insured against loss by fire . . . . All insurance
    policies required by Lender and renewals of such policies . . . shall name
    Lender as mortgagee and/or as an additional loss payee.Â  

Additionally, the
  mortgage provides: â€œ[i]f Â Borrower fails to maintain any of the
  coverages described above, Lender may obtain insurance coverage, at Lenderâ€™s
  option and Borrowerâ€™s expense.â€Â  The mortgage further states that in the event
  of loss: 

  Unless Lender and Borrower otherwise agree in writing, any
    insurance proceeds, whether or not the underlying insurance proceeds were
    required by Lender, shall be applied to restoration or repair of the Property,
    if the restoration or repair is economically feasible and Lenderâ€™s security is
    not lessened . . . . If the restoration or repair is not economically feasible
    or Lenderâ€™s security would be lessened, the insurance proceeds shall be applied
    to the sums secured by this Security Instrument, whether or not then due, with
    the excess, if any, paid to Borrower.Â  

Finally, the
  mortgage provides that attorneysâ€™ fees incurred in â€œa legal proceeding that
  might significantly affect Lenderâ€™s interest in the property and/or rights
  under this Security Instrumentâ€ shall become the additional debt of Blanding as
  the borrower.Â  
In August 2004, Blanding purchased a home insurance policy from
  Foremost Insurance Company (Foremost).Â  The policy issued by Foremost provided
  for $63,000 worth of coverage on Blandingâ€™s residence and named Washington
  Mutual as the lienholder.Â  In addition, the policy included an â€œother insuranceâ€
  clause providing â€œ[i]f both this and other insurance apply to a loss,
  [Foremost] will pay our share.Â  Our share will be the proportionate amount that
  this insurance bears to the total amount of all applicable insurance.â€Â  In
  November 2004 Lender, apparently under the misapprehension that Blanding had
  not obtained coverage on the property as required, obtained an insurance policy
  from American Security Insurance Company (American Security) providing $48,000
  worth of coverage on Blandingâ€™s property.Â  The American Security policy also
  included an â€œother insuranceâ€ clause which states â€œ[i]f there is any other
  valid or collectible insurance which would attach if the insurance under this
  policy had not been effected, this insurance shall apply only as excess and in
  no event as contributing insurance and then only after all other insurance has
  been exhausted.â€Â  
On December 7, 2004, the Master-in-Equity issued an order finding
  Blanding failed to make payments due as provided on the note.Â  He ordered
  Blandingâ€™s mortgage be foreclosed and the property sold at public auction.Â  At
  the time of foreclosure, the total debt due on the mortgage, including
  interest, escrow adjustments, late charges, costs, and attorneysâ€™ fees, was
  $51,995.14.Â  On January 1, 2005, prior to the foreclosure sale, Blandingâ€™s
  residence was destroyed by fire.Â  On January 5, 2005, the property was sold at
  public auction to Lender for $2,500.Â  
On January 31, 2005, American Security issued a check to
  Washington Mutual Bank in the amount of $22,403.91 for losses arising out of
  the fire.Â  Thereafter, on May 27, 2005, Foremost issued a check in the amount
  of $62,750[3] made payable to Blanding and her attorneys, as well as Washington Mutual and
  Deutsche Bank. Â When Lender discovered proceeds were issued under the Foremost
  policy, Lender returned the $22,403.91 to American Security based on its
  determination it was required to do so under the terms of the policy. Â The
  parties disagreed as to their rights to the Foremost proceeds, with Lender
  asserting these proceeds were to be applied first to the full amount of
  Blandingâ€™s debt due on the mortgage.Â  
Blanding filed this declaratory judgment action on November 10,
  2005 asserting Lender failed and refused to apply the other insurance proceeds
  paid in connection with the loss, and claiming she was entitled to an
  accounting of her debt and application of â€œany and all insurance proceeds paid
  or payable to or received by [Lender].â€Â  Lender answered and counterclaimed,
  asserting the American Security policy applied only â€œas excess and in no event
  as contributing,â€ and it was therefore entitled to receive from Blanding the
  amount of the debt at the time of foreclosure, less the $2,500 received in the
  foreclosure sale, together with prejudgment interest and attorneysâ€™ fees.Â 
  Blanding replied to Lenderâ€™s counterclaim, maintaining she was entitled to a
  set-off or credit for insurance proceeds received by Lender, including those
  retuned to American Security.Â  She further generally denied Lenderâ€™s
  counterclaim for prejudgment interest and attorneysâ€™ fees, and asserted her own
  right to recover attorneysâ€™ fees and costs.Â  
The matter was referred to the Master-in-Equity by order dated
  January 27, 2006.Â  Subsequently, both Blanding and Lender filed motions for
  summary judgment seeking a determination of the partiesâ€™ rights with respect to
  the casualty insurance proceeds paid for Blandingâ€™s foreclosed property.Â  Blanding
  argued she was entitled to have the proceeds from the American Security policy
  credited toward her debt and she was therefore due $35,908.77 from the Foremost
  proceeds, while Lender was entitled to only $27,091.23.Â  In the alternative,
  Blanding maintained the excess â€œother insuranceâ€ clause in the American
  Security policy was void as a matter of law, and therefore the American
  Security coverage was contributive insurance.Â  Under this application, Blanding
  claimed entitlement to a credit of $27,216, leaving a balance due to Lender of
  $22,279.14 and $40,720.86 due Blanding from the Foremost proceeds.Â  Lender asserted
  the American Security policy provided excess coverage only, and that Blanding
  was seeking to recover insurance proceeds to which she was not entitled and had
  refused to endorse the Foremost check to allow the proceeds to be applied to
  her debt.Â  Accordingly, Lender maintained it was entitled to recover prejudgment
  interest and attorneysâ€™ fees incurred in the current litigation.Â  Blanding
  argued Lender was not entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees as the mortgage had been
  released, and any obligations under the mortgage agreement were therefore
  terminated.Â  
Upon consideration of the cross-motions for summary judgment, and
  following a separate hearing on attorneysâ€™ fees, the Master ruled Lender was
  â€œentitled to be paid for the debt owed at the time of foreclosure, less $2,500,
  the amount bid by [Lender] at the foreclosure sale, plus pre-judgment interest,
  [attorneysâ€™] fees, and costsâ€ from the proceeds available in this case.Â  The
  master further determined the Foremost policy provided primary coverage while
  the American Security policy provided secondary or excess coverage only, and
  the insurance proceeds from Blandingâ€™s Foremost policy should be the first
  applied to the sums secured by the mortgage agreement.Â  He found Lender
  entitled to $49,495.14 on Blandingâ€™s debt due, plus $6,736.48 in prejudgment
  interest and $6,768.38 in attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Accordingly, the Master ordered
  Lender was entitled to the full amount of the $63,000 in available insurance
  proceeds.Â  Blanding then filed a motion for reconsideration and to alter or
  amend judgment pursuant to Rule 59 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure which, with the exception of the deletion of one sentence from the
  order, was denied.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is
  proper where no genuine issue exists as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Hurst v. E. Coast Hockey League, Inc., 371 S.C. 33, 36, 637 S.E.2d 560, 561
  (2006).Â  On appeal from a grant of summary judgment, the appellate court
  applies the same standard governing the trial court.Â  Id. Â at 35, 637
  S.E.2d at 561.Â  The trial court should
  grant summary judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any,
  show there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is
  entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Â Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A.,
  353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d 329, 334 (2003).Â  In determining whether any
  triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Law
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).
  â€œA court considering summary judgment neither makes factual determinations nor
  considers the merits of competing testimony; however, summary judgment is
  completely appropriate when a properly supported motion sets forth facts that
  remain undisputed or are contested in a deficient manner.â€Â  David v. McLeod
Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 250, 626 S.E.2d 1, 5 (2006).

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Masterâ€™s Refusal to
  Apply American Security Proceeds
Blanding
  first contends the master erred in failing to apply the insurance proceeds paid
  by American Security to reduce her outstanding debt.Â  She argues that the
  American Security payment of $22,403.91 was paid in settlement of the fire and,
  under the terms of the mortgage agreement, these sums must therefore be applied
  to her debt.Â  Specifically, she points to the language of the agreement that â€œany insurance proceeds, . . . shall be
  applied to restoration or repair,â€ and ifÂ  â€œ restoration or repair is not
  economically feasible . . . , the insurance proceeds shall be applied to the
  sums secured by this Security Instrument, whether or not then due, with the
  excess, if any, paid to Borrower.â€Â  Blanding asserts this language requires
  Lender to apply the proceeds of the American Security policy to her debt, and
  that she is then entitled to any excess proceeds after application of both the
  American Security and Foremost policy proceeds.Â  
In making this argument, Blanding does not dispute that the sums
  originally paid by American Security were returned by Lender after discovery of
  the Foremost coverage. Â However, she contends the return of those funds did not
  â€œexpunge the payment of those proceedsâ€ nor alter the requirement that these
  proceeds be applied to her mortgage debt.Â  Blanding makes several arguments as
  to why the returned funds must be included in the payment of insurance proceeds
  under the mortgage agreement.
A.Â  â€œOther
  Insuranceâ€ Clauses
Blanding
  argues the Masterâ€™s determination of which policy pays first is irrelevant, as
  both insurers have already paid.Â  She asserts the â€œother insuranceâ€ clauses,
  used by the Master to determine which policy was primary, do not apply because
  this is not a contribution action between insurers, but a dispute between
  insureds over proceeds that have already been paid.Â  Accordingly she maintains
  the Master erroneously relied on the â€œother insuranceâ€ clauses in the two
  policies in refusing to apply the American Security proceeds.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[C]ourts
  faced with the distasteful chore of apportioning liabilities among multiple
  insurers should look to the language of the policies to ascertain whether the
  policies are intended to provide primary or secondary coverage.â€Â  S.C. Ins. Co. v. Fid. & Guar. Ins. Underwriters, Inc., 327 S.C. 207,
  214, 489 S.E.2d 200, 203 (1997) (emphasis in original).Â  â€œIn other words, the relevant
  question is not whether a policy is blanket or specific, but what is the â€˜total
  policy insuring intentâ€™ embodied within the policy.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œOne method
  insurance companies use to indicate whether they intend to provide primary,
  secondary, or other coverage is to include in their policies â€˜other insuranceâ€™
  clauses that attempt to apportion liability among multiple insurers.â€Â  Id. at 215, 489 S.E.2d at 204.Â  â€œAn â€˜excessâ€™ clause, the most common kind of â€˜other
  insuranceâ€™ clause, provides a policy will cover only amounts exceeding the
  policy limits of other insurance covering the same risk to the same property.â€Â  Id. 
We
  find disingenuous Blandingâ€™s assertion that the rules concerning determination
  of policy coverage among more than one policy do not apply because this is an
  action between insureds, as opposed to insurers.Â  The crux of this litigation
  is which proceeds are available to be applied to the loss.Â  In the present
  case, the mortgage agreement provides Blanding is required to maintain property
  insurance naming Lender â€œas mortgagee and/or an additional loss payee.â€Â  In the
  event of loss, the mortgage further provides: â€œthe insurance proceeds shall be
  applied to the sums secured by [the mortgage agreement], whether or not then
  due, with excess, if any, paid to Borrower.â€Â  Therefore, under the plain
  and unambiguous terms of the mortgage agreement, any insurance proceeds must be
  first applied to sums secured by the mortgage agreement, with any excess paid
  to Blanding.Â  The American Security policy provided that if there were â€œany other valid or
  collectible insurance which would attach if the insurance under this policy had
  not been effected, this insurance shall apply only as excess and in no
  event as contributing insurance and then only after all other insurance has
    been exhausted.â€ Â (emphasis added). Â Here,
  it is undisputed that the Foremost policy was collectible insurance that would
  attach had the American Security policy not been effected.Â  Additionally, the
  Foremost policy was sufficient to cover the loss of the insured property and,
  thus, the American Security policy, as an excess policy, would provide no
  proceeds.Â  
B.Â  Policiesâ€™ Coverage of
  the Same Interests for Same Insureds
Blanding
  maintains, however, even if the Master properly considered the â€œother
  insuranceâ€ clauses to apply in a dispute between insureds, his analysis was
  still flawed because, in order for the â€œother insuranceâ€ clauses to apply, the
  policies must cover the same risk and same interest for the benefit of the same
  insured over the same period of time.Â  She argues the policies cover different
  interests for the benefit of different insureds, and therefore the â€œother
  insuranceâ€ clauses are inapplicable.Â  We disagree.
Our
  courts have held that â€œâ€˜[o]ther insuranceâ€™ clauses are intended to apportion an
  insured loss between or among insurers where two or more policies offer
  coverage of the same risk and same interest for the benefit of the same insured
  for the same period.â€Â  S.C. Ins. Co. v. Fid. & Guar. Ins. Underwriters,
    Inc., 327 S.C. 207, 212, 489 S.E.2d 200, 202 (1997).Â  â€œThese clauses began
  their lives as an attempt to prevent fraud in the overinsuring of property.â€Â  Id. Â Further, our courts have held that a mortgagor and mortgagee have separate and
  distinct interests in the same property which they may insure.Â  Johnson v.
    Fid. & Guar. Ins. Co., 245 S.C. 205, 209, 140 S.E.2d 153, 155 (1965); Murdaugh
      v. Traders & Mechs. Ins. Co., 218 S.C. 299, 307-308, 62 S.E.2d 723,
  726-27 (1950). Â 
While
  we agree with Blanding that she and Lender had separate and distinct interests
  in the property for insurance purposes, we disagree that, as a result, the two
  policies in question fail to cover the same interests for the benefit of the
  same insureds.Â  Although the parties have separate insurable interests, it is
  possible for both to have contracted to insure the same insurable interest.Â  Thomas
    v. Penn Mut. Fire Ins. Co., 244 S.C. 581, 585, 137 S.E.2d 856, 858 (1964).Â  The policy issued by Foremost
  provided for $63,000 worth of coverage on Blandingâ€™s dwelling at her Pineville
  address, naming Blanding as the insured but also denoting Washington Mutual as
  the lienholder, as required by the mortgage agreement which states Blanding â€œshall keep the improvements now existing or hereafter erected on
  the Property insured against loss by fireâ€ and that â€œ[a]ll insurance policies
  required by Lender and renewals of such policies . . . shall name Lender as
  mortgagee and/or as an additional loss payee.â€Â  Accordingly, the Foremost
  policy, while insuring Blandingâ€™s interest in the property, likewise insured
  Lenderâ€™s interest in the property.Â  The American Security policy provided the
  named insured mortgagee was Washington Mutual Bank, and named Blanding as the
  additional insured.Â  It likewise insured the property at Blandingâ€™s Pineville
  address stating, â€œit is agreed that the insurance applies to the property
  described above and to any person shown as an Additional Insured with respect
  to such property. . . .â€Â  It further noted â€œ[l]oss, if any, shall be adjusted with
  and payable to the above Named Insured Mortgagee, and the Additional Insureds
  as their interests may appear. . . .â€Â  Thus, the American Security policy
  insured the same property, during the same period, against the same risk for
  the benefit of the same insureds.Â  Both
  policies were intended to provide coverage for the mortgaged property that was
  security for the debt.Â  Thus, the two policies, while insuring the partiesâ€™
  separate and distinct interests, each insured the same interest of the
  mortgagor and the same interest of the mortgagee.Â  In other words, while
  Blanding and Lender may have separate and distinct interests insured by the
  policies, both policies insured both partiesâ€™ interests.Â  Accordingly, we find
  the two policies contracted to insure the same insurable interest, and there is
  no merit to Blandingâ€™s assertion that the â€œother insuranceâ€ clause in the
  American Security policy is inapplicable on this basis.Â  
C.Â  â€œOther Insuranceâ€
  Clause Conflict with Statutory Law
Finally
  Blanding claims, even if the policies did cover the same risks, interests, and
  insureds during the same period of time, the â€œother insuranceâ€ clause in the
  American Security policy conflicts with statutory law and is therefore
  invalid.Â  Specifically, Blanding points to sections 38-75-20 and 38-75-220 of
  the South Carolina Code of Laws in support of this argument. Section 38-75-20
  provides in pertinent part:

  No
    insurer doing business in this State may issue a fire insurance policy for more
    than the value stated in the policy or the value of the property to be insured.
    . . .Â  If two or more policies are written upon the same property, they are
    considered to be contributive insurance, and, if the aggregate sum of all such
    insurance exceeds the insurable value of the property, as agreed by the insurer
    and the insured, each insurer, in the event of a total or partial loss, is
    liable for its pro rata share of insurance.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-75-20
  (2002).Â  Section 38-75-220 provides in part:

  No
    insurer transacting a mobile home insurance business in this State and writing
    hazard insurance covering loss from physical damage to the mobile homes may
    issue a policy for more than the value stated in the policy or the value of the
    property to be insured. . . .Â  If two or more such policies are written upon
    the same property and covering the same interests, they are considered to be
    contributive insurance, and, if the aggregate sum of all such insurance exceeds
    the insurable value of the property, as agreed by the insured and insurer, each
    insurer, in the event of a total or partial loss, is liable for its pro rata
    share of insurance.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-75-220
  (2002).
Blanding
  argues, to the extent the two policies in question cover the same interests,
  the â€œother insuranceâ€ clause in the American Security policy is invalid because
  it conflicts with sections 38-75-20 and 38-75-220 of the South Carolina Code.Â 
  She argues under these sections such policies are deemed to be concurrent and
  contributive as a matter of law, and as such, each insurer is primarily liable
  for its pro rata share of the loss to the extent the aggregate sum of insurance
  exceeds the insurable value of the property.Â  Again, we disagree.
â€œ[I]f
  policies insure the same entity and interest against the same casualty, then the
  coverage provided by the policies is concurrent, thus requiring pro rata
  contribution absent a contrary provision in an â€˜other insuranceâ€™ clause contained in one of the policies.â€Â  S.C. Ins. Co. v. Fid. & Guar. Ins.
    Underwriters, Inc., 327 S.C. 207, 214, 489 S.E.2d 200, 203 (1997) (emphasis
  added).Â  Here, the American Security policy contains an â€œother insuranceâ€
  clause that provides â€œ[i]f
  there is any other valid or collectible insurance which would attach if the
  insurance under this policy had not been effected, this insurance shall apply
  only as excess and in no event as contributing insurance and then only after
  all other insurance has been exhausted.â€Â  Thus,
  the policy language clearly provides to the contrary and the coverage provided
  by the policy is not â€œconcurrent and contributive as a matter of law.â€
II.Â  Award of Attorneysâ€™
  Fees
Blanding
  raises as her next issue the propriety of the award of attorneysâ€™ fees.[4]Â 
  The Master determined attorneysâ€™ fees were warranted under the terms of the
  mortgage agreement, which provided such fees became the additional debt of
  Blanding.Â  Here, the mortgage agreement contains broad language regarding
  Lendersâ€™ rights to recover attorneysâ€™ fees:

  Protection of Lenderâ€™s Interest in the Property and Rights Under
    this Security Agreement.Â 
    If . . . there is a legal proceeding that might significantly affect Lenderâ€™s
    interest in the Property and/or rights under this Security Instrument (such as
    a proceeding in bankruptcy, probate, for condemnation or forfeiture, for enforcement
    of a lien which may attain priority over this Security Instrument or to enforce
    laws or regulations) . . . then Lender may do and pay for whatever is
    reasonable or appropriate to protect Lenderâ€™s interest in the Property and
    rights under this Security Instrument . . . . Lenderâ€™s actions can include, but
    are not limited to . . . (c) paying reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees to protect its
    interest in the Property and/or rights under this Security Instrument. 
  Any amount disbursed by Lender under this [section] shall become
    additional debt of Borrower secured by this Security Instrument.Â  

Blanding maintains, however,
  attorneysâ€™ fees are not recoverable under the terms of the mortgage because
  Lenderâ€™s rights under the mortgage were extinguished when the foreclosure
  judgment was entered.Â  We disagree. 
Blanding
  cites section 29-3-780 of the Code for the proposition that once Lender
  foreclosed the mortgage and the property was sold, Lenderâ€™s lien against the
  property was released, cancelled, and satisfied.Â  This section provides that â€œ[u]pon confirmation of the circuit court of the report of the master . . .
  Â pursuant to decree of foreclosure, the officer of the court making the sale
  shall cause to be recorded in the office where the foreclosed mortgage is recorded
  a release, cancellation, and satisfaction of the lien. . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  29-3-780 (2007).Â  This section further provides, â€œHowever, nothing in this
  section may be construed to satisfy any unpaid portion of the debt secured by
  the mortgage.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, while the mortgage may well have been deemed
  â€œreleased, cancelled, and satisfiedâ€ under this section, the sale is not
  construed to satisfy any unpaid portion of the debt secured by the mortgage
  agreement.Â  By the clear terms of the agreement, the attorneysâ€™ fees incurred
  by Lender in pursuing the insurance proceeds became the additional debt of
  Blanding secured by the mortgage agreement and were thus unpaid debt secured by
  the mortgage agreement that remained unsatisfied under section 29-3-780.
Blanding
  further cites Ryan v. S. Mut. Bldg. & Loan Assâ€™n, 50 S.C. 185, 27
  S.E. 618 (1897) for the proposition that the mortgage agreement merged into the
  foreclosure judgment such that the contract was extinguished, and therefore the
  attorneysâ€™ fee provision was no longer viable.Â  However, Ryan involved a
  suit for double the sum of interest collected by the defendant alleged to be
  received in excess of lawful interest, challenging the collection of the money
  as usurious, instituted subsequent to receipt of the proceeds in a foreclosure
  judgment and sale.Â  Id. Â at 186, 27 S.E.2d at 618-19.Â  There, the court
  determined the contract said to be usurious had become merged into the judgment
  of foreclosure, extinguishing the original contract.Â  Id. at 190, 27
  S.E. at 619. Â The court further noted â€œ[t]he judgment became a new debt,â€ and
  was not â€œinfected by the usurious nature of the cause of action.â€Â  Id.Â  In so ruling, the court was guided by the law that â€œ[a] judgment is the final
  determination of the rights of the parties in an action . . . and is conclusive
  of all matter necessarily involved, whether raised or not; especially if the
  party denying the adjudication knew of the matter, and could have interposed it
  at the previous trial, either in support of a claim or as a defense.â€Â  Id. at 188, 27 S.E. at 619.Â  In the case at hand, Lender could not have raised the
  issue of attorneysâ€™ fees incurred in the collection of the insurance proceeds,
  as no insurance issues were implicated at that time since the property had not
  yet been destroyed by fire.Â  Thus, this matter could not have been raised at
  the foreclosure proceeding and we do not believe the mortgage agreement was
  completely merged into the foreclosure such as to extinguish the broad
  conveyance of rights to collect attorneysâ€™ fees in â€œa legal proceeding that might significantly affect
  Lenderâ€™s interest in the Property and/or rights underâ€ the mortgage agreement.Â 
  Accordingly, we find no error in the award of attorneysâ€™ fees.
III.Â  Award of
  Prejudgment Interest
Lastly, Blanding contends the Master erred in awarding prejudgment
  interest to Lender, running from the date of issuance of the Foremost check to
  Blanding until the date of the summary judgment hearing.Â  We disagree.
Blanding asserts the $49,495.14 awarded to Lender from the
  insurance proceeds does not constitute damages and this is, therefore, not a
  liquidated damages case with a stated account.Â  She further maintains she never
  had possession or control of the proceeds and, accordingly, could not have paid
  the proceeds to Lender.Â  â€œThe
  law has long allowed prejudgment interest on obligations to pay money from the
  time when, either by agreement of the parties or operation of law, the payment is demandable, if the sum is certain or
  capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v.
    Court St., LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 133, 631, S.E.2d 252, 258 (2006).Â  Thus, â€œthe proper test for determining whether
  prejudgment interest may be awarded is whether the measure of recovery, not
  necessarily the amount of damages, is fixed by conditions existing at the time
  the claim arose.â€Â  Id. Â at 133, 631 S.E.2d at 259.Â  Consequently, â€œ[t]he
  right of a party to prejudgment interest is not affected by
  rights of discount or offset claimed by the opposing party.â€Â  Id. Â at 133-34,
  631 S.E.2d at 259.Â  Rather, â€œ[i]t is the character of the claim and not the
  defense to it that determines whether prejudgment interest is allowable.â€Â  Id. Â at 134, 631 S.E.2d at 259.Â  
Here,
  Blandingâ€™s indebtedness was certain throughout litigation.Â  The measure of
  recovery was fixed by conditions existing at the time the proceeds were
  issued.Â  Accordingly, Blanding was obligated to pay the insurance proceeds when
  she received them in May 2005.Â  We further find no merit to Blandingâ€™s
  assertion she had no control over the proceeds because the check was made out
  to her along with Lender.Â  She merely had to endorse the check along with
  Lender to have the proceeds applied to her debt.Â  
Blanding
  also argues Lender is entitled to no more than $49,495.14 from the available
  insurance proceeds as that is the extent of Lenderâ€™s interest in the property
  at the time of the fire.Â  Thus, she maintains, by awarding prejudgment
  interest, the Master effectively allowed Lenders to recover a deficiency
  judgment.Â  However, the award of prejudgment interest did not alter or add to
  the Lenderâ€™s interest in the property. Â As noted by the master, â€œ[t]he
  foreclosure judgment fixed the amount of [Blandingâ€™s] debt and was a final
  adjudication thereof.Â  The award of prejudgment interest does not alter the
  foreclosure judgment.Â  The interest is being awarded on top of the amount due
  and owing, not in alteration of that amount.â€
Blanding
  next contends if Lenders are entitled to prejudgment interest on their interest
  in the proceeds, she is likewise entitled to prejudgment interest on the
  remaining insurance proceeds that she was due after payment of her debt.Â  We
  disagree.Â  In her complaint, Blanding sought application of available insurance
  proceeds.Â  Lenders admitted the Foremost Insurance proceeds were to be applied
  to Blandingâ€™s debt, but denied that they refused to apply any other available
  insurance proceeds, i.e. those form the American Security policy.Â  As
  previously found, the Foremost policy was sufficient to cover the loss of the
  insured property and, thus, the American Security policy, as an excess policy,
  provided no proceeds for the loss.Â  Had Blanding relinquished the sum certain
  due Lenders at the time the proceeds were issued to her, she would have
  received the excess proceeds from the Foremost policy at that time.Â  It is
  clear Lenders sought only their share of the proceeds from the Foremost policy
  when this action was instituted by Blanding.Â  Because Lenders did not deny
  Blanding her interest in the excess, we find no merit to her assertion she is
entitled to prejudgment interest. 
Blanding also contends the original foreclosure judgment included
  $7,517 in prejudgment interest on her debt and that by including prejudgment
  interest on this same debt, the Masterâ€™s award amounted to a double recovery of
  prejudgment interest.Â  Blanding fails to recognize, however, that this is a
  separate proceeding seeking insurance proceeds that were due to Lender.Â  The
  prejudgment interest awarded by the Master here does not reflect that amount
  due in prejudgment interest from the mortgage foreclosure, but from the
  interest accrued from the time the insurance proceeds from the fire were made
  available by the Foremost check to Blanding, but were not paid to Lender as
  due.
Finally, Blanding argues, because the parties deposited the
  proceeds into the Clerkâ€™s Office by consent, she is relieved of any liability
  for prejudgment interest.Â  She further asserts in a footnote that should Lender
  be entitled to an award of prejudgment interest, she should be allowed to
  offset the interest earned on the funds while on deposit with the Clerk.Â  
In reviewing the record before us, it does not appear either of
  these arguments was raised to the Master in the summary judgment arguments.Â  In
  her motion for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP, Blanding stated
  only, â€œTo the extent that any prejudgment interest is awarded to [Lender],
  [Blanding] is entitled to offset against any such award the interest earned
  while the funds were on deposit with the Clerk.â€Â  In the hearing on her motion
  for reconsideration, Blanding questioned how the court intended â€œto treat the
  interest paid on the proceeds since their deposit with the court,â€ stating that
  the Clerk pays interest on the funds deposited at around 4.5 percent.Â  The
  Master indicated he was â€œnot aware of that,â€ did not know if that was correct,
  and stated the matter was not before him.Â  He concluded, â€œI do not know
  anything about any interest that the Clerk of Court has been awarding on this
  money and I am not going to do that.â€Â  Accordingly, it appears Blandingâ€™s
  argument that she had no liability based upon the deposit of the
  funds with the Clerk was never raised to the Master and therefore is not
  properly preserved on appeal.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach,
  339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an
  issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised
  to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€). Â As
  to the offset argument, this contention was first raised in Blandingâ€™s motion
  for reconsideration and therefore is not preserved for review. Â See Dixon v. Dixon, 362 S.C. 388, 399, 608 S.E.2d 849, 854 (2005) (holding that an
  issue first raised in a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion is not preserved for appellate
  review).[5]
Based
  upon the foregoing, the decision of the Master is 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON and
  KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Collectively, Long Beach Mortgage Company, Washington
  Mutual, Inc. and Deutsche Bank National Trust Company are the lender and
defendants in this case (hereinafter â€œLenderâ€).Â  
[3] The check initially issued by Foremost, in the amount
  of $62,750, represents the total amount of coverage less the $250 deductible.Â 
  Later, when the initial check expired and Blanding requested a new one,
Foremost issued a check in the amount of $63,000, instead of $62,750.Â  
[4] In the present case, the master awarded Lender
  attorneysâ€™ fees in the amount of $6,768.38, which is the amount of proceeds
  remaining after the debt ($49,495.14) and prejudgment interest ($6,736.48) were
  satisfied.Â  The amount of attorneysâ€™ fees, which is only a small portion of the
$39,335.50 Lender asserted it incurred, is not in dispute. 
[5] We would note that the Master found Lender entitled
  to a total judgment of $63,000 from the insurance proceeds, inclusive of
  prejudgment interest.Â  Lender will receive this specific amount, and thus
  Blanding should ultimately receive any remaining accrued interest on the
$63,000 deposited with the Clerk.

title: Horry County v. Parbel
description: In this litigation, Appellants contend the Circuit Court erred: (1) in ruling on the merits of the Countyâ€™s appeal because this was an appeal from a judgment of acquittal, and the only issue the Circuit Court should have addressed was the motion to dismiss the appeal pursuant to the doctrine of Double Jeopardy; (2) in making a finding on appeal that â€œthe Horry County Police Department acted reasonably, appropriately and in accordance with the Horry County Code of Ordinances in their activities at Thee Doll House on August 17, 2004,â€ because that issue was not properly before the Circuit Court for it to make such a finding and conclusion; (3) in finding â€œthere is a legal justification for the Countyâ€™s appeal and that, but for the timing of the Magistrateâ€™s Ruling, the County may have prevailed,â€ because that issue was not properly before the Circuit Court for it to make such a finding and conclusion; and (4) as a matter of law in denying Appellantsâ€™ motion for payment of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to the South Carolina Frivolous Civil Proceedings Sanctions Act (the Act), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-10, because the appeal in this matter was reviewed as a civil proceeding before the Court of Common Pleas, the appeal was frivolous since it was an appeal from a directed verdict of acquittal, and the Act applied in this matter. The County of Horry articulates the issues on appeal: (1) may a Circuit Court sit to correct an error of law by a Magistrate Judge, when that error results in an acquittal on misdemeanor charges, the error is otherwise capable of repetition while evading review, and the County agrees it will not seek a retrial?; (2) whether the Circuit Court abused its discretion in declining to award sanctions against the prevailing party.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Horry County, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        David
          Parbel, Kristen Parbel, Crystal Kawolski, Stephanie Regalado, & Laura
          Rajotte, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4388
Heard May 6, 2008 â€“ Filed May 12, 2008

REVERSED IN PART AND AFFIRMED IN PART.


  
    
      
        John S. Nichols, of Columbia, and Robert V. Phillips, of Rock Hill, for Appellants.
        John L. Weaver and Brenda L. Gorski, both of Conway, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  In 2004, several employees of Thee Doll House were arrested and
  cited for violating an Horry County zoning ordinance.Â  They appeared before the
  magistrate court and were acquitted of the charges against them.Â  Horry County appealed the magistrate courtâ€™s ruling to the circuit court.Â  Thee Doll House
  employees contend the circuit court erred in ruling on Horry Countyâ€™s appeal
  because it violated double jeopardy clauses of the federal and state
  constitutions and amounted to an advisory opinion.Â  The employees further
  maintain the circuit court erred in denying their request for attorneysâ€™ fees
  and costs pursuant to the South Carolina Frivolous Civil Proceedings Sanction
  Act.Â  We reverse in part and affirm in part.

  FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
  

The
  facts of the case are not in dispute.Â  On the evening of August 16, 2004, and
  on the following morning, undercover officers entered Thee Doll House and other
  strip clubs in Horry County to investigate whether dancersâ€™ breasts were
  properly covered.Â  Officers arrested and cited Kristen Parbel, Crystal
  Kawolski, Stephanie Regalado, and Laura Rejotte for violating an Horry County zoning ordinance by either exposing their nipples or covering their nipples
  with only transparent â€œpasties.â€Â  David Parbel, the manager on duty at Thee
  Doll House, was cited for permitting the female dancers to work while clothed
  in this manner.Â  Law enforcement declared
  this type of breast exposure was a criminal violation of section 526.3 of the Horry County zoning ordinances.Â  Subsequently, the charges were amended to allege criminal
  violation of section 1303 of the Horry County zoning ordinances. 
Section
  6-29-950(A) of the South Carolina Code (2004) authorizes the governing
  authorities of municipalities or counties to provide for the enforcement of any
  ordinance and provides: Â 

  A violation of any ordinance adopted pursuant to the provisions of
    this chapter is a misdemeanor. Â In case a building, structure, or land is or is
    proposed to be used in violation of any ordinance adopted pursuant to this
    chapter, the zoning administrator or other appropriate administrative officer .
    . . . may in addition to other remedies, institute injunction, mandamus, or
    other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent the unlawful . . . . use, or
    to correct or abate the violation . . . .

Additionally, Horry County zoning ordinance Section 1303 states:

  (A) It shall be unlawful to use, occupy or permit the use or
    occupancy of any building, mobile home, or premises, or all or parts thereof
    hereafter created, erected, changed, converted, or wholly or partly altered or
    enlarged in its use or structure until a certificate of zoning compliance shall
    have been issued therefore by the zoning administrator stating that the
    proposed use of the building or land conforms to the requirements of the
    ordinance.Â  (B) Failure to obtain a certificate of zoning compliance shall be a
    violation of this ordinance punishable under section 1308 of this ordinance.

Violating section 1303, as provided in section 1308, constitutes a
  misdemeanor:

  Any person violating any provisions of this ordinance shall be
    guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be imprisoned for a period
    not to exceed thirty (30) days and/or fined not more than two hundred dollars
    ($200.00) for each offense.Â  Each day such violation continues shall constitute
    a separate offense.Â  Nothing herein contained shall prevent the county from
    taking such other lawful action as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation.

A criminal
  trial was held in magistrateâ€™s court, and Appellants requested a jury trial.Â  After
  Horry County rested its case, Appellants moved for a dismissal of all
  charges.Â  The magistrate granted Appellantâ€™s motion for dismissal and
  inculcated â€œthe County has not met the allegations of this zoning ordinance in
  proving 1303.â€Â  Horry County appealed the magistrateâ€™s ruling to the circuit
  court after Appellantsâ€™ acquittal on March 8, 2005.Â  Though the magistrate â€œprayedâ€
  for the circuit court to dismiss Horry Countyâ€™s appeal with prejudice, the circuit court found it had both subject matter
  jurisdiction over the issues raised in the appeal and personal jurisdiction
  over the Appellants.Â  Appellants moved to dismiss Horry Countyâ€™s appeal based
  on the Double Jeopardy Clauses of the federal and state constitutions and sought
  sanctions for Horry Countyâ€™s pursuit of its appeal, averring the appeal was
  frivolous and violated the South Carolina Frivolous Civil Proceeding Sanction Act.
On
  appeal, the circuit court found Horry Countyâ€™s claim, â€œthe dancersâ€™ failure to
  completely and opaquely cover their breasts violated [section] 1303 (A) by
  changing or altering Thee Doll House â€˜useâ€™ fromÂ  a permissible nightclub into
  its â€˜useâ€™ as an adult entertainment establishment,â€ meritorious.Â  The circuit
  court elucidated:Â  â€œUnder [the Countyâ€™s] theory, [section] 1303 required the
  dancers and duty manager to wait until after Thee Doll House sought and
  successfully obtained a Certificate of Zoning Compliance for its use as an
  adult entertainment establishment before using or permitting Thee Doll House to
  be used that way.â€Â  However, the circuit court found double jeopardy prevented Appellants
  from being retried under the same charges.Â  Finally, the circuit court denied
  Appellantsâ€™ request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs because the case before the magistrate
  was criminal in nature and not a civil proceeding.Â  Appellantsâ€™ motion to alter
  or amend the circuit courtâ€™s judgment was denied.

  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  

In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220
  (2006); State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State
    v. Rice, 372 S.C. 302, 314, 652 S.E.2d 409, 414 (Ct. App. 2007); State
      v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004). Â This
  court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous.Â  State v. Northcutt, 372 S.C. 207, 215, 641 S.E.2d 873, 877
  (2007); State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 452, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111
  (2000); State v. Edwards, 374 S.C. 543, 553, 649 S.E.2d 112, 117 (Ct.
  App. 2007); State v.
    Patterson, 367 S.C. 219,
  224, 625 S.E.2d 239, 241 (Ct. App. 2006); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97,
  101, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct. App. 2004); see also State v. Abdullah,
  357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004).
On
  review, we are limited to determining whether the circuit court abused its
  discretion. Â State v. Laney, 367 S.C. 639, 643, 627 S.E.2d 726, 729
  (2006); State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 43, 503 S.E.2d 747, 751 (1998); State v. Grace, 350 S.C. 19, 23, 564 S.E.2d 331, 333 (Ct. App. 2002).
  This Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the circuit courtâ€™s
  ruling is supported by any evidence. Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d
  at 829; State v. Moore, 374 S.C. 468, 473-74, 649 S.E.2d 84, 86 (Ct.
  App. 2007); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 583, 575 S.E.2d 852, 855
  (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Error in Ruling on
  Merits of Countyâ€™s Appeal
A.Â  Double
  Jeopardy
Appellants maintain the circuit court violated the
  Double Jeopardy Clause by ruling on Horry Countyâ€™s appeal after they were acquitted
  in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  We agree. 
The United States Constitution and the South Carolina
  Constitution protect against double jeopardy. Â See U.S. Const. Amend. V (â€œ[N]or shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in
  jeopardy of life or limb . . . .); S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§ 12 (â€œNo person shall
  be subject for the same offense to be twice put in jeopardy of life or liberty,
  nor shall any person be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against
  himself.â€); see also State v. Mathis, 359 S.C. 450, 457, 597
  S.E.2d 872, 876 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œThe Double Jeopardy Clauses of the United
  States and South Carolina Constitutions protect citizens from being placed
  twice in jeopardy of life or liberty.â€); State v. Cuccia, 353 S.C. 430,
  434, 578 S.E.2d 45, 47 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œBoth the United States Constitution
  and the South Carolina Constitution protect against double jeopardy.â€).Â  
Under
  the Double Jeopardy Clause a defendant is protected from:Â  (1) a second
  prosecution for the same offense after acquittal; (2) a second prosecution for
  the same offense after conviction; and (3) multiple prosecution for the same
  offense after an improvidently granted mistrial.Â  State v. Gordon, 356
  S.C. 143, 149, 588 S.E.2d 105, 108 (2003); State v. Kirby, 269 S.C. 25, 27-28,
  236 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1977); Mathis, 359 S.C. at 457, 597 S.E.2d at 876;Â  Cuccia,
  353 S.C. at 434, 578 S.E.2d at 47; see also North Carolina v. Pearce,
  395 U.S. 711, 717 (1969) (overruled on other grounds by Alabama v. Smith,
  490 U.S. 794 (1989)); accord Schiro v. Farley, 510 U.S. 222, 229-30
  (1994); Justices of Boston Mun. Ct. v. Lydon, 466 U.S. 294, 306-07
  (1984); U.S. v. DiFrancesco, 449 U.S. 117, 129 (1980); Brown v. Ohio,
  432 U.S. 161, 165 (1977); U.S. v. Wilson, 420 U.S. 332, 343 (1975); Stevenson
    v. State, 335 S.C. 193, 198, 516 S.E.2d 434, 436 (1999); McMullin v. S.C.
      Depâ€™t of Revenue & Taxation, 321 S.C. 475, 478, 469 S.E.2d 600, 602
  (1996); State v. Owens, 309 S.C. 402, 405, 424 S.E.2d 473, 475 (1992).Â  
The United States has a long history of this
  constitutional protection: 

  If there
    is anything settled in the jurisprudence of England and America, it is that no man can be twice lawfully punished for the same offence. And though there
    have been nice questions in the application of this rule to cases in which the
    act charged was such as to come within the definition of more than one
    statutory offence, or to bring the party within the jurisdiction of more than
    one court, there has never been any doubt of its entire and complete protection
    of the party when a second punishment is proposed in the same court, on the
    same facts, for the same statutory offence.

Ex Parte Lange, 85 U.S. 163, 168 (1873).Â  The Supreme Court explicated:
  â€œPerhaps the most fundamental rule in the history of double jeopardy
  jurisprudence has been that â€˜(a) verdict of acquittal . . . could not be
  reviewed, on error or otherwise, without putting (a defendant) twice in
  jeopardy, and thereby violating the Constitution.â€™â€Â  U.S. v. Martin Linen
    Supply Co., 430 U.S. 564, 571 (1977) (citing U.S. v. Ball, 163 U.S. 662, 671, (1896)).Â  The Supreme Court reiterated the purpose of the Double Jeopardy
  Clause: Â â€œThe standard way for a defendant to secure a final judgment in her
  favor is to gain an acquittal . . . . [T]he â€˜primary purposeâ€™ of the Double
  Jeopardy Clause is to â€˜protect the integrityâ€™ of final determinations of guilt
  or innocence. Â Sattazahn v. Pennsylvania, 537 U.S. 101, 120 (2003)
  (internal citations omitted).Â  Moreover: 

  An
    acquittal is accorded special weight. Â The constitutional protection against
    double jeopardy unequivocally prohibits a second trial following an acquittal,
    for the public interest in the finality of criminal judgments is so strong that
    an acquitted defendant may not be retried even though the acquittal was based
    upon an egregiously erroneous foundation . . . . The law attaches particular
    significance to an acquittal.Â  

U.S. v. DiFrancesco, 449 U.S. 117, 129 (internal citations omitted). 
The South Carolina Supreme Court has long recognized the
  State has no right of appeal from an acquittal in a criminal case.Â  See State
    v. McKnight, 353 S.C. 238, 239, 577 S.E.2d 456, 457 (2003) (â€œBased
  primarily upon the double jeopardy provisions of the Constitution, we have long
  recognized that the State has no right of appeal from a judgment of acquittal
  in a criminal case . . . . These cases are premised upon the basic double
  jeopardy principle that a defendant in a criminal prosecution is in legal
  jeopardy when he has been placed upon trial under a valid indictment and a
  competent jury has been sworn.â€); State v. Rogers, 198 S.C. 273, 278, 17
  S.E.2d 563, 565 (1941) (â€œ[I]t is well settled that no writ of error, appeal, or
  other proceeding lies on behalf of the state to review or to set aside a
  verdict or a judgment of acquittal in a criminal case, although there may have
  been error committed by the court, or a perverse finding by the jury.â€); State
    v. Lynn, 120 S.C. 258, 260, 113 S.E. 74, 75 (1922) (â€œ[T]he state has no
  right of appeal from judgment upon verdict of acquittal in a criminal case
  seems to have been recognized and accepted as the law of this jurisdiction from
  the beginning of our judicial history.â€).Â  
In State
  v. Holiday, the supreme court held the State has no right of appeal from an
  acquittal in a criminal case unless the acquittal was procured by the accused
  through fraud or collusion.Â  255 S.C. 142, 145, 177 S.E.2d 541, 542 (1970).Â  The
  court articulated, â€œWhile a limited right of appeal in criminal cases has been
  conferred upon the State by statute in a number of jurisdictions, the extent of
  the right of the prosecution to appeal in this jurisdiction has been defined by
  our judicial decisions.Â  Id. at 144, 177 S.E.2d at 542.Â  
More
  recently, in State v. Tillinghast, the supreme court concluded the State
  did not have a right to appeal a magistrate courtâ€™s ruling to the circuit court
  after Defendantâ€™s acquittal.Â  375 S.C. 201, 203, 652 S.E.2d 400, 401 (2007).Â  The
  Defendant was charged with possession of alcohol by a minor and was granted his
  motion for a directed verdict in the magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Id. at 202, 652
  S.E.2d at 401.Â  The State appealed to the circuit court and argued the
  magistrate erred by directing a verdict of not guilty.Â  Id.Â  Â The State
  did not seek reinstatement of the charge but sought review of the magistrateâ€™s
  finding the statute was unconstitutional.Â  Id. Â The circuit court found
  it had jurisdiction to hear the appeal and found the magistrate erred in its
  ruling.Â  Id.Â  In reversing the circuit court, the supreme court
  asserted, â€œWhether or not the magistrate erred in [its] ruling of law,
  appellant was acquitted and is now out of court.Â  The circuit court erred by
  finding the State may appeal the magistrateâ€™s ruling.â€ Id. at Â 203, 652
  S.E.2d at 401.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find Tillinghast controlling of the issues in the case sub judice.Â  Â Though
  the parties concede Appellants cannot be retried again on the criminal zoning
  charges under double jeopardy principles, the circuit court found it had both
  subject matter jurisdiction over the issues raised in the appeal and personal
  jurisdiction over the Appellants.Â  The purpose of Horry Countyâ€™s appeal to the
  circuit court was to obtain a review of the magistrateâ€™s interpretation of an Horry County zoning ordinance.Â  Horry County posits â€œ[w]hether the State may appeal a
  magistrateâ€™s order of acquittal, entered on an erroneous interpretation of law,
  for the limited purpose of gaining review of that error of, without seeking to
  retry the defendants, appears to be a muddled question in South Carolina.â€Â  We
  disagree and find circuit courts do not possess authority to review possible
  legal errors of the magistrate after an acquittal.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the
  circuit courtâ€™s analysis regarding interpretation of Horry County Zoning
  Ordinance Section 1303.Â  
B.Â 
  Advisory Opinions
Appellants asseverate by appealing a ruling it knew
  was not appealable, Horry County essentially asked the circuit court to render
  an advisory opinion on the propriety of the magistrateâ€™s rulings.Â  We agree.
â€œIt is elementary
  that the courts of this State have no jurisdiction to issue advisory opinions.â€Â  Booth v. Grissom, 265 S.C. 190, 192, 217 S.E.2d 223, 224 (1975); see
    also Hitter v. McLeod, 274 S.C. 616, 618, 266 S.E.2d 418, 420 (1980)
  (â€œ[I]t does not ipso facto confer jurisdiction on this Court, or the court
  below, to render an advisory opinion, which we have repeatedly refused to do
  even on constitutional issues. . . .â€); McDill v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 368 S.C. 29, 32, 627 S.E.2d 749, 750 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œ[A] court is not permitted
  to issue advisory opinions.â€).Â  A court renders an advisory opinion when
  commenting on an issue will have no practical effect on the outcome of the
  case.Â  See Shasta Beverages v. S.C. Tax Comâ€™n, 280 S.C. 48, 56,
  310 S.E.2d 655, 659 (1983) (â€œIt is not the role of this [c]ourt to advise the
  legislative or executive branches how to proceed, nor to render an advisory
  opinion on a hypothetical situation.â€); Commâ€™r. of Pub. Works v. S.C. Depâ€™t.
    of Health & Envtl. Control, 372 S.C. 351, 641 S.E.2d 763 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (declining to address an issue which would be merely advisory in nature); Binkley
    v. Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation Dist. of Fountain Inn, 348 S.C. 58,
  76 n. 36, 558 S.E.2d 902, 911 n. 36 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThis court will not issue
  advisory opinions that have no practical effect on the outcome.â€).Â  
Other than granting
  Appellantsâ€™ motion to dismiss and ruling on whether to award attorneysâ€™ fees
  and costs, the circuit court had no authority to rule upon any matter raised in
  Horry Countyâ€™s appeal.Â  The role of the circuit court, or any state court, is
  not to give advice or render advisory opinions on hypothetical situations.Â  See Shasta Beverages, 280 S.C. at 56, 310 S.E.2d at 659.Â  By addressing Horry Countyâ€™s issues, the circuit court advised Horry County on what constitutes appropriate
  action under and how to interpret a county ordinance.Â  Such a decision had no
  practical effect on the outcome of a contested issue because Appellants were
  already acquitted of the charges against them.Â  Under South Carolina
  jurisprudence, the circuit court had no authority to comment on or render a
  decision regarding Horry County Zoning Ordinance Section 1303.
Because
  we find the circuit court lacked authority, we need not address Appellantâ€™s
  second and third issues on appeal.Â  See Wilson v. Moseley, 327
  S.C. 144, 147, 488 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1997) (holding when an appellate court
  affirms the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on a dispositive ground,
  the appellate court need not address the remaining issues on appeal); Fuller-Ahrens
    Pâ€™ship v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 311 S.C. 177, 182, 427
  S.E.2d 920, 923 (Ct. App. 1993) (declining to discuss the circuit courtâ€™s grant
  of summary judgment on additional grounds, including res judicata, where
  summary judgment was being affirmed for other reasons and on different grounds); Ringer v. Graham, 286 S.C. 14, 20, 331 S.E.2d 373, 377 (Ct. App. 1985) (determining discussion of remaining issues was unnecessary after reversing
  a directed verdict).Â  
II.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees and
  Costs
Appellants contend
  the circuit court erred as a matter of law by denying their motion for
  attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to the South Carolina Frivolous Civil
  Proceedings Sanctions Act (the Act).Â  Specifically, Appellants assert the
  Countyâ€™s appeal to the circuit court was reviewed as a civil proceeding because
  it was an appeal from a directed verdict of acquittal.Â  We disagree.
The
  determination of whether attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded under the Act is
  treated as one in equity, and in reviewing the award at issue this court may
  take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Hanahan v. Simpson,
  326 S.C. 140, 156, 485 S.E.2d 903, 912 (1997); Rutland v. Holler,
    Dennis, Corbett, Ormond & Garner (Law Firm), 371 S.C. 91, 97, 637
  S.E.2d 316, 319 (Ct. App. 2006). Â â€œ â€˜[F]ollowing the determination of facts, an
  appellate court applies an abuse of discretion standard in reviewing the
  decision to award sanctions and the specific sanctions awarded.â€™ â€ Rutland, 371 S.C. at 97, 637 S.E.2d at 319 (quoting Ex parte Beard, 359
  S.C. 351, 357, 597 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 2004)). 
Attorneys
  and individuals who take part in frivolous litigation may be sanctioned under
  the Act.Â  See S.C. Code Â§Â§15-36-10 to -50 (2005) (amended by Â§15-36-10
  (Supp. 2007)).Â  The Act in effect at the time Horry County gave notice of its
  appeal to the circuit court, on March 9, 2005, provides:[1]Â Â  

  Any
    person who takes part in the procurement, initiation, continuation, or defense
    of any civil proceeding is subject to being assessed for payment of all or a
    portion of the attorneyâ€™s fees and court costs of the other party if:Â  
  (1) he
    does so primarily for a purpose other than that of securing the proper
    discovery, joinder of parties, or adjudication of the claim upon which the
    proceedings are based; and
  (2) the
    proceedings have terminated in favor of the person seeking an assessment of the
    fees and costs.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-10.
Concomitantly,
  in order for a litigant to receive attorneyâ€™s fees and costs under the Act, the
  litigant has the burden of establishing:

  (1) the
    other party has procured, initiated, continued, or defended the civil proceedings against him;
  (2) the
    proceedings were terminated in his favor;
  (3) the
    primary purpose for which the proceedings were procured, initiated, continued,
    or defended was not that of securing the proper discovery, joinder of parties,
    or adjudication of the civil proceedings;
  (4) the
    aggrieved person has incurred attorneyâ€™s fees and court costs; and
  (5) the
    amount of the fees and costs set forth in item.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-40
  (emphasis added).Â  The original proceedings in magistrate court were criminal
  rather than civil in nature.Â  However, Appellants argue once Horry County appealed the magistrateâ€™s findings to the circuit court, or the court of common
  pleas, the case was converted into a civil proceeding.Â  We disagree.Â  
South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure govern â€œthe procedure in all South Carolina courts in all suits of a civil nature whether cognizable as cases at law or
  in equity. . . .â€ Rule 1, SCRCP; see also State v. Brown, 344
  S.C. 302, 307, 543 S.E.2d 568, 571 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe scope of the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure is limited to â€˜all suits of a civil nature
  whether cognizable as cases at law or in equity.â€™â€).Â  In State v. Brown,
  a defendant appealed a magistrateâ€™s ruling on a criminal charge against him to
  the circuit court.Â  Id. at 304, 543 S.E.2d at 569.Â  At issue before this
  court was whether Brown had to serve notice of appeal on the South Carolina
  Department of Public Safety (SCDPS) pursuant to Rule 74, SCRCP.Â  Id. at 305-06, 543 S.E.2d at 570.Â  There, we clarified: Â â€œThe dilemma . . . has
  arisen because criminal appeals from magistrates are heard in courts that
  operate under the Rules of Civil Procedure.â€Â  Id. at 305, 543 S.E.2d at
  570.Â  Ultimately this court found Rule 74 applied only to civil actions and did
  not apply to Brownâ€™s appeal because his original action was criminal in
  nature.Â  Id. at 307, 543 S.E.2d at 571.Â  
Following Brown, we find Horry Countyâ€™s appeal to the circuit court was criminal
  rather than civil in nature because Appellants originally faced criminal charges
  before the magistrate.Â  We hold the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure
  rather than the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure apply when parties
  appeal a magistrateâ€™s ruling in a criminal case to the circuit court.Â  Therefore,
  the Act does not apply to the proceedings concerning Appellants.Â  The circuit
  court did not err by denying attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to the Act. 
CONCLUSION
The circuit
  court violated the double jeopardy provision of the federal and state
  constitutions by allowing Horry Countyâ€™s appeal.Â  Moreover, by addressing the
  issues raised by Horry County, the circuit court erroneously issued an advisory
  opinion.Â  The circuit court properly denied Appellantâ€™s motion for attorneyâ€™s
  fees and costs.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
REVERSED IN PART AND AFFIRMED
  IN PART.
HUFF and
  KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] The provisions of this Act are outlined in sections
  15-36-10 to 15-36-50.Â  Â We note that section 15-36-10 was completely revised and
  became effective on July 1, 2005, and sections 15-36-20 through -50 were
  repealed effective March 21, 2005. Â Because Horry County filed their motion of
  appeal to the circuit court on March 9, 2005, the original Act still governed the
  circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  For purposes of this analysis, we reference the
  former version of the Act.Â

title: Ward v. West Oil Company, Inc.
description: In this civil case, Appellants posit the Special Referee committed an error of law by misconstruing a single sentence of the contract so as to: (1) render meaningless the primary contractual rights and duties of the parties; and (2) permit West Oil Company to repudiate at will its contractual duty to allow R&Bâ€™s game machines in West Oilâ€™s convenience stores for a period of one year.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Charles Ward
          and Robby Hodge, d/b/a R&B Amusements, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      West Oil
        Company, Inc., d/b/a Markette Stores, Respondent.
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Eugene P. Warr, Jr., Special Referee

Opinion No. 4389
Heard May 6, 2008 â€“ Filed May 12, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Charles
          E. Carpenter, Jr. and Carmen V. Ganjehsani, of Columbia, M.M. Weinberg, Jr., of
          Sumter, and Kenneth D. Baker, of Darlington, for Appellants.
        Martin S. Driggers, Jr. and William R. Calhoun, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Charles Ward and Robby Hodge, d/b/a
  R&B Amusements, appeal the Special Refereeâ€™s award of $5,067.31 in their
  favor in a breach of contract action.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
I.Â  Initial Meeting
Charles
  Ward (Ward) and Robby Hodge (Hodge) operated a gaming business known as R&B
  Amusements (R&B).Â  They desired to place their pull tab machines in
  convenience stores owned by West Oil Company, Inc. (West Oil).Â  The machines
  sold tickets, called â€œPots of Gold,â€ with potential for winning prizes.Â  On
  September 11, 2001, Ward and Hodge met with Lex West, Jr. (West), owner of West
  Oil, and Camp Seegars (Seegars), an employee of West Oil, to discuss the
  possibility of placing the machines.Â  Seegars was West Oilâ€™s Director of
  Operations and oversaw its twenty-four convenience stores.Â  This was the first
  time the parties met; they had never done business together before.
R&B
  gave West Oil an overview of their machines and presented West Oil with a form contract,
  entitled â€œExclusive Agreement,â€ that R&B obtained from its machine
  supplier.Â  The typewritten contract consisted of eleven paragraphs.Â  West Oil agreed
  to place the machines initially at four of their stores.Â  The terms of the
  agreement were negotiated at this meeting.Â  West Oil expressed its desire to
  reduce the term of the agreement from the three years R&B proposed to one
  year and to collect a $500 placement fee from R&B for each machine situated
  in its stores.Â  R&Bâ€™s typical agreement was to split the profits, defined
  as the total money taken in by the machines less the payouts and cost of the
  tickets from the manufacturer, with the location owner.Â  West Oil wanted
  R&B to absorb the cost of the tickets in the machines in its stores.Â  R&B
  was agreeable to the modifications because of their desire to place their
  machines in such a large operatorâ€™s stores.Â  
There
  were some discussions regarding termination of the contract.Â  West Oil contends
  it wanted the ability for either party to terminate the contract at will.Â  At
  trial, Seegars testified that West Oil â€œwanted a way out because what if down
  the road they didnâ€™t like us or we didnâ€™t like them.Â  That was put into that
  clause.â€Â  Both parties understood the impending arrival of the South Carolina
  Education Lottery was a concern to West Oil, and it did not want the presence
  of R&Bâ€™s machines to jeopardize its ability to become a lottery retailer.Â  R&B
  advances they intended for West Oil to be able to terminate the contract only
  if their machines prohibited West Oil from selling lottery tickets.
II.Â  Execution of
  Agreement
Two
  days later, on September 13, 2001, Ward, Hodge, and Seegars met again.Â  West
  did not attend this meeting, so Seegars alone represented West Oil.Â  R&B
  brought a revised, typed contract.Â  The parties do not dispute that their
  agreement was for R&B to pay West Oil a $500 placement fee for each
  machine.Â  The parties were to evenly split the profits (total money taken in by
  the machine less the payouts made by West Oil), and R&B was to absorb the
  costs of the tickets.Â  The revised contract was for a one year term. Â 
The revised contract contained no language allowing termination of
  the agreement if the relationship between the parties was no longer amicable.Â  The typewritten contract R&B presented to West
  Oil on September 13 included the following paragraph:

  7.Â 
    In the event of any breach of this Agreement, it is recognized by both parties
    that remedies at law are inadequate given the highly competitive nature of this
    industry, and the difficulty of finding alternative locations not committed to
    existing agreements.Â  OWNER further acknowledges the unique nature of the
    location.Â  OWNER further acknowledges that the loss of this location will
    result in irreparable harm to R&B.Â  As a result, the parties agree that
    either party may, without notice to the other party, petition in court of
    competent jurisdiction and obtain a restraining order and/or injunction
    requiring compliance with the terms of this Agreement.Â  Notwithstanding the
    forgoing, in the event of a breach, in addition to any other remedy available,
    R&B may elect to terminate this Agreement and remove all game promotions
    materials and equipment without interference from OWNER and shall be entitled
    to liquidated damages in an amount equal to R&Bâ€™s highest weekly share of
    the net proceeds prior to said breach, multiplied by the number of weeks
    remaining in the unexpired term of this Agreement.

Seegars wrote an additional provision (the Addition) at the top of
  the contract:

  Addition
    * In event of contract termination up front placement money will be re-imbursed
    [sic] at pro-rated time with no penalties to either party of this contract.Â 
    This is added this day September 13th [sic] 2001 [sic]
  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  CSÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  RHÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  CW
  

Seegars,
  Hodge, and Ward each initialed below the handwritten addition.Â  All three
  signed the bottom of the contract.Â  The contract originally specified four
  store locations where machines were to be placed.Â  The machines performed well,
  and the parties agreed orally to place the machines in more stores over time.Â 
  Eventually, West Oil authorized the placement of machines in thirteen
  additional stores.
III.Â  Ticket Sales
Initially, each ticket machine held a total of $4,800 worth of
  â€œredâ€ tickets at a time.Â  When the red tickets sold out, R&B would remove
  the money, pay the portion due to West Oil, and refill the machine with red
  tickets.Â  In late 2001, R&B

  were explicitly addressed by the written agreement.Â  R&B placed machines in
  thirteen additional stores without any additional written agreement.Â  Because
  R&B paid West Oil a $500 placement fee each time a machine was placed and
  R&B split the proceeds from the machines in the manner specified by the
  contract, the court appropriately found the same terms of the written contract,
  including the handwritten termination clause, applied to the additional
  thirteen machines.
CONCLUSION
â€œCourts
  are without authority to alter a contract by construction or to make new
  contracts for the parties.â€Â  Gilstrap v. Culpepper, 283 S.C. 83, 86, 320
  S.E.2d 445, 447 (1984).Â  Our duty is to interpret the contract according to the
  intentions of the parties themselves â€œ. . . regardless of its wisdom or folly,
  apparent unreasonableness, or failure to guard [the partiesâ€™] rights
  carefully.â€Â  Id. (quoting Blakeley v. Rabon, 266 S.C. 68, 73, 221
  S.E.2d 767, 769 (1976)).Â  Because the record illuminates the partiesâ€™ intent to
  include the handwritten termination provision as an additional term to the
  Exclusive Agreement, we hold the special referee properly construed the
  Addition so as to allow West Oil to terminate the contract at will.Â  
We
  rule the partiesâ€™ contract is ambiguous.Â  Concomitantly, parol evidence is
  admissible to determine the partiesâ€™ intent.Â  The special referee correctly
  held the contract is ambiguous and looked to parol evidence to construe the
  contract.Â  There is ample evidence to support the refereeâ€™s decision that the
  parties intended for either to be able to terminate their agreement.Â  The only
  monetary consequence for termination was the prorated repayment of the $500
  placement fee, which the court ordered West Oil to pay R&B.Â  Accordingly,
  the order of the special referee is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

description: This is an appeal from an order of the Administrative Law Court (ALC) granting SGM-Moonglo, Inc. (Moonglo) an off-premises beer and wine permit.  Marjorie Smith argues the ALC should have considered the existence of a restrictive covenant as a factor in determining whether to grant Moongloâ€™s petition for the permit.  We affirm.
