THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				SGM-Moonglo,
      Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Revenue, Respondent,
				and
				Marjorie H.
      Smith, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from the Administrative Law Court
Â Marvin F. Kittrell, Administrative Law
  Court Judge
Opinion No. 4390
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 15, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James Ross Snell, Jr., of Lexington, for Appellant.
				Robert L. Jackson, of Columbia, for Respondent SGM-Moonglo, Inc.
				Thomas A. McDermott, Ray N. Stevens, Harry T. Cooper, Jr., and Nicholas
  P. Sipe, of Columbia, for Respondent South Carolina Department of Revenue.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, A.J.:Â  This is an appeal from an order of the Administrative Law Court (ALC)
  granting SGM-Moonglo, Inc. (Moonglo) an off-premises beer and wine permit.Â  We
  affirm. [1]
FACTS
In 1975, Marjorie Smith sold a tract of real property to Virginia
  Miller.Â  Smithâ€™s deed to Miller contained a restrictive covenant prohibiting
  the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises. Â Moonglo purchased the
  property in August 2006, and operates a truck stop on the property.Â  
Moonglo applied to the South Carolina Department of Revenue (DOR)
  for an off-premises beer and wine permit. Â After several area residents filed
  protests, DOR denied the application. Â Moonglo then requested a contested case
  hearing before the ALC. 
Prior to the hearing, the ALC granted Smithâ€™s motion to intervene
  to enforce the restrictive covenant. Â After a hearing, the ALC granted Moonglo
  an off-premises beer and wine permit, finding the property was a suitable
  location and Moonglo met all applicable statutory requirements for obtaining
  the permit. Â The ALC held it did not have jurisdiction to enforce a restrictive
  covenant because its jurisdiction was limited to whether a proposed location
  meets the criteria established by statute and case law. Â Smith appeals.[2]
LAW / ANALYSIS
Smith argues the ALC should have
  considered the existence of the restrictive covenant as a factor in determining
  whether to grant Moongloâ€™s petition for a beer and wine permit.Â  Smith contends
  the truck stop is not a suitable location for a permit because the restrictive
  covenant prohibits the sale of alcohol on the property. 
Section 1-23-610 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006)
  sets forth the applicable standard of review when the court of appeals sits in review of a
  decision by the ALC. â€œThe
  review of the administrative law judgeâ€™s order must be
  confined to the record.â€[3] Â The court of appeals may reverse or modify the decision only if the
  appellantâ€™s substantive rights have been prejudiced because the decision is
  clearly erroneous in light of the reliable and substantial evidence on the
  whole record, arbitrary or otherwise characterized by an abuse of discretion,
  or affected by other error of law.[4] Â 
An
  administrative agency has only the powers conferred on it by law and must act
  within the authority created for that purpose.[5]Â 
  Pursuant to section 61-4-520 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006), the ALC must
  determine whether a proposed location is proper and suitable prior to granting
  an off-premises beer and wine permit.Â  Restrictions in the chain of title of a
  proposed location, however, are not a legitimate concern of the ALC in
  determining whether the location is suitable.[6]Â 
  Accordingly, the ALC did not err in refusing to consider the existence of the
  restrictive covenant.[7]
AFFIRMED.
SHORT
  and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Smith also filed a separate civil action in Lexington County seeking an injunction to prohibit the sale of alcohol pursuant to the
  restrictive covenant.Â  This action is pending.
[3]Â  Â Id.
[4]Â Â  Id.
[5] Â Â Bazzle
  v. Huff, 319 S.C. 443,
  445, 462 S.E.2d 273, 274 (1995).
[6] Â See Lones v. Blount County Beer Bd.,
  538 S.W.2d 386, 390 (Tenn. 1976); see also Bd. of Tr. of Woodland
    Union High School Dist. of Yolo County v. Munro, 329 P.2d 765, 769-70 (Cal.
  App. 3 Dist. 1958) (holding the alcoholic beverage control board did not err in
  granting a license where a restrictive covenant existed on the property, and
  finding the parties could bring an action in the courts to enforce the
  covenant); Barnegat City Beach Assâ€™n v. Busby, 44 N.J.L. 627, 627 (N.J.
  1882) (holding the court is not required to consider restrictive covenants in
  granting a liquor license, and restrictive covenants do not render licenses
  invalid).
[7] Â We do not overlook McLeod v. Baptiste, 315
  S.C. 246, 433 S.E.2d 834 (1993) wherein the supreme court held a remote grantor
  lacked standing to enforce a restrictive covenant where the grantor no longer
  owned real property that would benefit from the covenantâ€™s enforcement.

title: State v. Evans
description: Larry D. Evans appeals his criminal conviction for possession of a stolen vehicle.  On appeal, Evans maintains the trial court erred in overruling defense counselâ€™s objection to hearsay testimony.

<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Larry D. Evans, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J.C. Buddy Nicholson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4391
Submitted March 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 15,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Lanelle C. Durant, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of
  Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Senior Assistant Attorney General, Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Christina T. Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PIEPER, J.:Â  Larry D. Evans appeals his criminal
  conviction for possession of a stolen vehicle.Â  On appeal, Evans maintains the
  trial court erred in overruling defense counselâ€™s objection to hearsay
  testimony.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On June
  27, 2006, Evans was indicted for possession of a stolen vehicle in violation of
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-21-80 (1976).Â  At trial, William Human, Bobbie Hicks, and
  Detective Steven Reeves presented testimony regarding the condition of the
  stolen vehicle.Â  According to Human, â€œ[a]ll the molding was gone and wrecked .
  . . [t]he steering column busted out. . . . I had stickers on it.Â  All those
  was stripped off of it and all.â€Â  Human went on to testify that his tool box
  was also missing and that Evansâ€™ wallet containing his driverâ€™s license was
  found in the vehicle.Â  Following Humanâ€™s testimony, Hicks testified regarding
  the condition of the vehicle, stating, â€œ[a]ll the siding is off of it.Â  The
  column is gone out of it.â€ Â Hicks further stated â€œ[h]e had emblems all over the
  window, they were gone.â€ Â Hicks also confirmed that a tool box and tools belonging
  to Human were inside the vehicle prior to the theft.Â  
Following the testimony of Human and Hicks, Detective Reeves
  presented testimony regarding his investigation into the alleged theft. Â Reeves
  testified he spoke with Human about damage to the vehicle and the details of
  the crime. Â When questioned at trial regarding the vehicleâ€™s condition, Reeves
  stated â€œ[t]he molding is removed.Â  Any emblems, Dodge or Dakota are removed
  from the vehicle.â€Â  When Reeves attempted to reference a statement by Human, Evans
  objected to Reevesâ€™ testimony on the ground of hearsay. Â The trial court
  overruled Evansâ€™ objection and allowed the statements.Â  Reeves continued
  his testimony, stating, â€œ[a]ccording to Mr. Human, when he and Miss Hicks
  picked up the vehicle in Abbeville, the steering column was damaged and heâ€™s
  had to replace that.Â  I didnâ€™t actually see that damage, but thatâ€™s some of the
  other damage that Mr. Human had told me about.â€Â  Reeves further indicated that
  a toolbox, which Human estimated was valued at over one thousand dollars, was
  missing.Â  
In addition to the above-stated testimony, other evidence offered
  to establish Evansâ€™ possession of the stolen vehicle was presented at trial.Â  Harley
  Burdette, Rebecca Alexander, Catherine Johnson, and David Bolt all testified
  that the vehicle was stolen and that Evans was in possession of the vehicle
  following its theft.Â  Alexander and Burdette further testified that Evans
  attempted to sell tools from the vehicle. Â It was also established that Evans
  was arrested while driving the stolen vehicle. 
At the conclusion of the trial, the jury found Evans guilty of
  possession of a stolen vehicle.Â  Evans was sentenced to ten years
  imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Wilson,
  345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  The admissibility of evidence is
  within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Gaster, 349
  S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002).Â Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility
  of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the
  commission of legal error which results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State
    v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Evans
  contends the trial court erred by admitting hearsay testimony from Reeves
  regarding damage to the stolen vehicle.Â  Evans further asserts that the
  admission of this testimony caused prejudice, amounting to reversible error.Â 
  We disagree.
Improper
  admission of hearsay testimony constitutes reversible error only when the
  admission causes prejudice.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336
  S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  Generally, a conviction will not be set aside by the
  appellate court where error by the trial court is insubstantial and does not
  affect the result of the trial. Â State v. Price, 368 S.C. 494, 499, 629
  S.E.2d 363, 366 (2006).Â  Accordingly, where guilt has been conclusively proven
  by competent evidence, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the
  trial is harmless.Â  Id.; Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420
  S.E.2d 834, 842 (1992); State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581,
  584 (1989).Â  
Assuming,
  arguendo, that the testimony in question was improperly admitted by the trial
  court, Evans has not demonstrated reversible error.Â  See Price,
  368 S.C. at 499, 629 S.E.2d at 366.Â Â  Review of the record reveals Reevesâ€™
  testimony regarding the condition of the vehicle was merely cumulative as both
  Human and Hicks also testified to the damage sustained by the vehicle. Â See id. at 499-500, 629 S.E.2d at 366; see also State v. Haselden,
  353 S.C. 190, 196-97, 577 S.E.2d 445, 448-49 (2003) (admission of improper
  evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other
  evidence); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862
  (1993) (finding any error in the admission of testimony that is merely cumulative
  is harmless).Â  Prior to Reevesâ€™ testimony, Human testified that: the vehicleâ€™s
  molding was removed; the steering column was busted out; the stickers were stripped
  from the exterior; and a toolbox was missing.Â  Hicks also similarly testified about
  the molding, the steering column, and the emblems or stickers. 
Further,
  review of the record reveals other eyewitness testimony placing Evans in
  possession of the stolen vehicle as well as testimony indicating Evans
  attempted to sell tools from the vehicle; moreover, there is evidence that his
  wallet and driverâ€™s license were found in the vehicle and that he was arrested
  while driving the stolen vehicle.Â  Thus, despite the presence of the alleged
  improper testimony regarding the condition of the vehicle, the verdict was
  based on an abundance of competent evidence from which Evansâ€™ guilt was
  properly established.Â  See State v. Lyles, 211 S.C. 334, 45
  S.E.2d 181 (1947) (the possession of recently stolen property is an evidential
  fact from which the possessorâ€™s guilt may be inferred); State v. Lee,
  147 S.C. 480, 145 S.E. 285 (1928) (in a prosecution for receiving stolen goods,
  guilty knowledge can be proved by showing a person was found in possession of
  recently stolen goods); State v. Williams, 350 S.C. 172, 175-76, 564
  S.E.2d 688, 690-91 (Ct. App. 2002) (possession of stolen vehicle was
  circumstantial evidence that defendant knew the vehicle was stolen).Â 
  Therefore, the admission of Reevesâ€™ testimony, as merely cumulative,
  insubstantial, and not affecting the result of the trial, was harmless.Â  Accordingly,
  we find no reversible error.
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

description: In this criminal matter, the appellant appeals his convictions for three counts of violating the peeping tom statute in regard to his actions involving three minor victims at a youth swim meet.  Appellant asserts error in the trial courts (1) refusal to sever his trials, (2) denial of his motion to suppresss the in-court indentifications by one of the victims and a witness,  (3) admission of alleged statements made by appellant, (4) admission of testimony regarding how appellant's actions made the victims feel, and (5) denial of his motion for directed verdict.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				William Frank
      Caldwell, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â Â  4392
Submitted March 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 15,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Michael W. Barcroft, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
				
				Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HUFF, J.:Â  William
  Frank Caldwell appeals from his convictions for three counts of violating the
  eavesdropping or peeping tom statute.Â  Caldwell asserts error in the trial
  courts (1) refusal to sever the trials, (2) denial of his motion to suppress
  the in-court identifications by a victim and a witness, (3) admission of
  alleged statements made by Caldwell, (4) admission of testimony regarding how
  Caldwellâ€™s actions made the victims feel, and (5) denial of his motion for
  directed verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Caldwell was
  indicted in three separate indictments which alleged Caldwell did, on or about
  June 23, 2005, eavesdrop or peep on the premises of the Sugar Creek Homeowners
  Association, invading the privacy of three different young boys, hereinafter
  GT, DW, and QB.Â  Caldwell was found guilty on all three charges, and was
  sentenced to three years, three years consecutive, and three years suspended to
  one year and five years probation.Â  
Thirteen
  year-old GT testified that on the day in question he was participating in a
  swim meet, swimming for the Sugar Creek team.Â  During the swim meet, he used
  the pool deck bathroom facilities twice.Â  GT stated there were two sets of
  bathrooms around the pool, â€œone for the kidsâ€ located on the pool deck, and
  â€œanother one for the adultsâ€ in the clubhouse.Â  The first time he entered the
  bathroom by himself and saw a man at the far urinal.Â  GT went to the other
  urinal where, because of the nature of his racing swim suit, he had to pull the
  front of the suit down to urinate.Â  As he did so he saw the man at the far
  urinal â€œlooking over at [his] private.â€Â  When asked how this made him feel, GT
  replied â€œuncomfortable.â€Â  GT went to the bathroom a second time and encountered
  the same man, who was coming out of one of the urinals as GT walked into the
  bathroom.Â  As GT walked toward a urinal, the man turned around when he saw the
  young boy and went back to a urinal.Â  When GT again pulled down his swim suit

  sidewaysâ€ â€œto get a better lookâ€ at GTâ€™s privates.Â  GT again responded it made
  him feel â€œuncomfortableâ€ when the man looked at him the second time.Â  GT also
  testified no one had ever made him feel the way this man did that day.Â  
After
  exiting the bathroom from this second encounter, GT found his mother in the
  crowd watching the meet and told her he needed to speak to her.Â  As his mother
  made her way through the chairs to follow him, GT saw his recent school teacher,
  Ms. Tate.Â  His mother walked up as GT explained to Ms. Tate that there was a
  man in the bathroom looking at him.Â  The two women told GT to go up on the
  balcony and point out the man to them.Â  GT did so, and pointed out a man
  standing outside the boysâ€™ bathroom.Â  GT made an in-court identification of Caldwell as the man who twice looked at his privates in the bathroom.Â Â  
Thirteen
  year old DW also testified at Caldwellâ€™s trial.Â  DW testified that in June of
  the previous year, he swam in a swim meet on the Sugar Creek team.Â  The first
  time he went to the bathroom, he entered by himself and saw a man towards the
  back in the shower area.Â  DW went to the first urinal and pulled down the front
  of his swimsuit to urinate.Â  As he did so, the man, who had taken a position at
  a urinal, started to glance over at DW, looking at DWâ€™s privates but not his
  face.Â  When asked how this made him feel, DW replied it made him
  uncomfortable.Â  DW turned his back to the man, and after he finished urinating,
  he left the urinal to go swim in his events. Â DW went back to the
  bathroom a second time, this time with his friend JB.Â  When he entered the

  but at his privates.Â  DW again stated this made him feel uncomfortable.Â  He also
  testified no one had ever made him feel the way this man did on that day.Â  DW
  made an in-court identification of Caldwell as the man in the bathroom who

JB,
  who was thirteen years old at the time of trial and also swam on the Sugar
  Creek team, likewise testified to events that occurred at the swim meet on June
  23, 2005.Â  JB stated that he and DW entered the boysâ€™ bathroom on the pool deck
  and saw an older man at the sink.Â  JB used the far urinal and DW used the first
  one.Â  JB stated he finished urinating first and went to wash his hands.Â  As he
  did so, the man went to the second urinal.Â  When JB finished washing his hands,
  he observed the man at the second urinal turn his head to the side and look down
  at DWâ€™s privates.Â  The man was not looking at DWâ€™s face.Â  JB and DW left the
  bathroom and went straight to swim in their event.Â  JB made an in-court
  identification of Caldwell as the man looking at DWâ€™s privates that day.Â  
Twelve
  year old QB also testified to an encounter with Caldwell while swimming on the
  Sugar Creek team in June of 2005.Â  QB went alone to the bathroom for the boys
  located on the pool deck.Â  There was a man in there at a urinal.Â  QB went to a
  urinal and pulled down the front of his swimsuit to urinate.Â  As he did so, the
  man looked down at QBâ€™s privates.Â  QB testified this made him feel â€œreally
  awkward.â€Â  Like GT and DW, QB stated no one had ever made him feel the way this
  man made him feel that day.Â  QB made an in-court identification of Caldwell as the man who looked at him in the bathroom.Â  QB further testified, after he
  left the bathroom, he later saw the same man talking to DWâ€™s father outside the
  bathroom.Â  
Ms.
  Tate, one of the presidents of the Sugar Creek swim team, testified that at the
  meet on June 23, 2005, she saw GT, whom she taught in fifth grade, and he
  appeared to be â€œvery upset.â€Â  She asked GT what was wrong, and he told her
  â€œthere was a man in the bathroom that was watching him go to the bathroom.â€Â 
  GTâ€™s mother came up to them as GT explained this to Ms. Tate.Â  The two women
  sent GT up to the balcony as they walked over to the bathroom area.Â  GT pointed
  out a man in that area to them. Â Ms. Tate then went to find someone who
  could help with the situation while GTâ€™s mother stayed in the area to keep boys
  out of the bathroom.Â  Ms. Tate found DWâ€™s father and led him back to the area
  in front of the bathrooms, where the man was still standing.Â  DWâ€™s father
  approached the man and tried to engage him in conversation.Â  Without objection,
  Ms. Tate made an in-court identification of Caldwell as the man pointed out by
  GT that day.Â  
DWâ€™s
  father testified that during the swim meet on June 23, 2005, Ms. Tate
  approached him and told him what was occurring as she led him over to the bathroom
  area.Â  After she pointed out Caldwell to him, DWâ€™s father walked up to the man
  and introduced himself, attempting to engage the man in conversation.Â  The man
  shook his hand, but never gave his name and apparently did not want to talk.Â 
  At some point, DWâ€™s father asked the man if he had a child on either of the
  swim teams.Â  The man told him he had an eleven year-old boy on the Sugar Creek
  team by the name of Trey Dowden.Â  When confronted with the fact that DWâ€™s
  father knew most of the boys in that age group on the team, the man claimed
  they were new to the team.Â  DWâ€™s father then asked the man what events his son
  was swimming in, and when the man stated he did not know, he told the man he
  would get a heat sheet that listed the children and the events.Â  When he
  stepped back to get the heat sheet, he turned around and the man had left.Â 
  DWâ€™s father spotted the man and walked toward him, holding up the sheet and
  telling him they could then look up his son.Â  The man exited the pool area and
  DWâ€™s father followed him.Â  The man then ran away into a residential area and
  DWâ€™s father pursued him for twenty or twenty-five minutes until some police
  officers arrived and apprehended the man.Â  Without objection, DWâ€™s father
  identified Caldwell as the man he had pursued that day.Â  DWâ€™s father further
  testified there was no Trey Dowden in the eleven and twelve age group on either
  of the swim teams.Â  
Deputy
  Chuck Porter arrived on the scene and spoke with Caldwell.Â  After the officer advised him of his Miranda[2] rights, Caldwell indicated he understood his rights and was willing to speak to
  him without an attorney present.Â  Officer Porter than asked Caldwell if he
  could tell him â€œwhatâ€™s going on.â€Â  Caldwell stated he had been confronted by
  someone he believed to be a parent over at the pool and he had been â€œaccused of
  doing something to one of the little boys in the restroom.â€Â  Officer Porter
  asked, â€œWell, did you?â€Â  Caldwell replied that â€œ[h]e was there to look at the
  boys, but hadnâ€™t touched anyone.â€Â  When asked if Caldwell said anything else,
  the officer testified Caldwell â€œsaid he preferred to look at the younger
  boys.â€Â  
ISSUES
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court
  err in refusing to grant Caldwellâ€™s motion for separate trials on each
  indictment?
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court
  err in refusing to suppress the in-court identification by the minors DW and
  JB?
III.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court
  err in allowing testimony of the alleged statements made by the defendant to
  Officer Porter?
IV.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court
  err in allowing the victims to testify how they felt when Caldwell looked at
  them?
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court
  err in refusing to direct a verdict in favor of Caldwell? 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Motion for Separate Trials
On appeal, Caldwell contends the trial court erred in refusing
  to grant his motion for separate trials on each of the indictments.Â  He
  contends the joint trial on the indictments was extremely prejudicial such that
  the trial court committed error in failing to sever them. We disagree.
A
  motion for severance is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court

  a partition, to afford the young boys complete privacy, we find, under
  the facts of this case, the victims did in fact have an expectation of privacy
  such that there is evidence Caldwell was on the premises of another for the
  purpose of invading that privacy.Â  The evidence shows the children were
  participating in a swim meet on private property.Â  The young, male victims used the boysâ€™ bathroom on the pool deck that was provided
  â€œfor the kids,â€ while another bathroom for the adults was located in the clubhouse.Â 
  While in the boysâ€™ bathroom, the three victims encountered Caldwell at least
  five separate times.Â  The record shows Caldwell, on more than one occasion, was
  either in another area of the bathroom or appeared to be exiting the bathroom
  when he purposely came back to one of the urinals just as a victim went to use
  the other urinal.Â  There is evidence that on each occasion Caldwell
  specifically looked directly at the boysâ€™ privates and, on at least one
  occasion, bent over and spit in the urinal and looked sideways in order to get
  a better look at the privates of one of the children.Â  We find there is more
  than sufficient evidence Caldwell invaded the privacy of his three young
  victims, inasmuch as children should reasonably expect a certain degree of
  privacy when urinating in a bathroom that, when respected, would protect them
  from peering adults.
C.Â  Looks Cast by Appellant
Finally,
  Caldwell argues he was entitled to a directed verdict because the alleged
  looks cast by him did not arise to the level required by South Carolina Code
  Ann. Section 16-17-470(D)(3) (2003), which provides â€œAs used in this section .
  . . â€˜Viewâ€™ means the intentional looking upon of another person for more than a
  brief period of time, in other than a casual or cursory manner . . . .â€Â  As
  previously noted, subsection (D) of this statute clearly refers to the terms
  used in subsection (B) of the statute which prohibits the crime of voyeurism.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-470(B) and (D) (2003).Â  Subsection (A) of the statute
  prohibits one from â€œpeep[ing] through windows, doors, or other like places . .
  . and any other conduct of a similar nature, that tends to invade the privacy
  of others.â€Â  S.C. Code. Ann. Â§ 16-17-470(A) (2003).Â  â€œPeepâ€ has been defined
  alternatively as â€œto look cautiously or slyly; a brief look: glance; a furtive
  look.â€Â  Websterâ€™s Ninth New Collegiate Dictionary 867 (9th ed. 1990).Â  There is
  clearly evidence that Caldwell peeped at each of the young victimsâ€™ privates.Â 
  Finally, even if we were to assume arguendo subsection (D) of the statute
  applied, we find there is evidence Caldwell did intentionally look at the
  privates of the three young victims for more than just a brief period of time
  in other than a casual or cursory manner.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing reasons, we find no reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to sever the trials, denial of
  Caldwellâ€™s motion to suppress the two boysâ€™ in-court identifications, admission
  of alleged statements made by Caldwell, admission of testimony regarding how
  Caldwellâ€™s actions made the victims feel, and denial of Caldwellâ€™s motion for
  directed verdict. Accordingly, Caldwellâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  JJ., concurs.
KITTREDGE,
  JJ., concurs in result.
KITTREDGE, J.:  I concur in result but write separately as I
  believe it was error to admit the victimsâ€™ testimony concerning how they felt
  when Caldwell stared at their genitals.Â  As the defense points out, the
  presence or absence of a victimâ€™s â€œfeelingsâ€ is irrelevant under the â€œpeeping
  tom statuteâ€ because a victimâ€™s emotional response has no bearing on any
  element of the crime.Â  Indeed, in many such prosecutions, the victim is unaware
  of the peeping tom's presence and the invasion of privacy.Â  I concur in result
  as this error was harmless due to the overwhelming evidence of guilt.Â  State
    v. Garner, 304 S.C. 220, 222, 403 S.E.2d 631, 632 (1991) (holding
  improperly admitted evidence was harmless error given the overwhelming evidence
  of guilt).


[1]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2]Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).
[3]Neil v. Biggers,
  409 U.S. 188 (1972).
[4]Although the State opposed a Neil v. Biggers hearing at the trial level arguing it was unnecessary where the in-court
  identification forms the first identification the witness made, it does not so
  argue on appeal.Â  Because we find no error in the admission of the in-court
  identifications, we express no opinion on whether such a hearing was required
  under the circumstances.Â  See State v. Lewis, 363 S.C. 37, 43, 609
  S.E.2d 515, 518 (2005) (holding Neil v. Biggers does not apply to a
  first-time in-court identification because the judge is present and can
  adequately address relevant problems; the jury is physically present to witness
  the identification, rather than merely hearing testimony about it; and
  cross-examination offers defendants an adequate safeguard or remedy against
  suggestive examinations); but cf. State v. Simmons, 308
  S.C. 80, 82-83, 417 S.E.2d 92, 93 (1992), (holding in camera hearing was needed
  to determine whether the in-court identification was of independent origin or
  was the tainted product of the circumstances surrounding a bond hearing where a
  witness saw a suspect at a bond hearing prior to his in-court identification of
  the suspect and the witness may have gotten a â€œfixâ€ on the suspect at the bond
  hearing). 
[5]Jackson v.
  Denno, 378 U.S. 368 (1964).
[6]Caldwell cites to
  language in the statute defining the phrase â€œ[p]lace where a person would have
  a reasonable expectation of privacyâ€ in support of his argument this testimony
  was not relevant.Â  However, this phrase applies to the section of the statute
  prohibiting the crime of voyeurism and is not found in the section prohibiting
  eavesdropping and peeping.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-470(A), (B), and (D) (2003).
[7]It should be noted, while Caldwell challenged the
  constitutionality of the statute at trial, in particular the phrase â€œother
  conduct of a similar nature, that tends to invade the privacy of others,â€ as
  being overly broad, he does not raise that issue on appeal.Â

title: Stradford v. Wilson
description: Bettina Wilson (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order changing her childâ€™s surname from Wilson to Stradford, the surname of the childâ€™s father, Ryan Stradford (Father).  Finding Father failed to carry his burden of proving the name change was in childâ€™s best interest, we reverse.

<!--

-->




THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ryan Corey
      Stradford, Respondent,
				v.
				Bettina
      Rashunda Wilson, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lancaster County
Brian M. Gibbons, Family Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  4393
Submitted March 5, 2008 â€“ Filed May 20,
  2008Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Coreen B. Khoury, of Lancaster, for Appellant.
				Govan T. Myers, III, of Lancaster, for Respondent.
			
		
	



HEARN, C.J.:Â  Bettina
  Wilson (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order changing her childâ€™s surname
  from Wilson to Stradford, the surname of the childâ€™s father, Ryan Stradford
  (Father).Â  Finding Father failed to carry his burden of proving the name change
  was in childâ€™s best interest, we reverse. [1] 
FACTS
Jane
  Doe Wilson (Child) was born to Mother and Father on March 14, 2004.Â  Mother and
  Father never married,[2]Â 
  and since birth, Child has lived with Mother, Motherâ€™s sister, Childâ€™s
  half-sister, and Childâ€™s maternal grandmother in the grandmotherâ€™s home.Â 
  Father lives in the same town with his mother in her home.Â  
In April 2005, Father filed a complaint seeking to establish his
  paternity and requesting liberal visitation.Â  Father thereafter amended his
  complaint seeking to change Childâ€™s name to Stradford.Â  In October 2005, the
  parties informed the court they had reached an agreement on all issues, except
  changing Childâ€™s name.Â  Accordingly, the family court entered an order finding
  Father was Childâ€™s biological father, ordering the birth certificate to reflect
  Fatherâ€™s paternity, and establishing a visitation schedule; however, the court continued
  Fatherâ€™s request to change Childâ€™s name pending the appointment of a guardian
  ad litem (GAL). 
At the March 13, 2007 trial, Father testified he wanted Child to
  have his surname because he planned on supporting her the rest of his life.Â 
  The paternal grandmother also testified Child should have Fatherâ€™s surname
  because â€œ[w]e have a family tradition, a long family tradition.â€Â  Mother, on the other hand, testified Childâ€™s
  surname should remain Wilson because Child lives with the Wilson family, Child is close to her half-sister, and â€œboth of them know now that their
  last name is Wilson.â€Â  Motherâ€™s
  half-sister testified to the difficulty she had experienced living in a
  household with a different surname from that of other family members.
The GAL recommended changing Childâ€™s surname to either Stradford
  or Wilson-Stradford, stating: â€œI think itâ€™s important that this child have the
  recognition that she is her fatherâ€™s child and that she does have that strong
  relationship with both families.â€Â  The
  court stated from the bench it would grant Fatherâ€™s petition to change Childâ€™s
  surname and issued a written order on April 15, 2007.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother
  argues the family court erred in granting Fatherâ€™s petition to change Childâ€™s
  surname from Wilson to Stradford because Father failed to prove changing the
  name was in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  We agree.Â  
When
  one parent petitions the court to remove the other parentâ€™s surname from the
  partiesâ€™ minor child, each parent has a protectible interest in receiving
  notice and being heard on the petition.Â  Ex parte Stull, 276 S.C. 512,
  513, 280 S.E.2d 209, 210 (1981).Â  However, â€œthe parent seeking to change the
  childâ€™s surname has the burden of proving that the change will further the childâ€™s
  best interests.â€Â  Mazzone v. Miles, 341 S.C. 203, 210, 532 S.E.2d 890,
  893 (Ct. App. 2000).
In Mazzone,
  the family court granted the fatherâ€™s request to change the name of the
  partiesâ€™ young child from motherâ€™s surname to his, in which it found: Â the
  childâ€™s parents had never married; the child had been in the motherâ€™s custody
  since birth; the father, mother, and child had lived together for two years;
  the father had a close relationship with the child; and the child was
  comfortable with her present name.Â  Mazzone, 341 S.C. 203. 532 S.E.2d
  890.Â  On appeal, this court reversed, and identified nine factors to consider in
  determining whether changing a childâ€™s surname is in the childâ€™s best interest,
  including: (1) the length of time the child has
  used the present surname; (2) the effect of the proposed change on the
  preservation and development of the childâ€™s relationship with each parent; (3)
  the identification of the child as part of a family unit; (4) the wishes of each
  parent; (5) the reason the petitioning parent states for the proposed change;
  (6) the motive of the petitioning parent and the possibility the childâ€™s use of
  a different name will cause insecurity or a lack of identity; (7) the
  difficulty, harassment, or embarrassment the child may experience if the child
  bears a surname different from that of the custodial parent; (8) if the child
  is of age and maturity to express a meaningful preference, the childâ€™s preference; and (9)
  the degree of community respect associated with the present and proposed
  surnames.Â  Id. at 210-11, 532 S.E.2d at 893-94.Â  The court explained:

	[B]oth
  parents have an equal interest in the child bearing their respective surname . . . While it may
  be a custom to name a child after the father, giving greater weight to the
  fatherâ€™s interest fails to
  consider that, where the parents have never been married, the mother has at
  least an equal interest in
  having the child bear the maternal surname. Â In these times of parental
  equality, arguing that the child of unmarried parents should bear the paternal
  surname based on custom is another way of arguing that it is permissible to
  discriminate because the discrimination has been endured for many years.

Id. at 211-12, 532 S.E.2d at 894 (internal citations
  omitted).Â  
In
  this case, the family courtâ€™s order recognized that Mazzone controlled
  and noted the applicable burden of proof.Â  Although the order lists the Mazzone factors and states the court considered each factor, it does not contain
  specific findings pursuant to Mazzone.Â  Applying the Mazzone factors to this case, as we are permitted to do under the broad scope of review
  accorded to us, we make the following findings based on the preponderance of
  evidence: Â (1) Child, who was three years old at the time of the hearing, is
  known in the community by the Wilson name; (2) Child already is aware her name
  is Wilson; (3) although we agree changing Childâ€™s name could help develop her
  relationship with Fatherâ€™s family, it also could have a negative impact on
  Childâ€™s continuing relationship with her custodial family; (4) Childâ€™s
  relationship with Fatherâ€™s family will develop primarily through regular
  participation in the visitation granted by the court; (5) Fatherâ€™s basis for changing
  Childâ€™s name is insufficient; and (6) Child could experience embarrassment if
  her name differs from that of her custodial family. 
Accordingly,
  we reverse the order of the family court changing Childâ€™s surname to Wilson.Â  The decision of the family court is
REVERSED.
PIEPER, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant
  to the partiesâ€™ request and Rule 215, SCACR.Â  
[2] Father
  has a second daughter, who lives with her mother and is two years younger than
  Child.Â  Mother has a second daughter, who lives
  with her and is a year older than Child.Â  Â Â

title: Platt v. SCDOT
description: In this civil litigation, the Appellant states the issues: (1) the South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) had a duty to protect the public from the dangerous condition created by the malfunctioning warning device at Red Bank Road; (2) the trial court improperly held that SCDOT satisfied its duty by informing CSX Transportation of the malfunctioning signals; and (3) SCDOTâ€™s negligence in failing to maintain the traffic signals in compliance with the signal plans was a proximate cause of the collision. The Respondent, South Carolina Department of Transportation, identifies the issues on appeal: (1) did Respondent SCDOT owe an individual duty to Asia Platt and her family rather than a general duty to the public at large?; (2) did the trial court err in holding that Respondent SCDOT properly fulfilled its duty to the public at large by informing CSX Railroad of the malfunctioning signals maintained by CSX railroad in accordance with the Code of Federal Regulations?; and (3) did the trial court err in granting summary judgment to respondent SCDOT where Appellantâ€™s expert testified that the accident would not have occurred but for a malfunction in the railroad crossing arms maintained by CSX railroad?

<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA|
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Beaulah
      Platt, as guardian for Asia Platt, a minor under the age of fourteen years,
      as Personal Representative of the Estate of Valerie Marie Platt, deceased,
      and as Personal Representative of the Estate of William Leroy Platt,
      deceased, Appellant,
				v.
				CSX
      Transportation, Inc., and South Carolina Department of Transportation, Defendants,
				of whom
      South Carolina Department of Transportation is Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4394
Heard May 6, 2008 â€“ Filed May 20, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David L. Savage, of Charleston; Ronnie Lanier Crosby, of Hampton, for Appellant.
				Jonathan J. Anderson, Lisa A. Reynolds, and Eric M. Johnsen, all
  of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Beaulah Platt, as guardian of Asia Platt and as personal
  representative of the estates of Valerie Platt and William Leroy Platt, appeals
  the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of the South Carolina
  Department of Transportation (Department).Â  Platt contends: (1) the Department
  had a duty to protect the public from the dangerous condition created by a
  malfunctioning railroad warning device; (2) the trial court improperly held the
  Department satisfied its duty by informing CSX Transportation, Inc. (CSX) of
  the malfunctioning signals; and (3) the Departmentâ€™s negligence in failing to
  maintain the traffic signals in compliance with the signal plans was a
  proximate cause of the collision.Â  We affirm.Â Â  
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On June 19, 1999,
  William Corley was driving Valerie Platt, Asia Platt, and William Corley Jr.,
  in his automobile on Red Bank Road toward Highway 52 in Goose Creek, South Carolina.[1]Â 
  Red Bank Road intersects both Highway 52 and a CSX railroad track, which are
  parallel to one another.Â  In the direction Corley was traveling, he would cross
  over the railroad tracks before entering the Red Bank Road and Highway 52
  intersection.Â  There were railroad crossing arms and warning lights
  approximately two car lengths on either side of the railroad tracks. 
As Corley approached the intersection of Red Bank Road and Highway
  52, traffic was stopped at the traffic signal.Â  While Corley waited, the railroad track crossing arms and
  warning lights activated and lowered in front of his vehicle.Â  A train did not
  pass, the crossing arms lifted, and Corley drove forward.Â  Soon thereafter, the
  crossing arms again lowered, placing Corleyâ€™s vehicle between the crossing arms
  and the railroad tracks.Â  Testimony differs regarding Corleyâ€™s actions
  at this point, but it appears Corley backed up at least once to ensure his
  vehicle was clear from the tracks. Â At least one vehicle was in front of
  Corleyâ€™s but on the other side of the tracks between the tracks and the stop
  light at Highway 52.Â  Prior to the trainâ€™s arrival, no vehicles blocked Corleyâ€™s
  forward progress to the intersection. Â Corley drove forward and was
  struck by an oncoming CSX train.Â  Asia Platt was the sole survivor in the
  vehicle, and has since been cared for by her maternal grandmother, Beaulah
  Platt. 
Beaulah Platt, as the guardian for Asia
  Platt and personal representative of the estates of Valerie and William Platt,
  filed a negligence action against CSX and the Department.Â  Beaulah Platt and
  CSX reached a settlement agreement prior to oral argument on the Departmentâ€™s summary
  judgment motion.Â  The trial court granted the Departmentâ€™s summary judgment
  motion, finding: (1) the Department fulfilled its duty by reporting defects in
  the warning signals to CSX; (2) the Department had no duty to make repairs of
  the crossing arms; (3) the Code of Federal Regulations vests only CSX with the
  duty to maintain crossing signals; and (4) the proximate cause of the collision
  was a malfunction of the crossing arms and not the Departmentâ€™s traffic
  signals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When
  reviewing a grant of summary judgment, the appellate
  court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c),
  SCRCP, summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 633 S.E.2d 505 (2006); Houck v.
    State Farm Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 11, 620 S.E.2d 326, 329
  (2005); Bradley v. Doe, 374 S.C. 622, 649 S.E.2d 153 (Ct. App. 2007); Bennett
    v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 578, 635 S.E.2d 649 (Ct. App. 2006); see Rule 56(c), SCRCP (â€œThe judgment sought shall be rendered forthwith if the
  pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file,
  together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to
  any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a
  matter of law.â€).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the
  evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light
  most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall
    Co., 363 S.C. 334, 611 S.E.2d 485 (2005); Medical Univ. of S.C. v.
      Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); Hackworth v. Greenville
        County, 371 S.C. 99, 102, 637 S.E.2d 320, 322 (Ct. App. 2006); Rife v.
          Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 609 S.E.2d 565 (Ct. App. 2005).
â€œSummary
  judgment is appropriate where the pleadings, depositions, answers to
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any,
  show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  BPS, 362 S.C. at
  325, 608 S.E.2d at 159; see also Higgins v. Medical Univ. of South Carolina, 326 S.C. 592, 486 S.E.2d 269 (Ct. App. 1997) (a trial judge
  considering a motion for summary judgment must consider all documents and
  evidence within the record, including pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, admissions on
  file, and affidavits).Â  â€œOn
  appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review
  all ambiguities, conclusions, and
  inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the
  non-moving party below.â€Â  Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina v. The
    State of South Carolina, 372 S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007).Â  
Summary
  judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into where further inquiry
  into the facts is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Brockbank
    v. Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688 (2000); Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 487 S.E.2d 187 (1997).Â  Even when there is no dispute
  as to evidentiary facts, summary judgment is not appropriate if there is
  disagreement concerning the conclusion to be drawn from those facts.Â  Moriarty
    v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000); Ellis
      v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, when
  plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot
  differ, summary judgment should be granted.Â  BPS,
  362 S.C. at 325, 608 S.E.2d at 159.Â  
The purpose of summary judgment
  is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a
  fact finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438
  (2003) (quoting George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874
  (2001)); Moore v. Weinberg, 373 S.C. 209, 217, 644 S.E.2d 740, 744 (Ct. App.
  2007); Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 596-97, 608 S.E.2d 587,
  592 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Because summary judgment is a drastic remedy, summary
  judgment should be cautiously invoked to ensure a litigant is not improperly
  deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues.Â  Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz
    Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 644, 594 S.E.2d 455, 462 (2004); B
      & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™ Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 270, 603 S.E.2d 629, 631
  (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Public Duty Rule
Platt avers the
  Department had a duty to protect the public from a dangerous condition created
  by the malfunctioning warning device.Â  We disagree. 
The public duty rule was originally adopted by the South Carolina Supreme Court in Parker v.
  Brown, 195 S.C. 35, 52, 10 S.E.2d 625, 632 (1940):

	The law
  necessarily grants certain discretion to its officers in handling the public
  business.Â  In one instance it may be wise for a public officer to pursue one
  course, in another instance, another course. Those charged with protecting the
  public interest should view that interest as supreme, should consider what is
  best for the public, and should be free at all times to prosecute the course
  that appears to be in the public interest . . . .Â  It is well settled that an
  individual has no right of action against a public officer for breach of a duty
  owing to the public only, even though such individual be specially injured
  thereby. Where a duty is owing to the public
  only, an officer is not liable to an individual who may have been incidentally
  injured by his failure to perform it. 

Under South
  Carolinaâ€™s public duty doctrine, public
  officials are not liable to individuals for their negligence in discharging
  public duties as the duty is owed to the public at large rather than to anyone
  individually.Â  Tanner v. Florence Co. Treasurer, 336 S.C. 552, 561, 521
  S.E.2d 153, 158 (1999); Jensen v. Anderson County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 304 S.C. 195, 199, 403
  S.E.2d 615, 617 (1991); Arthurs v. Aiken County, 338 S.C. 253, 262,
  525 S.E.2d 542, 546 (Ct. App. 1999) (Arthurs I) affâ€™d as
    modified, 346 S.C. 97, 551 S.E.2d 579 (2001) (Arthurs II).
The public duty rule is not a separate legal doctrine.Â  Arthurs I, 
  338 S.C. at 262, 525 S.E.2d at 546; Rayfield v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 297
  S.C. 95, 105, 374 S.E.2d 910, 915 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The public duty rule is a
  special application of the broader
  principle that an action for negligence based upon an alleged violation of a
  statute cannot be maintained if the statute was enacted for a purpose other
  than preventing the complained of injury.Â  Arthurs I, 338 S.C. at 262,
  525 S.E.2d at 546; Rayfield, 297 S.C. at 105, 374 S.E.2d at 915.Â  The
  rule applies to the special case of statutes which create or define the duties
  of a public office.Â  Rayfield, 297 S.C. at 105, 374 S.E.2d at 915.
An essential element in a
  negligence cause of action is the existence of a legal duty of care owed by the
  defendant to the plaintiff.Â  Wyatt v. Fowler, 326 S.C. 97, 101, 484
  S.E.2d 590, 592 (1997); Rogers v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Parole and Cmty. Corr.,
  320 S.C. 253, 255, 464 S.E.2d 330, 332 (1995).Â  Without such a duty, there can
  be no actionable negligence.Â  Rogers, 320 S.C. at 255, 464 S.E.2d at
  592.Â  To prevail in a negligence action, a plaintiff must demonstrate: (1) a
  duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty
  by a negligent act or omission; and (3) damage proximately resulting from the
  breach.Â  Tanner, 336 S.C. at 561, 521 S.E.2d at 158.Â  The court must
  determine, as a matter of law, whether the law recognizes a particular duty.Â  Steinke
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 387, 520
  S.E.2d 142, 149 (1999); see also Rogers v. Atl. Coast Line
    R.R., 222 S.C. 66, 71 S.E.2d 585 (1952) (whether defendant is under legal
  duty to plaintiff is question of law for court); Araujo v. S. Bell Tel. and
    Tel. Co., 291 S.C. 54, 351 S.E.2d 908 (Ct. App. 1986) (question of whether
  defendant owes duty, the breach of which
  may constitute negligence, is a question of law, not of fact). 
Ordinarily,
  there is no common law duty to act.Â  Arthurs I,  338 S.C. at 264,
  525 S.E.2d at 547.Â  However, an affirmative legal duty may be created by

    Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 306, 501 S.E.2d 746, 752 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Normally,
  such officials enjoy immunity from a private cause of action under the public
  duty rule. Wells, 331 S.C. at 307, 501 S.E.2d at 752.Â  This rule limits public
  officialsâ€™ liability to individuals for their negligence in
  discharging public duties as the duty is owed to the public at large rather
  than an individual.Â  Id.Â  Thus, when the duty is owed to the public in
  general, the official is not liable to an individual who may have been

  specific individuals rather than the public at large.Â  Id.

  public office have the essential purpose of providing for the structure and
  operation of government or for securing the general welfare and safety of the
  public.â€Â  Arthurs I, 338 S.C. at 265, 525 S.E.2d at 548; Tanner,
  336 S.C. at 562, 521 S.E.2d at 158; Wells, 331 S.C. at 308, 501 S.E.2d

  exception is recognized where the plaintiff can establish the defendant owed a

To determine if a special duty is owed to the
  plaintiff, the court looks to the statute and the facts of the particular case.Â  Arthurs I, 338 S.C. at 265, 525 S.E.2d at 548.Â  In Rayfield, 297

	(1) an

title: State v. Mitchell
description: Mitchell appeals his convictions for murder, attempted armed robbery, and possession of the weapon during the commission of a violent crime, arguing (1) the trial judge should not have admitted a statement of alleged accomplice who refuse to testify when called as a witness for the State, and (2) Mitchell should have been allowed to present certain evidence concerning third-party guilt.
