-->




THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Hercules E.
      Mitchell, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4395
Heard April 8, 2008 â€“ Filed May 22, 2008
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant
  Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor David
  Michael Pascoe, Jr., of Orangeburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

THOMAS, J.:Â 
  Hercules E. Mitchell appeals his convictions for murder, attempted armed
  robbery, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime,
  arguing the trial judge made several erroneous evidentiary rulings.Â  We affirm
  in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS AND
  PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The
  victim, David Martin, lived close to his father, Nathaniel Martin, in a mobile
  home and ran Nathanielâ€™s farm for a living.Â  There was evidence that David sold
  marijuana and cocaine out of his mobile home.
On
  March 2, 2003, around 11:00 p.m., Thomas Anthony, a family friend who was
  staying with David at the time, knocked on Nathanielâ€™s window and told him
  David had been shot.Â  Nathaniel and his wife went to Davidâ€™s mobile home, where
  they found him lying on the floor. Unable to elicit any response from David,
  they called 911.
According
  to Nathaniel, Anthony, who was deceased when the matter came to trial, informed
  him three persons were involved in the incident. Â Two of the participants were
  males wearing masks, neither of whom Anthony could identify.Â  Anthony did,
  however, identify the third participant as Bridgett Darby. Â Darby used to rent
  the mobile home where David was residing at the time of his death.
Officers
  then located and arrested Darby.Â  On March 3, 2003, at 1:33 p.m., Darby gave a
  written statement implicating herself and naming Kelvin Johnson and Terrance
  James.[1]Â 
  In the statement, Darby said the three â€œtalked about getting together to do to
  David Martinâ€™s house to rob him.â€Â  Darby further stated the three only intended
  to take marijuana from David and then flee the scene without injuring him.Â  She
  further maintained the shooting was an accident and she learned about it only
  after the three later met at her home.Â  In addition to giving the written
  statement, Darby also told police that both Kelvin Johnson and Terrance James were
  from Columbia.
Darby
  then accompanied police officers to Columbia to help them find Kelvin Johnson
  and Terrance James.Â  Officers consulted Richland County authorities, but were
  still unable to locate either individual.Â  They then confronted Darby about the
  accuracy of her information. Â At 8:00 p.m. the same day, Darby gave a second
  statement, this time naming Mitchell instead of Terrance James as the third
  accomplice.
Police
  apprehended seventeen-year-old Kelvin Johnson during the early morning hours of
  March 4, 2003.Â  About eight or nine hours later, Johnson gave a written
  statement in which he admitted he had panicked and shot David when he saw David
  reach for a gun.Â  In the statement, Johnson also implicated Mitchell,
  specifically noting (1) Mitchell had helped in supplying the guns that they
  used to rob David; (2) following the incident, he, Darby, and Mitchell checked
  into the Southern Lodge; and (3) the three divided the money they had seized
  from David during the robbery.Â  Two days later, Mitchell voluntarily submitted
  to police custody.
In
  October 2004, the Orangeburg County Grand Jury indicted Mitchell for the
  offenses of murder, attempted armed robbery, and possession of a weapon during
  the commission of a violent crime.Â  A jury trial in the matter commenced
  December 13, 2005.
At
  trial, Darby testified for the State, giving information consistent with her
  second statement and acknowledging she was serving sentences for accessory
  after the fact and armed robbery because of her participation in the incident.Â 
  She testified she and Mitchell worked together, were romantically involved, and
  had discussed robbing David Martin before the incident took place.Â  Darby also
  admitted a rifle used in the incident belonged to her uncle; however, she also
  stated she did not know how a pistol believed to be the murder weapon was
  acquired.
The
  State then called Johnson to the stand.Â  Johnson had previously pled guilty to
  and was sentenced for murder, armed robbery, and possession of a weapon during
  the commission of a violent crime. Â Outside the presence of the jury, Johnson
  complained to the trial judge that the solicitorâ€™s office had â€œforcedâ€ him to
  appear at Mitchellâ€™s trial and threatened him with additional time in prison if
  he did not â€œcome up here and make this man be guilty.â€Â  In response, the trial
  judge advised Johnson that (1) both the State and the defense had the right to
  subpoena witnesses and any witnesses who refused to answer questions while on
  the stand could be held in contempt of court and sentenced to six months; (2)
  untruthful answers could result in perjury charges, for which the sentence
  could be five years; and (3) when Johnson pled guilty to the charges for which
  he was sentenced, he gave a statement under oath adopting the statement that he
  had previously given to the police about the incident.
When
  the jury returned to the courtroom, Johnson, after some prodding, affirmed to
  tell the truth.Â  When the solicitor began to question him, Johnson was uncooperative,
  giving unresponsive answers and again accusing the State of forcing him to
  appear in court.Â  When Johnson persisted in refusing to answer the solicitorâ€™s
  questions, even after the trial judge warned him of the consequences, the trial
  judge sentenced him for contempt and ordered officers to remove him from the
  courtroom.
The
  State moved to introduce Johnsonâ€™s statement through its next witness, Captain
  Rene Williams of the Orangeburg County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  During an in camera
  hearing, the trial judge, over objections from the defense, found Johnson had
  given his statement freely and voluntarily. Â When the State asserted the
  statement was admissible as a prior inconsistent statement as a result of
  Johnsonâ€™s denying it on the stand, defense counsel argued the prejudicial
  effect would outweigh the probative value of the statement and
  cross-examination was not possible because Johnson had already been removed
  from the proceedings.Â  Counsel further asserted:Â  â€œTheyâ€™re asking us to admit a
  blanket statement that says that thereâ€™s some culpability of my client, and I
  have no opportunity to test the credibility other than to ask the officers who
  assisted in getting the statement.â€
The
  solicitor then asserted Johnsonâ€™s statement was admissible under Rules
  804(a)(2) and (b)(3) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence, which permit the
  admission of a statement against interest as an exception to the hearsay rule
  when a witness persists in refusing to testify despite a court order to do so.Â 
  In response, defense counsel stated he stayed with his objection.Â  The trial
  judge accepted the Stateâ€™s argument and allowed the solicitor to publish
  Johnsonâ€™s statement through Captain Williams.
After
  Williams testified, the State called Kenny Kinsey, who at the time of the
  incident was a sergeant in the Central Investigative Division of the Orangeburg
  County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  Kinsey testified he interviewed Darby after she was
  arrested.Â  He also noted that although Darby initially implicated Johnson and
  Terrance James as well as herself, she later revealed that Johnson and Mitchell
  were her accomplices.Â  
On
  cross-examination, Kinsey claimed Terrance James â€œwas a fictitious nameâ€ that
  Darby had given authorities to protect Mitchell.Â  Defense counsel then
  attempted to refer to an Orangeburg telephone directory, prompting the
  solicitor to request an in camera hearing.Â  During this hearing, Kinsey
  explained on cross-examination that after previous attempts to locate Terrance
  Johnson in Richland County proved futile and both Darby and Johnson named
  Mitchell as the third participant, he did not check Orangeburg County sources, including the local telephone book, to determine if anyone by the name of
  Terrance James could be found in the area.Â  Upon further cross-examination,
  Kinsey acknowledged there was a directory listing for a â€œTerrance A. Jamesâ€ in Springfield, a town in Orangeburg close to the crime scene, as well as various listings
  for â€œTerry Jamesâ€ and â€œT.A. Jamesâ€ in Lexington and Richland Counties.
The
  solicitor argued against allowing the jury to hear evidence about the telephone
  book listings, contending this was impermissible evidence of third-party guilt
  that would only confuse the jury.Â  The trial judge agreed and did not allow the
  defense to introduce either the telephone books or â€œany evidence that thereâ€™s
  somebody somewhere named Terrance James.â€Â  The trial judge, however, did allow
  defense counsel to question Kinsey about what he did and did not do during the
  course of his investigation.
On
  December 15, 2005, the jury convicted Mitchell of all three offenses, and the
  trial judge sentenced him accordingly.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Admission of Kelvin
  Johnsonâ€™s Statement
Mitchell
  first contends the trial judge committed error in admitting the statement Johnson
  made to law enforcement while in police custody.Â  We agree.
The
  Confrontation Clause of the Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution
  requires that â€œ[i]n all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the
  rightÂ  . . . to be confronted with the witnesses against him.â€Â  U.S. Const.
  amend. VI.Â  In South Carolina, not only is this right applicable to state
  prosecutions under the Fourteenth Amendment, it is specifically mandated by the
  State Constitution.Â  State v. Green, 269 S.C. 657, 661, 239 S.E.2d 485, 487
  (1977) (citing S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 14).
In
  1987, the South Carolina Supreme Court noted the Confrontation Clause did not
  prevent the use of hearsay evidence in criminal trials â€œwhere the evidence
  bears significant â€˜indicia of reliability.â€™ â€Â  State v. Cooper, 291 S.C.
  351, 355, 353 S.E.2d 451, 454 (1987) (quoting Lee v. Illinois, 476 U.S. 530, 539 (1986)).Â  Two years later, however, in State v. Pfirman, the court
  appeared to take a decidedly more restrictive view toward allowing hearsay
  evidence against a criminal defendant.Â  Under Pfirman, although a prior
  inconsistent statement implicating an accused may be admitted as substantive
  evidence when the declarant testifies at trial and is subject to
  cross-examination, â€œ[w]hen . . . the declarant refuses to admit the statement
  imputed to him, the accused is denied effective cross-examination in violation
  of his confrontation rights.â€Â  State v. Pfirman, 300 S.C. 84, 86, 386
  S.E.2d 461, 462 (1989).Â  
In
  2004, the United States Supreme Court, in Crawford v. Washington, reversed
  an assault and battery conviction, holding the trial court should have
  suppressed a statement to law enforcement given in conjunction with the
  investigation because state privilege law prevented the prosecution from
  calling the declarant to testify against the defendant.Â  Although the statement
  was admissible as a hearsay exception under the applicable rules of evidence,
  the court held that â€œ[w]here testimonial evidence is at issue, . . . the Sixth
  Amendment demands what the common law required:Â  unavailability and a prior
  opportunity for cross-examination.â€Â  Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 68 (2004).
We
  see no reason why the rule in Crawford and similar South Carolina cases
  should not apply to the present dispute.Â  Although the trial judge ultimately
  ruled Johnsonâ€™s statement admissible as a statement against interest from an
  unavailable declarant rather than as a prior inconsistent statement, Mitchell
  had no opportunity to cross-examine Johnson about the statement because Johnson
  had already been removed from the courtroom when the State moved to admit it.
The
  State argues Mitchell did not preserve this issue for appeal because his trial
  attorney never explicitly raised the issue of due process.Â  The State further contends
  Mitchell did not adequately present a Crawford objection in his brief to
  this Court.Â  We reject these arguments.
There
  is persuasive authority for the Stateâ€™s position that an assignment of error
  under Crawford requires more than a standard hearsay objection.Â  See Mencos v. State, 909 So. 2d 349, 351 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2005) (â€œAn
  objection specifically based on Crawford serves to focus the trial
  courtâ€™s attention on the salient inquiry required by that decision, i.e.,
  whether the evidence is â€˜testimonial,â€™ whether the witness is â€˜unavailable,â€™
  and whether there was a â€˜prior opportunity for cross-examination.â€™ â€) (quoting Crawford,
  541 U.S. at 68).Â  Nevertheless, even though Mitchellâ€™s attorneys did not cite Crawford during trial or explain on appeal why this decision is applicable, we hold Mitchell
  presented a sufficient basis for an assertion of reversible error. Â 
At
  trial, defense counsel argued the statement at issue was â€œa blanket statement
  that thereâ€™s some culpability of my clientâ€ and he had â€œno opportunity to test
  [Johnsonâ€™s] credibility.â€Â  Even without a citation to Crawford, these
  assertions were sufficient to direct the trial judgeâ€™s attention to the
  problems attendant to admission of an incriminating statement when the declarant
  is unavailable for cross-examination by the accused.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Transp. v. First Carolina Corp. of S.C., 372 S.C. 295, 302-03, 641
  S.E.2d 903, 907 (2007) (holding an objection, though not phrased â€œin the exact
  terms used in the issues on appealâ€ â€œprovided a
  meaningful objection with sufficient specificity to allow the trial court to
  rule on the issueâ€).
In
  the recent case of State v. Ladner, the South Carolina Supreme Court
  noted that although â€œ[t]he Crawford Court declined to comprehensively
  define â€˜testimonial,â€™ â€ it included within a â€œ â€˜core class of â€œtestimonialâ€
  statementsâ€™ â€ (1) â€œcustodial examinationsâ€ and (2) â€œstatements that were made
  under circumstances which would lead an objective witness reasonably to believe
  the statement would be available for use at a later trial.â€Â  State v. Ladner,
  373 S.C. 103, 112, 644 S.E.2d 684, 688-89 (2007) (quoting Crawford, 541 U.S. at 51-52).Â  Here, defense counsel argued Johnsonâ€™s statement inculpated his client,
  the only reasonable inference being that an objective witness would expect the
  statement could be used at a later trial.
We further
  hold the objections presented at trial concerning the defenseâ€™s inability to
  cross-examine Johnson, together with the arguments Mitchell presented on appeal,
  sufficiently preserved for our review the issue of whether he was denied his
  Sixth Amendment right of confrontation.Â  See State v.McNinch, 12 
S.C. 89, 96-97 (1879) (â€œBut the right to cross-examine is one which must remain 
inviolate.  To take it away would render almost valueless the
  constitutional right â€˜to meet the witnesses against him face to face.â€™ â€) (citing
  S.C. Const. art. 1, Â§ 11 [now section 14]), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 69 n.5, 406 S.E.2d 315, 328 n.5 (1991).Â 
  The State suggested during oral argument that the arguments by the defense
  against admission of Johnsonâ€™s statement were presented in a context that would
  have more readily suggested an assertion of prejudice than one of the loss of
  the right to confront a witness. Â We hold, however, defense counselâ€™s complaint
  about his inability to cross-examine Johnson were sufficient to preserve for
  our review the issue of his clientâ€™s right to confront witnesses.Â  Counselâ€™s
  contention that he had â€œno opportunity to test the credibility other than to
  ask the officers who assisted in getting the statementâ€ went directly to the
  heart of confrontation, namely, the requirement that â€œa witness . . . testify
  under oath and submit to cross-examination so that the jury can observe the
  witnessâ€™s demeanor and assess his credibility.â€Â  State v. Gillian, 360
  S.C. 433, 449, 602 S.E.2d 62, 71 (2006).[2]
Finally, we disagree with the Stateâ€™s argument that we should
  uphold the admission of Johnsonâ€™s statement because Mitchellâ€™s brief to this
  Court focused on a general denial of due process rather than on the specific
  complaints expressed during the trial about his Sixth Amendment right of
  confrontation under Crawford.Â  Although defense counsel never expressly
  mentioned due process at trial, his assertions about the right to confront adverse
  witnesses regarding incriminating statements raised due process concerns.Â  See Dangerfield v. State, 376 S.C. 176, ___, 656 S.E.2d 352, 354 (2008) (including
  â€œthe right to confront and cross-examine adverse witnessesâ€ as one of the
  requirements of â€œ[t]he procedural component of the state and federal due
  process clausesâ€).
The
  State further argues there was no denial of fundamental fairness because
  Johnson took the stand and gave evidence favorable to Mitchell.Â  We disagree.Â 
  As noted in Crawford, â€œ[w]here testimonial evidence is at issue, . . .
  the Sixth Amendment demands what the common law required:Â  unavailability and a
  prior opportunity for cross-examination.â€Â  Crawford, 541 U.S. at 68.Â  In the present case, although Johnson took the stand, he refused to answer the
  solicitorâ€™s questions, was found in contempt, and was removed from the
  courtroom while still on direct examination and before his statement was
  introduced.Â  We are simply at a loss to understand how Mitchell ever had the
  opportunity to cross-examine Johnson about his statement.Â  See Douglas
    v. Alabama, 380 U.S. 415, 416-19 (1965) (holding a defendantâ€™s Sixth
  Amendment rights were improperly denied by allowing the prosecutor to read,
  â€œunder the guise of cross-examination to refresh [the witnessâ€™s] recollectionâ€
  a statement from a witness who persisted in relying on self-incrimination
  grounds to avoid answering questions even after the trial court advised the
  witness that such a privilege was not available); Simpkins v. State, 303
  S.C. 364, 368, 401 S.E.2d 142, 143-44 (1991) (holding that admission of hearsay
  testimony from a child victimâ€™s guardian ad litem unfairly denied the defendant
  the right of cross examination even though the victim had testified in court); cf. State v. Blue, 717 N.W.2d 558, 566 (N.D. 2006) (â€œA witnessâ€™s mere appearance at a preliminary hearing is not an adequate
  opportunity for cross-examination for purposes under the Confrontation
  Clause.â€).Â  Moreover, the trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit the statement under
  Rule 804 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence suggests at least a tacit
  understanding that the declarant was â€œunavailable.â€
Finally, the State argues any error in admitting Johnsonâ€™s
  statement after his removal from the courtroom should be considered harmless.Â 
  In support of this argument, the State suggests that cross-examination by the
  defense would have served no useful purpose, pointing out that Johnson
  testified on direct examination that he had nothing to do with the crimes, that
  the prosecution was threatening him to make him say things that were not true
  in order to convict Mitchell, that the State had tried to brainwash him, and
  that he had been forced to appear at Mitchellâ€™s trial.Â  We disagree that
  Johnsonâ€™s conduct while he was on the stand warrants a finding of harmless
  error.
The supreme court has recently stated that â€œ[a] violation of a
  defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront witnesses is not per se reversible errorâ€ and that the appellate court â€œmust determine whether the
  error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.â€Â  State v. Davis, 371 S.C.
  170, 181, 638 S.E.2d 57, 63 (2006).Â  The court further explained that although the
  particular circumstances of a case should be considered in determining whether
  an error it harmless, â€œ[e]rror is only harmless â€˜when it â€œcould not have
  affected the result of the trial.â€ â€™ â€ Â Id. at 181-82, 638 S.E.2d at 63
  (quoting State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151
  (1986)) (internal citation omitted). Â 
Even if Johnsonâ€™s conduct on the stand was helpful to the defense,
  the State failed to explain in its brief how his behavior and evasive answers would
  inevitably lead to a determination by this Court that the admission of his
  statement did not contribute to the verdict beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  In the
  statement, Johnson did more than corroborate the Stateâ€™s allegations; he also
  gave specifics about Mitchellâ€™s involvement that were not provided by any other
  witnesses, including assertions that Mitchell helped to obtain the weapons used
  to attack the victim and shared in the spoils of the crime.Â  We are also
  concerned about the acknowledged lack of physical evidence linking Mitchell to
  the incident and the fact that Darby, the only eyewitness who provided any
  substantive testimony at the trial, implicated Mitchell only after authorities
  confronted her about the truth of her initial statement.Â  Considering the
  record as a whole, then, we cannot say that admission of Johnsonâ€™s statement could
  not reasonably have affected the result of Mitchellâ€™s trial.Â  See State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 362, 543 S.E.2d 586, 596 (Ct. App. 2001)
  (â€œIt is the duty of a reviewing court to consider the trial record as a whole
  and to ignore errors that are harmless, including most constitutional
  violations.â€) (citing U.S. v. Hasting, 461 U.S. 499, 509 (1983)), overruled
    on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 107, 610 S.E.2d
  494, 502 (2005).
II.Â  Exclusion
  of Evidence of Third-Party Guilt
Mitchell
  next argues the trial judge erred in refusing to allow him to submit into
  evidence telephone directories with listings similar to the name Darby
  initially gave to authorities.Â  He argues this evidence was admissible because
  it was probative on the issues of third-party guilt, Darbyâ€™s credibility, and
  the thoroughness of the police investigation.Â  Based on the record before us, we
  find no error.
We
  decline to address the issue of whether the telephone directory listings were
  admissible as evidence of Darbyâ€™s credibility or lack of it.Â  Defense counsel,
  in arguing for admission of the directories, pointed out only that Darbyâ€™s
  statements to police had been inconsistent, but never argued that admission of
  the directories would affect the juryâ€™s determination as to whether she was a
  believable witness.Â  Absent an argument at trial that this evidence was
  necessary to impeach Darbyâ€™s overall credibility, Mitchell cannot raise this
  argument on appeal.Â  See State v. Bryant, 372 S.C. 305,
  317, 642 S.E.2d 582, 589 (2007) (holding that, because an objection to the
  exclusion of certain testimony was not made to and ruled on by the trial judge,
  the issue was not preserved for appeal), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 245,
  169 L. Ed. 2d 169 (2007).
We
  further hold the trial judge correctly excluded the telephone books as evidence
  of third-party guilt under State v. Gregory, 198 S.C. 98, 16 S.E.2d 532
  (1941).Â  
In Gregory, the supreme court held â€œ
  â€˜[e]vidence which can have (no) other effect than to cast a bare suspicion upon
  another, or to raise a conjectural inference as to the commission of the crime
  by another, is not admissible.â€™ â€Â  Id. at 104, 16 S.E.2d at 534 (quoting
  16 C.J. 560).Â  See alsoÂ  State v. Rice, 375 S.C. 302, 317, 652
  S.E.2d 409, 416 (Ct. App. 2007) (â€œOur state supreme court has imposed strict
  limitations on the admissibility of testimony indicating third-party guilt.â€).
Although the United States Supreme Court recently addressed the
  issue of the admissibility of evidence of third-party guilt in Holmes v.
    South Carolina, 547 U.S. 319 (2006), that decision overruled the
  application of the limits on such evidence only to the extent that these limits
  rely on the prosecutionâ€™s evidence against the defendant rather than on the
  strength of the evidence proffered by the defendant to establish third-party
  guilt.Â  In the present case, there is nothing in the record suggesting the
  trial judge even considered the strength of the Stateâ€™s evidence against
  Mitchell in refusing to admit the telephone books into evidence.Â  The fact that
  the directories may have contained listings of individuals with names that were
  either identical or similar to the name Darby initially gave to the police is simply
  not evidence that any of these individuals was involved in the incident.
Furthermore,
  we hold no prejudice resulted from the exclusion of the evidence insofar as it
  was proffered to demonstrate the police were not thorough in investigating the
  matter.Â  See Rule 103(a), SCRE (â€œError may not be predicated upon a
  ruling which admits or excludes evidence unless a substantial right of the
  party is affected . . . .â€).Â  Although the trial judge prohibited the defense
  from introducing directory listings of similarly named individuals without
  evidence to connect such persons with the crime, he allowed the defense to ask
  what law enforcement did and did not do in their attempt to locate Terrance
  James, including whether the police checked the National Crime Information
  Center records, what police did to â€œflush outâ€ Terrance James, and whether
  police looked for such a person in the local area. Â We have found nothing in
  Mitchellâ€™s brief explaining why this line of questioning would not be
  sufficient to cover the issue of the adequacy of the police investigation.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold
  the trial judge committed reversible error in admitting Kelvin Johnsonâ€™s
  statement to the police, Mitchellâ€™s objection to the statement and arguments on
  appeal were sufficient to preserve the matter for our review, and Mitchell is
  entitled to a new trial on this ground.Â  Based on the record before us, we
  further hold the trial judge correctly excluded evidence submitted by the
  defense of third-party guilt.
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON
  and SHORT, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  Although Darbyâ€™s statement refers to her
  co-participants as â€œKelvin and Terrance James,â€ there appears to be no dispute
  that she was referring to Kelvin Johnson. 
[2]Â  The supreme court affirmed this Courtâ€™s decision in Gillian,
  but modified it on grounds not related to the issues relevant to this appeal.Â  State
    v. Gillian, 373 S.C. 601, 646 S.E.2d 872 (2007).

description: Chad Jones was killed when he was shot in the head as he attempted to escape after being taken into custody by Richland County Sheriffâ€™s deputies.  His estate appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of directed verdict in favor of Sheriff Leon Lott in his official capacity.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Willie L.
          Jones, Personal Representative of the Estate of Chad Jones, Appellant,
        v.
        Leon Lott, Linn
          Pitts, Gilbert Gallegos, and Clark Frady, Individually and in their official
          capacities with the Richland County Sheriff’s Department, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge 

Opinion No.Â  4396
Heard May 8, 2008 â€“ Filed May 28, 2008 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Hemphill P. Pride, II, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Andrew F. Lindemann, William H. Davidson, II, Robert D. Garfield, all
          of Columbia, for Respondents.

      
    
  

HEARN,
  C.J.: Â Chad Jones was killed when he was shot in the
  head as he attempted to escape after being taken into custody by Richland
  County Sheriffâ€™s deputies.Â  His estate appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of
  directed verdict in favor of Sheriff Leon
  Lott in his official capacity.
   We affirm.
FACTS
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Two members of Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department,
  Corporal Linn Pitts and Deputy Gilbert Gallegos, attempted to pull over Jones
  when he failed to use a turn signal.Â  Jones refused to stop and the officers pursued
  him.Â  Eventually, Jonesâ€™ vehicle struck an air conditioning unit at the Waverly
  Street Apartments, and Jones fled on foot, ultimately dropping a .22 caliber
  revolver. Â The officers found Jones in the laundry room of a nearby house, and
  after a brief struggle, he was subdued and apprehended.Â  The officers found a
  clear plastic container that, at the time, they believed contained crack
  cocaine.[1]Â 
  Jones was put in handcuffs and placed in the rear of Pittsâ€™ police cruiser,
  while the officers began preparing the paperwork accompanying the arrest.Â  
Ultimately, Jones
  was arrested for ten criminal and traffic offenses.[2] Â At the time he was arrested, Jones identified himself to the officers as
  â€œLavaris Richardson,â€ although a Columbia Police Department officer on the
  scene identified his true identity.Â  A quick check revealed Jones also had
  outstanding arrest warrants for attempted burglary, assault with intent to
  kill, and assault and battery with intent to kill.Â  
At some point while
  the officers were working on their paperwork, Pitts and Gallegos observed Jones
  fidgeting in the back seat of the cruiser.Â  Gallegos and a third deputy who had
  arrived with a paddy wagon to transport Jones, Deputy Clark Frady, removed
  Jones from the cruiser, and conducted a pat down search.Â  Finding nothing, they
  again secured Jones in the back of the cruiser with his hands handcuffed behind
  his back and his seat belt fastened.Â  Because it was an unusually warm day in
  November, Pitts left the engine of the cruiser running so that the air
  conditioning would be operating, and left the Plexiglas window in the cruiser
  open in order to let the air reach Jones.Â  Initially, the windows of the
  cruiser were also open, but the officers closed them when Jones continued to
  yell out to passersby.Â  The officers then continued their paperwork on the hood
  of the cruiser. Â 
Thereafter, Jones
  apparently maneuvered his handcuffed hands to the front of his body, and
  squeezed through the open Plexiglas window into the driverâ€™s seat of the
  cruiser, locking the doors.Â  The officers noticed Jones in the front seat when
  they heard the sound of him turning the key to the already-running vehicle. Â The
  officers yelled to Jones to stop and unlock the doors, and Gallegos
  unsuccessfully attempted to break the front driverâ€™s side window with his
  baton.Â  Gallegos then retreated to his own cruiser in anticipation of a second
  pursuit, while Pitts tried to unlock the passenger side door with his key.Â  
Meanwhile, Jones
  had placed the cruiser in reverse and backed up approximately twenty feet.Â 
  Both Pitts and Frady repositioned themselves in front of the cruiser, and
  shouted instructions for Jones to stop the vehicle and turn off the ignition.Â 
  Jones ignored these instructions, instead slumping in the driverâ€™s seat,
  placing the cruiser back in drive, and eventually stepping on the accelerator.Â 
  The cruiser first cut left toward Pitts, who moved out of the way and fired a
  shot hitting the rear hubcap.Â  The cruiser then turned and came directly at
  Frady, who fired twice into the vehicle.Â  One of Fradyâ€™s shots struck Jones in
  the back of the head, killing him.Â  
Jonesâ€™ estate brought
  a wrongful death and survival action against Sheriff Leon Lott, Linn Pitts,
  Gilbert Gallegos, and Clark Frady, individually and in their official
  capacities with the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department, based on allegations
  of negligence and civil conspiracy.Â  Defendants filed a motion for summary
  judgment, which Judge Allison Lee granted with respect to all the individual
  defendants, but allowed the case to proceed against Lott in his official
  capacity as to the gross negligence claim.Â  The circuit court ultimately
  granted Lottâ€™s motion for a directed verdict at the close of Jonesâ€™ case.Â  This
  appeal follows. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On a
  motion for directed verdict, the trial court is required to view the evidence
  and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most
  favorable to the party opposing the motions and to deny the motions where
  either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in
  doubt. Â Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648
  (2006). Â The appellate court will reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a directed
  verdict motion only when there is no evidence to support the ruling or where the ruling is
  controlled by an error of law.Â  Id. at 434-35, 629 S.E.2d at 648. Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Jones contends the
  circuit court erred in granting Lottâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the
  following grounds:Â  (1) Richland County deputies had no duty to Jones with
  respect to the manner in which they confined and secured him upon taking him
  into custody; (2) the use of deadly force by the deputies was objectively
  reasonable as a matter of law; and (3) Jonesâ€™ attempted escape outweighed any
  negligence on the part of the deputies in failing to secure him.Â  
The circuit court
  granted Lottâ€™s motion for directed verdict on four grounds:Â  (1) Sheriffâ€™s
  Department deputies did not owe a duty to Jones to secure him in the back of
  the police cruiser in a manner that made it impossible to escape; (2) any
  negligence on the deputiesâ€™ part in securing Jones in the cruiser was
  outweighed as a matter of law under our comparative negligence standard by
  Jonesâ€™ actions in his escape attempt; (3) the use of deadly force by the
  deputies in that situation was objectively reasonable as a matter of law; and (4)
  the Sheriffâ€™s Department was entitled to immunity under Section 15-78-60(6) of
  the South Carolina Code (2005) for the method of providing police protection.Â 
  As illustrated by Jonesâ€™ contentions on appeal listed above, Jones failed to
  appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict on the issue of Lottâ€™s
  immunity under section 15-78-60(6).Â  Consequently, the circuit courtâ€™s ruling
  on Lottâ€™s immunity is the law of the case and warrants our affirmance of the
  directed verdict under the two issue rule.Â  See Anderson v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 322 S.C. 417, 420, 472 S.E.2d 253,
  254 (1996) (finding when a general verdict can be supported by more than one
  cause of action submitted to it, the appellate court will affirm unless the
  appellant appeals all causes of action).Â  In Anderson, the supreme court
  explained that the two issue rule is also applicable in situations not
  involving a jury:Â Â Â  

  It
    should be noted that although cases generally have discussed the â€œtwo issueâ€
    rule in the context of the appellate treatment of general jury verdicts, the
    rule is applicable under other circumstances on appeal, including affirmance of
    orders of trial courts. Â For example, if a court directs a verdict for a
    defendant on the basis of the defenses of statute of limitations and
    contributory negligence, the order would be affirmed under the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule
    if the plaintiff failed to appeal both grounds or if one of the grounds
    required affirmance.

Id. at 420 n.1, 472 S.E.2d at 255 n.1.Â  See also Anderson v. Short, 323 S.C. 522, 476 S.E.2d 475 (1996) (where a decision
  is based on more than one ground, the appellate court will affirm unless the
  appellant appeals all grounds because the unappealed ground will become the law
  of the case); First Union Natâ€™l Bank of S.C. v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554,
  566, 511 S.E.2d 372, 378 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding an â€œunchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is
  the law of the case and requires
  affirmanceâ€).
Moreover, Lott
  maintains on appeal that an additional sustaining ground exists under Section
  15-78-60(21) of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  We agree.
Section
  15-78-60(21) provides:Â  

  The
    governmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from . . . the decision
    to or implementation of release, discharge, parole, or furlough of any persons
    in the custody of any governmental entity, including but not limited to a
    prisoner, inmate, juvenile, patient, or client or the escape of these
      persons.

(emphasis supplied).Â  This
  argument was presented to the circuit court; however, it was not a ground upon
  which the court orally granted Lottâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â 
  Nevertheless, this court may consider any ground present in the record to
  affirm the circuit courtâ€™s judgment.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt.
    Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000) (finding when a circuit court
  rules in favor of one party, it is not necessary for preservation purposes for
  the winning party to ask the court to revisit its decision in order to rule on
  the remaining issues and arguments it put forth).Â Â  Therefore, we find section
  15-78-60(21) provides Lott immunity from the loss resulting from the escape
  attempt of Jones, who, having already been arrested, was in custody and a
  prisoner.
Accordingly, the
  circuit courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict to Lott is 
AFFIRMED.
SHORT, J., and KONDUROS,
  J., concur.


[1] Police tested and later determined the white powder
  was washing detergent.
[2] These included:Â  failure to use a turn signal;
  leaving the scene of an accident; failure to stop for blue lights and siren;
  driving without a driverâ€™s license; possession of a stolen vehicle; possession
  with intent to distribute crack cocaine; unlawful carrying of a pistol;
  possession of a pistol under the age of 21; resisting arrest; and possession
  with intent to distribute crack cocaine within a half mile of school.

title: Brown v. Brown
description: In this appeal from family court, the husband claimed the family court erred by not finding the wife committed adultery and in turn by awarding the wife alimony.  Additionally, the husband claimed the family court erred in its disposition of certain assets and in requiring the husband to pay the wife's attorney fees.  The Court of Appeals affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded, finding the husband presented direct and overwhelming circumstantial evidence to sustain his burden of proof for adultery, such that an award of alimony to the wife was improper.  The Court of Appeals also found the value of the parties' timeshare condominium should be awarded against each party equally, rather than solely against the husband, as both parties allowed it to enter into default, yet neither attempted to prevent this from occurring.  The Court also held the wife failed to show that the husband's gun collection was marital property as her testimony on its value, the date of its acquisition, and the amount of guns within the collection was speculative at best.  Lastly, the Court of Appeals remanded the award of attorney's fees to the family court for reconsideration based on the Court's findings.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Thomas Lee
          Brown, Appellant,
        v.
        Gina Marie
          (Stiles) Brown, Respondent,
        and
        Gina Marie
          (Stiles) Brown, Third Party
          Plaintiff,
        v.
        Myron L. Brown
          & Carol J. Brown, Third Party
          Defendants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4397
  Submitted March 1,
  2008 â€“ Filed May 28, 2008

AFFIRMED IN
PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Oscar W. Bannister, of Greenville, for
          Appellant.
        Kenneth C. Porter, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this divorce action, Thomas Lee Brown (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s
  failure to find Gina Marie Brown (Wife) committed adultery, thus barring her
  from receiving alimony.Â  Additionally, Husband appeals the family courtâ€™s
  inclusion of certain items as marital property and the assessment of Wifeâ€™s
  attorneyâ€™s fees against him.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Husband and Wife (collectively the Browns) married in Ohio on November 27, 1982.Â  They had five children together during their marriage.Â  In
  1985, the Browns moved to Greenville, South Carolina.Â  In 1989, Husband
  purchased a house with several acres of property in Travelers Rest, South Carolina, but the Browns continued to reside in a house they were renting in Greenville,   South Carolina.Â  In 1995, Husband and Wife built a new home on the
  property in Travelerâ€™s Rest where they resided throughout the remainder of the
  marriage.Â Â  
Chris Craft (Craft) sold and installed the windows in the Brownsâ€™
  new home.Â  A few months later, Craft and his wife began socializing with the
  Browns.Â  Around Christmas of 1996, Husband took the children to church
  while Wife remained at home with their baby.Â  Husband returned home and
  unexpectedly discovered Craft there. Â In explaining Craftâ€™s presence,
  Wife told Husband Craft had stopped by to look at their Christmas lights.Â  
Wife and Craft became close and began having lunch without either
  of their spouseâ€™s knowledge.Â  On several occasions, Craft and Wife met
  in a remote part of a restaurantâ€™s parking lot and fondled each other in Wifeâ€™s
  car.Â  In 1998, Husband discovered Craft and Wife were having lunch together.Â  After confronting Wife, she temporarily ceased contact with Craft but
  admitted to subsequently resuming their relationship.Â  Additionally, Craft and
  Wife frequently talked on the phone.Â  In late 2000, Husband discovered
  Wife had a cell phone for which she had the bill sent to her motherâ€™s address,
  and Husband testified Wife had called Craft several dozen times from Wifeâ€™s
  cell phone.Â  
Wife admitted her relationship with Craft was sexual in nature.Â 
  Over the course of their relationship, Wife admitted to kissing Craft â€œa couple
  of dozen times,â€ permitting him to grope her breasts, and allowing him to
  fondle her genital area.Â  Wife stated she was in love with Craft and discussed
  marriage with him.Â  Furthermore, Wife agreed her relationship with Craft was
  â€œsexual to a degree,â€ and while not admitting to engaging in sexual
  intercourse, she stated both she and Craft desired sex with each other.Â  
On November 14, 2000, Husband filed for divorce on the grounds of
  adultery.Â  However, the action was
  administratively dismissed, and Husband filed a new action in 2002. Â Thereafter, Wife filed an answer denying
  she committed adultery and a third-party complaint against Husbandâ€™s parents.Â 
  Wife alleged Husbandâ€™s parents were necessary parties to the divorce action
  because Husband and his parents had â€œcommon financial interests,â€ and Wife
  believed they might claim an interest in a house in Husbandâ€™s name as well as
  property surrounding the marital residence.Â  Pursuant to a consent order, Wifeâ€™s
  action against Husbandâ€™s parents was consolidated with the divorce action.[1]Â  
Following a hearing on the matter, the
  family court found Wife had not committed adultery, but her behavior with Craft
  did not aid in the preservation of the marriage.Â  The family court
  further found Husbandâ€™s predilection towards online pornography did not aid in
  the preservation of the marriage.Â  Â 
Finding Wife had never worked, the family court awarded Wife
  alimony of $3,197 per month.Â  The family court found Husbandâ€™s net monthly
  income was $6,136.48 with an annual earning capacity of $150,000.Â  The family
  court also noted Husbandâ€™s ability to make several personal expenditures, such
  as buying two expensive motorcycles and flying lessons, while he was paying
  temporary unallocated support of $5,000 a month.Â  
The parties agreed Wife would retain
  custody of the minor children.Â  The family court awarded Wife child
  support of $1,743 per month. Â The family court equally divided the
  marital property, awarding each party approximately half the value of the
  marital estate.Â  
Furthermore, the family court ordered Husband to pay a total of
  $58,895.76 in Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees, which included $27,000 previously paid
  pursuant to a temporary order and $3,000 previously paid to Wife during the
  pendency of the action.Â  The family court also ordered Husband pay
  $5,006.50 of Wifeâ€™s expert witness fee.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered Husbandâ€™s parents to pay $5,006.50 of
  Wifeâ€™s expert witness fee and $5,000 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of
  law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  When
  reviewing decisions of the family court, we are cognizant of the fact the
  family court had the opportunity to see the witnesses, hear â€œthe testimony
  delivered from the stand, and had the benefit of that personal observance of
  and contact with the parties which is of peculiar value in arriving at a
  correct result in a case of this character.â€Â  DuBose v. DuBose, 259
  S.C. 418, 423, 192 S.E.2d 329, 331 (1972).Â  When
  the evidence is conflicting and susceptible of different inferences, the family
  court has the duty of determining not only the law of the case, but the facts
  as well, because it had
  the benefit of observing the witnesses and determining how much credence to
  give each witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  Anders v.
    Anders, 285
  S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985).
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Adultery
Husband contends the family court erred in failing to
  find Wife committed adultery, and thus, Wife should be barred from receiving
  alimony.Â  We agree.
A
  family court may not award alimony to a spouse who commits adultery before the
  earliest of (1) the formal signing of a written property or marital settlement
  agreement or (2) entry of a permanent order of separate maintenance and support
  or of a permanent order approving a property or marital settlement agreement
  between the parties.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A) (Supp. 2007).Â  
Proof
  of adultery as a ground for divorce must be â€œclear and positive and the
  infidelity must be established by a clear preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  McLaurin v. McLaurin, 294 S.C. 132, 133, 363 S.E.2d 111, 111 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  A â€œpreponderance of the evidenceâ€ is evidence which convinces as
  to its truth.Â  DuBose, 259 S.C. at 424, 192 S.E.2d at 331.Â  Because of the â€œclandestine natureâ€ of adultery, obtaining
  evidence of the commission of the act by the testimony of eyewitnesses is rarely
  possible, so direct evidence is not necessary to establish the charge.Â  Fulton v. Fulton, 293 S.C. 146, 147,
  359 S.E.2d 88, 88 (Ct.
  App. 1987).Â  
Accordingly,
  adultery may be proven by circumstantial evidence that establishes both a
  disposition to commit the offense and the opportunity to do so.Â  Hartley v. Hartley, 292 S.C. 245, 246-47, 355 S.E.2d 869, 871 (Ct. App.
  1987).Â  Generally, â€œproof
  must be sufficiently definite to identify the time and place of the offense and
  the circumstances under which it was committed.â€Â  Loftis v. Loftis, 284 S.C. 216, 218, 325 S.E.2d 73, 74 (Ct. App. 1985). Â Evidence placing a spouse and a third party together on several
  occasions, without more, does not warrant the conclusion the spouse committed
  adultery.Â  Fox v. Fox, 277 S.C. 400, 402, 288 S.E.2d 390, 391 (1982).Â  
Our
  courts have not specifically stated what sexual acts constitute adultery.Â  Panhorst v. Panhorst, 301 S.C. 100, 104, 390 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  In Nemeth v. Nemeth, 325 S.C. 480, 486,
  481 S.E.2d 181, 184 (Ct. App. 1997), this Court noted South Carolina has
  rejected the argument equating adultery with intercourse.Â  In Nemeth,
  the wife took a cruise and stayed in a cabin with a man other than her
  husband.Â  Id. at 484, 481 S.E.2d at 183.Â  The wife denied she committed
  adultery and introduced evidence she had chronic pain that made intercourse
  difficult for her.Â  Id. at 485, 481 S.E.2d at 184.Â  This Court found
  adultery, stating sexual intercourse is not required to establish adultery;
  sexual intimacy is enough.Â  Id. at 486, 481 S.E.2d at 184.
Additionally, in Panhorst,
  the wife was accused of adultery and sought to testify her alleged paramour was
  impotent and thus was incapable of performing intercourse.Â  301 S.C. at 104,
  390 S.E.2d at 378.Â  This Court found â€œher assertion
  that she has first hand knowledge and experience of [her paramourâ€™s] sexual
  abilities, if the family court had considered it, would have supported the
  courtâ€™s finding of adultery.â€Â  Id.
In McElveen v.
  McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 598, 506 S.E.2d 1, 8 (Ct. App. 1998), this Court
  declined to find the wife committed adultery because â€œthere [was] virtually no
  evidence of a romantic or sexual relationship between the [wife and her
  paramour].â€Â  This Court noted without evidence to support a romantic
  relationship, including love letters, romantic cards, hand-holding, hugging,
  kissing, or any other romantic demonstrations or actions between the wife and
  her paramour, adultery was not adequately established.Â  Id.
This Court
  reiterated in McLaurin, 294 S.C. at 133-34, 363 S.E.2d at 111, that
  circumstantial evidence indicating opportunity and inclination is sufficient to
  sustain a finding of adultery.Â  In McLaurin, we affirmed the family
  courtâ€™s finding the husband committed adultery when the only evidence of
  adultery was the wifeâ€™s testimony that her husband admitted committing adultery
  and a process serverâ€™s statement that the divorce pleadings were served on the
  husband at the alleged paramourâ€™s residence where the paramour answered the door
  â€œcomfortably clothed,â€ but the husband came to the door fully dressed.Â  Id. at 135, 363 S.E.2d at 112.Â  Noting the husbandâ€™s presence in the paramourâ€™s
  house without more was not enough to establish adultery, this Court found the
  incident was â€œsome evidence that [the husband and his paramour] had the
  opportunity and dispositionâ€ to commit adultery.Â  Id.Â  
Husband has the burden of proving Wife committed
  adultery.Â  See McElveen, 332 S.C. at 598, 506 S.E.2d at 8-9 (â€œ[The]
  [h]usband bore the burden at trial, as he does on appeal, of convincing the
  court that [the] [w]ife committed adultery.â€).Â  While Husband is not required to
  show direct evidence of the actual act, he must demonstrate Wifeâ€™s inclination
  and opportunity to commit adultery.Â  Fulton, 293 S.C. at 147, 359 S.E.2d at 88.
The family court determined Wife and Craft may have had the
  opportunity to commit adultery at two locations: (1) in the Brownsâ€™ home around
  Christmas when Husband was at church and (2) in the car in a parking lot at
  lunchtime.Â  Despite these apparent opportunities, the family court noted Wifeâ€™s
  strict moral upbringing regarding sexual activity supported Wifeâ€™s position
  that she and Craft had not had sexual intercourse.Â  
We agree that Craft and Wifeâ€™s presence in the Brownsâ€™ home, without
  more, is not sufficient to establish adultery.Â  See Fox, 277 S.C. at 402, 288
  S.E.2d at 391 (finding evidence
  that a spouse and a third party were together
  on several occasions, without more, does not warrant a finding of adultery).Â  
However,
  we disagree with the family courtâ€™s finding that Wife and Craftâ€™s continued and
  secretive meetings in various parking lots did not provide sufficient evidence
  to establish an opportunity to commit adultery.Â  The family court found Craft and Wife met
  approximately twenty-four times over a four to five year period.Â  While the admitted
  meetings were during the daytime in a car parked in public parking lots, Wifeâ€™s
  and Craftâ€™s admissions to the conduct that occurred while in the car are
  circumstantial evidence that adultery was committed.Â  
Furthermore, Wifeâ€™s and Craftâ€™s own admissions establish they were
  inclined to commit adultery.Â  Craft testified the activities he and Wife
  engaged in were sexual in nature.Â  Wife and Craft admitted that when
  they would meet for lunch, they would often kiss in Wifeâ€™s car.Â  Craft
  also touched Wifeâ€™s breast and removed her bra. Â Both Wife and Craft touched
  one another below the waist, outside of their clothing.Â  Wife also admitted
  Craft touched Wife â€œunder her pantiesâ€ once or twice.Â  Additionally, Wife stated she was in love with Craft
  and that she discussed marriage with him.Â  Further, she admitted their
  relationship was sexual to a degree, and she desired to have sexual intercourse
  with Craft.Â  
Their
  admissions to meeting for one-on-one lunches, calling each other frequently,
  kissing, and fondling indicate a â€œromantic relationshipâ€ existed, which also
  supports a finding of adultery.Â  Wife acknowledged she ceased talking to and
  seeing Craft for a period of time after Husband confronted her, showing Wife
  knew her actions were wrongful and inappropriate for a married woman.Â  While we
  defer to the family court on issues of credibility, sufficient direct and
  overwhelmingly circumstantial evidence is present in the record to clearly prove
  Wife committed adultery.Â  The evidence here of opportunity and inclination is
  too compelling to be brushed aside on the basis of Wifeâ€™s â€œstrict moral
  upbringingâ€ and her claims that the romantic rendezvous always stopped short of
  sexual intercourse.Â  
Therefore, based on the evidence Husband presented, we
  hold Husband met his burden in proving Wife committed adultery.Â  Accordingly,
  the family court erred in failing to find Wife committed adultery and
  consequently in awarding Wife alimony.Â  
II.Â  Equitable Division
Husband contests several decisions of the family court
  regarding the distribution of the marital estate, specifically the assessment
  of the value of the partiesâ€™ timeshare solely against Husband and the family
  courtâ€™s determinations that a backhoe and a gun collection were marital
  property.Â  We address each argument in turn. 
Marital
  property includes all real and personal property the parties acquired during
  the marriage and owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital
  litigation.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2007).Â  The
  ultimate goal of apportionment is to divide the marital estate, as a whole, in
  a manner which fairly reflects each spouseâ€™s contribution to the economic
  partnership and also the effect on each of the parties of ending that
  partnership.Â  Johnson v. Johnson,296 S.C. 289, 298, 372 S.E.2d 107, 112 (Ct. App.
  1988). Â The division of marital
  property is within the family courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be
  disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion. Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 290, 617
  S.E.2d 359, 361 (2005).Â  The appellate court looks to the overall fairness of the
  apportionment.Â  Deidun v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 58, 606
  S.E.2d 489, 495 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThe
  doctrine of equitable distribution is based on a recognition that marriage is,
  among other things, an economic partnership.â€Â  Mallett
    v. Mallett,323 S.C. 141, 150,
  473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œUpon dissolution of the marriage, property acquired during
  the marriage should be divided and distributed in a manner which fairly
  reflects each spouseâ€™s contribution to its acquisition, regardless of which
  spouse holds legal title.â€Â  Id.
A.Â 
  Timeshare
Husband
  argues the family court erred in assessing the entire value of the Hilton Head timeshare
  against him because it found he was at fault in allowing the timeshare to go
  into default.Â  We agree.
The Browns owned a Hilton Head timeshare valued at $27,500 at the
  commencement of the divorce proceedings.Â  However, the timeshare had
  gone into default by the time of the divorce decree.Â  The family court
  found no credible evidence of an outstanding mortgage and stated Husband
  allowed the â€œtimeshare to go into default quite possibly for spite.â€
For
  purposes of equitable distribution, marital property is typically valued at the time of the
  commencement of the marital litigation.Â  Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C.
  141, 151, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Often, â€œthe value of marital
  assets . . . change, sometimes substantially, between the time the action was
  commenced and its final resolution.â€Â  Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C.
  222, 228, 512 S.E.2d 539, 542 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œ[B]oth
  parties are entitled to share in any appreciation or depreciation that occurs
  to marital property after separation but before divorce.â€Â  Arnal v. Arnal, 363
  S.C. 268, 293, 609 S.E.2d 821, 834 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  However, this Court
